PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Ms H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 243rd report of the Committee entitled Review of Defence Project Management. The report consists of two volumes, volume 1 being the report proper and volume 2 being the project analyses. I seek leave to make a statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

SPEECH.PARA: This report presents the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the Department of Defence's management of its major capital equipment acquisitions. It is presented in two volumes. The first comprises the main report and contains the Committee's findings, recommendations and supporting arguments. The second volume contains analyses of sixteen current or recent defence projects examined in detail by the Committee. The Utz report on the higher defence organisation noted `a history of criticism and complaint surrounding Defence procurement'.
In an examination of ten major defence projects, the Auditor-General found that `Defence project management practices were unsatisfactory, contributing to:
Significant additional costs to the Commonwealth;
the need for scarce resources to be engaged in rectifying project problems; and
a diminution of the defence capability through untimely delivery of equipment and facilities and through equipment and facilities not meeting technical performance objectives.

The Committee sought to identify changes in defence organisational arrangements, decision-making processes and management systems which would improve the efficiency, effectiveness and accountability of defence project management. The inquiry encompassed the full range of activities associated with the acquisition of defence equipment, from the conception of a need to the introduction of a specific brand item of equipment into service. The Committee drew a great deal of its evidence from a detailed investigation of sixteen recent major defence projects. The sample included some of Australia's largest peace time defence equipment acquisitions.

I commend to honourable members the detailed assessments of these projects in volume two of the report. Of the sixteen projects examined by the Committee, eleven have failed or may fail to be completed on time, to budget or to technical requirements. A multitude of factors have contributed to these unsatisfactory results. Most could be attributed to inefficient and ineffective defence project management. The most common shortcomings in defence project management were:
Inadequate evaluation of project proposals;
underestimates of project costs, time scales and risks;
incomplete project planning;
inadequate evaluation of tenders;
contracts which did not specify all contract requirements or provide effective incentives for contractors to minimise cost or perform to schedule;
inadequate monitoring of contractor performance;
contract supervision which did not submit the sometimes large number of contract changes to sufficient scrutiny to preserve project budgets and schedules; and
generally slow departmental decision-making processes.
These project shortcomings reflected several systematic inadequacies in Defence project management:
a dispersal of project management responsibilities and authority;
inadequate project management resources, especially in numbers of staff and computer support;
a shortage of experienced project managers;
limited training in project management at all levels;
low retention of knowledge due to a high staff turnover; and
inadequate management information systems within project offices and throughout the Department.

An illustration of the problems which can befall a project when insufficient and inadequate resources are applied to project management is provided by the design of the cargo handling and storage systems on the Royal Australian Navy's new fleet underway replenishment ship, HMAS Success. A Cargo Working Party was formed in February 1977 to address cargo handling and storage on HMAS Success. However, the Cargo Working Party did not meet for the first time until three months later in May 1977. There were long breaks in deliberations of the Cargo Working Party and in 1983 fundamental design parameters of the ship were still being addressed. The Committee was told that the reason for the lack of progress of the Cargo Working Party was its lack of resources until the middle of 1983. Not only was the Cargo Working Party slow to produce results but sometimes the results themselves were wanting. A major decision of the Cargo Working Party was to retain the RAN standard pallet for ammunition and provision pallets on HMAS Success. There were sound reasons for this decision. Unfortunately, the Cargo Working Party did not think through the implications of the decision for the existing design of the ship.

The decision to adopt RAN standard pallet size for HMAS Success involved a difference of 600 kilograms in the weight of a single ammunition pallet. The heavier pallets needed a heavier forklift to carry them and the heavier forklifts required modifications to the ammunition lifts for carrying the forklifts down to the magazines where they move the pallets. The combination of heavier forklifts and pallets exceeded the concentrated load designed for the replenishment deck and the deck had to be strengthened. Existing stowage arrangements in the magazines were also deleted and a Forgeweld system of flexible, adjustable stowage installed. Perhaps fortuitously the Cargo Working Party decision cost only $150,000 and 10 weeks excusable delay.

An example of the difficulties which can ensue from the underestimation of the complexity of a project and its associated risks is given by the history of the Army's Hiport/Medport Mobile Radio Terminals project. The Committee heard a great deal of underestimation of the complexity of the project.

The Department saw the project as a straightforward purchasing exercise although it involved significant design development for the initial equipment item. This failure to correctly estimate risk was a major contributing factor to two ensuing problems concerning the vetting of design drawings and the testing of initial equipment items. The contract stipulated that design drawings would be submitted to the Commonwealth before initial equipment items were cleared for production. However, the Commonwealth underestimated the number of drawings which were to be submitted by the contractor. Indeed, at the time of contract award there was no estimate of the number of drawings involved. The Army's Design Approval Authority was unable to cope with the number of contractor-supplied drawings and some 501 drawings were approved without vetting.

The contract also provided that, prior to the manufacture of follow-on equipment, the initial production item was to be tested in accordance with contractor-supplied specifications to be approved by the Army's Design Authority. However, not only did the specification of the Commonwealth's test requirements in the contract omit the full series of tests but insufficient time was allowed under the contract for the approval of the contractor's test specifications. The resolution of these problems resulted in an increase of $3.5m in project costs and 41 months extension to the contract delivery dates.

The findings do not necessarily reflect defence project management today. The Department has acknowledged and responded to many of the shortcomings identified by the Committee. Over the five-year to six-year time span of the projects under review there have been a number of improvements in defence project management. Greater authority has been given to project directors and there has been a gradual increase in the level of resources allocated to project management.
In June 1984, after the inquiry was well under way, the major defence equipment acquisition functions were centralised in a new Capital Procurement Organisation.

This change, the Department of Defence believed, would overcome the unsatisfactory dispersal of project responsibilities and authority, assign more authority to project directors, and simplify project organisational arrangements. The effects of the re-organisation had yet to make themselves felt in the time frame of the Committee's inquiry.

The Committee believes that the Capital Procurement Organisation initiative will significantly improve defence project management. However, we have a number of reservations about the adequacy of these measures. They include:

The change may represent only a formal change in the top management structure that will leave the underlying Service ways of doing things unchanged. The Committee believes that the procurement function should be given independence from the Services. In the past there has been a tendency for the Service sponsors or functional areas to maintain undue control, particularly over the technical aspects of projects. As a result large numbers of specification changes have been made with adverse effects on project costs and schedules.

Most project directors do not have authority commensurate with their enhanced responsibilities. In addition to their limited control over technical aspects, project directors have insufficient control over project administrative resources.
The measures make no explicit reference to training and other critical personnel management issues.
Current planning envisages only a limited and gradual upgrading of computer support for project management.
Basic Trainer Project

An example of the difficulties which can face a project when technical considerations are allowed to drive a project in seeming isolation from cost or schedule concerns is supplied by the RAAF's basic pilot trainer aircraft project. In the basic trainer project this situation arose out of the failure to resolve conflicting project objectives and divided project management responsibilities. In addition to the acquisition of a suitable trainer aircraft, the RAAF wanted to re-establish a local military aircraft design capability to meet its overall aircraft support needs. The RAAF chose to pursue this objective by requiring the aircraft to be designed to military specifications. Another major objective of the project was the development of export sales to defray design and development costs and sustain the industry's acquired design capabilities. As aircraft design and development got underway however these parallel objectives of marketability and the development of design expertise came into open conflict.

Dispute arose between the RAAF and the contractor, Australian Aircraft Consortium Pty Ltd, as to the status of the military specifications. AAC told the Committee that its understanding was that the specification was a target which would not be met to the full letter of the law. The AAC seemed prepared to compromise military specifications when 100 per cent compliance threatened to affect cost, schedule and marketability of the design. The RAAF, the AAC argued, was insisting on strict compliance with the specification even when non-compliance would have no significant influence on the RAAF's aircraft performance requirements. The RAAF told the Committee that it was in a situation of designing an aeroplane to specification but not regardless of cost. It added however that `undue compromise of the specification . . . would contribute to defeating the purpose of the project'.

Under the management arrangements adopted for the basic trainer project, responsibility for the project was shared between the Air Force Materiel Division and the Air Force Technical Services Division. Although the Chief of Air Force Materiel was responsible for the overall management of the project, the Chief of Air Force Technical Services was the design approval authority and the air worthiness authority. Parallel with Materiel Division's project management organisation, the Chief of Air Force Technical Services had personnel responsible for supervising the design, engineering and quality assurance aspects of the project, although they were required to copy to, or channel, relevant information through the Project Director or his representatives. A 13-month slippage in schedule and a prospective doubling of the project cost appears to have persuaded the Government to abandon local design and development and opt for the licenced production of an existing overseas design.

We believe there is considerable scope for further improvements in defence project management. Unfortunately, the Department of Defence appears not to share the urgency the Committee attaches to these improvements, largely, we suspect, because it does not appreciate the full costs of inefficient and ineffective project management. Failure to introduce defence equipment on time, to budget or to technical requirements, affects not only the Commonwealth Budget but also our defence capability and Australian industry. For instance:
The savings forgone by projects not being delivered to cost represent resources not available to be applied to other defence purposes or other areas of Government expenditure;
The shortfall in capability which may result from project delays is a cost to defence preparedness; and

Contracting delays and generally slow decision-making processes impose significant costs on contractors and on the efficiency of Australian industry since Defence is a major customer of sections of Australian industry.

For the Committee, the apparently secondary priority defence accords to efficient and effective project management underlined the importance of public accountability. If other defence priorities outweigh efficient project management, the choices and their consequences should be made explicit. Unfortunately, parliamentary scrutiny of the defence equipment acquisition process is inadequate.

The Committee has made 68 recommendations to improve the effectiveness, efficiency and accountability of defence project management; 65 for action by the Department of Defence and three for action by other Commonwealth agencies. To improve the effectiveness of defence project management the Committee has recommended:
(1) Firmly delineating the responsibilities of the Capital Procurement Organisation and the Service sponsor or client organisation;
(2) assigning the Capital Procurement Organisation increased authority and control;
(3) delegating more authority to project directors, especially over technical and administrative aspects;
(4) increasing the level of staffing and computer support given to project offices;
(6) making greater use of project management expertise outside Defence, especially that in the private sector;
(7) implementing improvements in defence project management information systems;
(8) improving the quality of defence contracting and contract administration;

The further centralisation of procurement functions, the increased delegation of authority to project directors and increased computer support to project offices will also improve the efficiency of defence project management by shortening decision chains and increasing productivity. The Committee believes there is considerable scope for further improving the efficiency of defence project management by:
(9) Modifying departmental procurement approval procedures to
speed decision-making, and
improve the quality of information available to decision-makers
to allow a fuller consideration of cost-saving options, and
to avoid costly changes after contracts have been let;
(10) increasing the level of project management skills within Defence by
giving greater emphasis to project management experience in selecting key project personnel, and
expanding project management training at all levels;
(11) increasing the retention of project management skills by developing career paths in project management and related areas;
(12) consolidating defence project management procedures and practices;
(13) providing stronger contractual incentives for suppliers to meet requirements on time and to cost; and
(14) reducing the potential for post-contract delays by simplifying procedures governing
design approvals,
contract changes, and
contract disputes.

The implementation of a number of these recommendations will require additional resources. Others will involve a reallocation of existing defence resources. The Committee believes that improved efficiency will provide the necessary offsetting savings. Improved accountability will be assisted by centralising functional responsibilities, establishing firm management performance baselines and improving management information systems. To provide the necessary external oversight the Committee has recommended annual reporting to parliament on the major defence equipment program.

The scope of the inquiry was very broad, touching upon all aspects of the defence procurement cycle from requirement definition to in-service support. Some aspects, particularly in-service support, could not be covered satisfactorily within the time and with the resources available. During the inquiry the Committee received some evidence of shortcomings in spares procurement and equipment support. These are important matters and the Committee intends to address them in a follow-up inquiry.

A large number of people contributed to this report. In the first place I would like to acknowledge the contributions of my colleagues on the sectional Committee and also members of the sectional Committee in the previous Parliament, Senator Georges, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). We thank the Department of Defence, the Department of Housing and Construction and other Commonwealth agencies for the co-operation and assistance extended during the inquiry. The Committee also thanks most sincerely the members of its secretariat, past and present, for their support and work. The Committee looks forward to the response to this report. We shall be monitoring the implementation of the recommendations with interest. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am delighted to support the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) in the presentation of the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, because it has been quite a marathon. My involvement as a newer member of the Parliament has been relatively brief, nonetheless it has been a most stimulating and interesting period. I have welcomed the opportunity to serve on the defence sectional committee. It has been a period of learning for me, and I am sure that once the report is studied it will be a period of learning for not only the Department of Defence but also the many other departments and arms of government.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the report contains 68 recommendations is evidence of its depth and, as the honourable member for Chisholm said, the Department of Defence has already in the course of the investigation adopted many changes and has made many improvements to its defence project management. There are a great many areas where improvement is still needed. I am sure all members of the Committee, and indeed the Parliament, look forward to seeing a number of these recommendations implemented.

I wish briefly to highlight one or two points of particular significance. One is in volume 1, page 35, paragraph 3.21 and deals with estimating project costs. The point made in the report is that incentives within the defence decision- making process to understate project costs to facilitate project approval apparently exist. I am sure this does not exist only in the Department of Defence; I am sure that it would be prevalent and common throughout government activity. One of the difficulties is that when government is being asked to consider a major project involving enormous amounts of money the cost estimate should be realistic. It should also be pointed out that the Committee has found and has been presented with some evidence which states that in some cases in obtaining equipment from overseas the price is quoted according to an inflation adjusted scale and then, before it is presented to the Parliament or the Government, the price is deflated back to current dollar values. This is why very often one gets incredible increases in the nominal cost, because of inflation. I think probably, that if the Department is to continue to deflate the inflation-adjusted prices quoted by overseas suppliers, particularly from the United States of America, both costs should be presented to the Government and to the Parliament.

Also of significant interest is the length of time often taken in obtaining approval for technical changes or changes in the cost of delivery. For instance, in the case of the minehunter catamarans, in the client office the number of days taken to get change approved in delivery was a minimum of 49 days, a maximum of 75 days and an average of 61 days. In the technical area for these catamarans the minimum time was 50 days to get a change, even a simple change, made; the average time taken was 152 days and the maximum was 315 days. An inordinate amount of time is being taken to get sometimes quite simple changes made. For HMAS Success the maximum number of days required for change was 235 days and the average was 75 days. In the Hiport-Medport communications system changes for costing took 322 days maximum, delivery was 110 days maximum with an average of 51 days; technical change approvals took a maximum of 134 days and a minimum of 2 days, but still with an average of 37 days. For the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar project, in the purchasing office the amount of time taken to get a change approved in the cost area was a minimum of 5 days, an average of 115 days and a maximum of 250 days. Perhaps astoundingly, in the technical area, to have a change approved took a minimum of 10 days, an average of 105 days, and an almost unbelievable 595 days to get one change approved. That is incredible.

I would like to comment on an item from the Auditor-General's report on the review of defence project management of September 1983. Even at that time relevant information was coming forward which indicated that the amount of time taken to supply major projects was increasing. The Humpty Doo transmitting station was expected to be fully in service when the project was approved in December 1978. In fact, it was in service in November 1983-five years late. The completion date for testing of the prototypes of the minehunter catamarans was August 1982. The actual in-service date was April 1987, again a lapse of five years. The equipment deliveries for the Hiport-Medport mobile radio terminals were supposed to commence in 1980. The expected in-service date at the time of the Auditor-General's report was April 1984, a four-year delay. They are still not expected before September 1986. Those examples highlight some of the problems we are experiencing in the supply of major defence projects.

I also refer to page 10 of volume 1 of the report, which shows a chart of extended completion dates for defence projects. I shall cite examples from each service: From the Navy, the minehunter catamarans; from the Army, the Hamel light gun; and from the Air Force the Jindalee project. The minehunter catamarans were started in September 1974. The suggested time of completion is 1987, but the chart shows that phase 3 has only a question mark against its estimated completion date.

Phases 1, 2 and 3 of the Hamel light gun project were started in December 1974. The guns are expected to be delivered and available by 1988, but the ammunition will take until 1991 to be delivered. Stages A and B of the Jindalee project were started in October 1969. They are now expected to be completed in the late 1980s. Again, my examples merely illustrate that we have a problem in this area. I hope and trust that Defence and Government will act to improve performance in this area and take notice of the Committee's recommendations.

It is also of some interest to look at the chart on page 14 of volume 1, which shows schedule slippages. The figures I will give are the schedule overrun percentages for defence projects. The tactical air defence system is running 71 per cent late; stage A of Jindalee, 35 per cent, and stage B, 22 per cent; the C-130H simulator, 31 per cent; the F111A attrition aircraft, 82 per cent; Hiport-Medport, 80 per cent; HMAS Success, 70 per cent, and the minehunter catamarans, 57 per cent.

The chart on page 15 shows the percentage cost overruns for defence projects. For the tactical air defence system, the nominal cost variation was 45.7 per cent, but in real cost terms the variation was minus 5 per cent. For Jindalee, the nominal cost variation was 46.2 per cent and the real cost variation, 25.3 per cent. For the C-130H simulator, the normal cost variation was 132 per cent, but 59.6 per cent in real cost. For the HMAS Success, the nominal cost variation was 185.4 per cent and the real cost, 98.6 per cent. I hope that those examples illustrate the need for a much more intensive application of effective and professional project management of defence projects.

In conclusion, I pay tribute to and compliment the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) on her extremely effective chairmanship of the sectional committee. As I said at the beginning of my speech, it has been a marathon task. The honourable member has produced an excellent result. I, together with other members of the Committee, I am sure, present my compliments and congratulations to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When I became involved part way through the Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry, as did the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), I was under the impression that project management probably took a different form from that which I subsequently found it did take. Having spent a lifetime involved in the building industry I imagined that it was something like the management technique which has been applied so successfully throughout Australia. That proved not to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that perhaps the Department of Defence and members of the armed services might learn a little from practitioners in the building industry about project management and the allocation of duties and responsibilities. While the building industry's experience is not necessarily adaptable to all projects undertaken under this project management technique which has been applied so successfully throughout Australia. That proved not to be the case.

I make the point that perhaps the Department of Defence and members of the armed services might learn a little from practitioners in the building industry about project management and the allocation of duties and responsibilities. While the building industry's experience is not necessarily adaptable to all projects undertaken under this project management technique adopted by the Defence Department, it certainly is adaptable to some projects. Projects of a construction nature, as distinct from those which are essentially of a procurement-type deal involving great technical know-how, could be profitably studied by the Defence Department and the armed services as they seek to improve their abilities in this area.

Chapter 2 of the Committee's report details some of the criteria which give rise to its recommendations. Although the findings were made as a result of evidence led and given to the inquiry, they contain a clue to the reasons for the recommendations which are enumerated. I remind the House that there are 68 recommendations in all. Eleven of the 16 projects examined may fail to be completed on time, to budget or to meet technical requirements.

I am sure honourable members will agree that that is a pretty impressive percentage. In seven of those projects the major equipment items were likely or are likely to enter service significantly behind approved target dates. Further, eight projects incurred significant overall real cost increases. It is those sorts of circumstances that have led to the recommendations which are clearly set out in the report.

There are shortcomings, and that is obvious. Generally, if not in specific cases, those shortcomings have been identified and are admitted by Defence personnel, both uniformed and not uniformed. The truth is that a new technique has been developed and one might expect progress to be made with it as experience is gained. However, there was nothing to suggest that without the initiative taken by the Public Accounts Committee in this area the evolution which one might expect to happen would have happened. There is some reason to believe that progress may not have been made had this matter not been brought to the attention of the Committee by the Auditor-General.

Evidence was adduced which led us to the conclusion that deficient project definition was probably the reason for lack of management resources, particularly management personnel. It might be that they were complementary and that both the former and the latter are said to harbour some of the causes of the problems we found. But it was this combination of deficiencies in project definition and the subsequent lack of personnel and other management resources which caused the authorities involved to set priorities in a way which certainly involved shortcomings in the way the projects were handled. I suppose it does not need to be said, but this differed from project to project. As a result of these sorts of problems, attention to management resources, reporting systems and contract administration were seriously lacking in many cases.

The honourable member for Cowper was, I think, unduly humble when he said he was involved in a learning capacity. I assure the House that he made a very significant contribution, as did all other members of the sectional Committee. Like him, I extend my congratulations to our Chairman, the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer). She was an effective chairman. She is a very diligent woman. With the co-operation and assistance of the staff of the Committee, she did a very good job on what is a major report of some substance and size.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was indicated when this subject was under debate on Tuesday evening, the community employment program is a part of the long term co-ordinated plan established by the Government to tackle the problem of unemployment in Australia. It has specific reference to the problems of the long term unemployed. The Government, of course, recognises that we cannot achieve all of our goals simply with one program. For that reason it has initiated the Priority One program, part of which is the youth traineeship scheme. It is to be hoped that through that program in the long term many of the problems that are associated with long term unemployment today will be obviated. The Government also recognises that it is particularly necessary to provide an economic climate in which jobs will be created and, at the same time, to assist those without job skills, whether they be young or of mature age, to gain the necessary job experience. It is in that particular area the CEP has its origin.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that under the previous Government, in its latter days, there was a wage pause program. The wage pause program is one of a number of ad hoc programs which were established by that Government in a response to particular pressures at a particular time. In recalling the contribution of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) the other evening, I might say that he made an unfortunately disparaging reference to a program in his own electorate in the small town of Boolarra. I think it was a rather unfortunate choice that he made, because that program, which he claimed was one of the CEP programs and which he also claimed was unsuccessful, was part of the wage pause program. It was called the travelling clowns project. The interesting thing about that project is that it was appraised by and raised by the honourable member for Gippsland. It is a pity that he criticised that as it probably would have been far more useful had he gone out and contacted the group when it was in operation and provided some assistance rather than criticism.

Job creation was not the top priority of the Fraser Government. I think people recognise this. Its economic policies demonstrably failed to achieve any of its stated objectives. Inflation rose, growth in the economy was negative and unemployment rose to levels that we had not seen since the appalling Depression of the 1930s. There are those who claim that there was a meanness of spirit about that Government that demonstrated that it had little compassion for the poor and those who were not the manipulators of the system. The Fraser Government pursued a policy that appeared to be deliberately geared to dividing the society by setting one competing group against another. At a time when national unity was a crying need, the Government was set on a path of social disruption and the very groups that should have been working together to forge a strong and growing economy in which all Australians could share were being set against each other as the Fraser Government attacked the workers and their representatives in the trade union movement. It pursued an industrial relations policy that blamed the union movement for all the economic and social ills that troubled the nation.

Most of the members of the then Government, and I would imagine those who are the remnants of it in the current Opposition, knew then and know today that the causes of industrial strife are numerous and various. The nature of the conservatives, of course, has always been to break the back of the union movement and to deregulate the labour market. In this way it would be able set up a quiescent and dependent labour pool. I am sorry that I have to say this, but it does appear that their hearts and minds belong to the sweat shops of the nineteenth century. As we know, their policies resulted in an enormous increase in industrial unrest and bitter divisions in Australia. No real thought was given to job creation projects such as the community employment program as a long term program. All we had-I include the wage pause program in this-was a series of disjointed programs of a cosmetic kind that arose in an ad hoc way in response to pressures net along the way. It is sad to relate that there is ample evidence to show that the Opposition, as it now is, has not profited by its mistakes. Opposition members are still preaching the same policies-policies that this country just cannot afford to have foisted upon it. As we know, the result of their seven-year rule was an unemployment rate of 10.4 per cent of the entire work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have learnt nothing.

—That is quite true. As the Minister states, they have learnt nothing. Bad as that was, the impact was felt more savagely in areas such as the area of Ballarat which I represent. The decline in the economy and the unplanned restructuring of industry left my own city with an unemployment rate in excess of 15 per cent. The Fraser Government promised full employment, but it left the country divided, the economy stagnant and unemployment at tragic proportions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government promised to tackle all of these issues and to its credit it has achieved remarkable successes since its term of office began in March 1983. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised that we would see 500,000 jobs created within three years. Of course, that was scoffed at by the pundits on the other side. The country was full of sceptics and no wonder, because they had good cause to suspect promises of governments, given the record of the Fraser Government. Within the three-year period on my calculations, in excess of 608,000 jobs were created. That is a remarkable achievement. It is 108,000 more than was anticipated. Oddly, what we now face is a shortage of workers in certain skill areas because of the activity in those areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —A wonderful problem to have.

—Yes, but one which, of course, needs to be addressed. An equally significant achievement has been the creation of employment opportunities under the community employment program. In most areas of Australia there are groups which find it extremely difficult to gain employment. These are the long term unemployed and certain disadvantaged groups such as the disabled, Aborigines, women, and people whose facility with the English language is very limited. It needs to be said that the community employment program is aimed at providing opportunities for employment in the local market for those who are unemployed, by targeting their specific needs.

SPEECH.PARA: The significance of these projects for an area might be gauged by looking at the following figures that apply to Ballarat and Ararat. For the Ballarat electorate generally, the number of jobs created by community groups, the jobs on local roads program, local government and water projects total 874. The contribution the CEP has made directly to these is $10,143,338. In total there have been 164 projects in that area. I am pleased to say that 50 of these projects have been sponsored by community groups such as the Tramways Preservation Society, the wonderful and justifiably acclaimed tourist village Sovereign Hill in Ballarat, which the Minister knows very well, the Central Highlands Library, the Aboriginal Co-operative and, of course, the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers, that remarkable organisation which is growing very rapidly across Australia, which is based in Ballarat and was initiated by Mr Tim Cox.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it well.

—Yes, and that group has deservedly received in excess of $1m for its projects. In Ararat a wonderful project called the Green Lake Reserve has been developed. These projects have had a number of benefits apart from those which obviously flow to the local community. The Ararat Harness Racing Club, a very fine organisation, has also taken advantage of the program. The work provided for the long term unemployed gives them the opportunity to develop skills, to overcome the psychologically debilitating effect of long term unemployment, and to develop self-esteem.

SPEECH.PARA: These and many other projects by councils, government bodies, State governments and water boards have provided a remarkable number of opportunities for people to become involved. The program has been particularly successful in terms of people gaining jobs. About 59 per cent had gained some employment and 41 per cent were still in employment six months after leaving the program. Of these, 82 per cent were in full time jobs. Let us bear in mind that these people would have been virtually wiped off the scene because they did not have the skills to compete in the work force before the program. A certain parsimonious attitude has been expressed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) in this matter. I do not think he understands the nature of long term unemployment and the effect it can have on people.

Before closing, I thank those people in my electorate who have come to the assistance of the unemployed by sponsoring projects. People such as John O'Loughlin and Daryl Vorbach, field officers, have done a remarkable job extremely conscientiously. People such as Chaz Dichiera, Stephen Bracks and David Miller have also contributed very much to the actual administration of these programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are their telephone numbers?

—I do not need a telephone. These people really and truly deserve gratitude because they are so willing to go anywhere and encourage the groups that have contributed to take an active part in the scheme. I congratulate the Government on this program. I am particularly pleased to support the Bill because, once again, we have a long term problem and should not just turn away from the people who, in many respects, are the most severely hit victims of this system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating the Community Employment Amendment Bill, which provides for the continuation of the community employment program first introduced in 1983. The difficulties assessed in this matter are enormous. Firstly, the continuation of the program is now, without doubt, a commitment that the Government must pursue. It must pursue it because it is one of the linchpins of the claims that employment has been increased and that there is a better overall level of employment. Of course, that raises very wide issues, many of which certainly were not canvassed by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) when he spoke a few moments ago. The approach that he took was merely to talk of the veneer that is superficial in this total matter and not to recognise the salient features of the problems of unemployment and the needs that are so real if we are to develop any degree of permanency in a fuller level of employment in this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say at the outset that the present CEP scheme is certainly better than the infamous regional employment development scheme begun in 1973-74 by the previous Labor Administration-an administration which found that it was unable to grapple with this problem. In fact it terminated that infamous scheme-that is an inadequate description of it but I will leave it at that-before it left office. Of course, then the Fraser Government gave consideration to what might be done in this area and a responsible approach was taken.

To the credit of the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), when an employment scheme was reintroduced by the present Government, at least he was wise enough to take steps to avoid the disabilities that had existed in the previous scheme. But that was achieved largely because of the dedication and the responsible approach by officers of his Department, not only those centrally based in each State but certainly those in the regional areas. That has made a very substantial difference to the success of the present employment scheme.

Unfortunately it has been necessary for many of my colleagues on this side of the House to catalogue some of the objectionable features of the scheme-objectionable because they present a very unfortunate aspect of just a segment of the scheme. I refer to the funding of very sectional propositions which promote the ideology and the philosophies of the present Government and its supporters in a range of areas. This scheme should never have permitted that sort of thing. I know that subsequent speakers from this side of the House will further catalogue the unfortunate occurrences which are on record and which in some areas continue.

I believe that the Minister would strengthen his own stance in the whole matter and enhance the standing of his Government if he were to take steps to correct these anomalies and to rectify what can be regarded only as a very wilful approach on the basis of sectional interests being given funds to promote particular ideologies. I leave it at that because of other important considerations that I want to cover in this brief debate.

The real issue in many electorates and certainly in mine and those of my colleagues in northern New South Wales is the problem of youth unemployment. Despite what speakers from the Government side have said thus far in the debate, the fact remains that youth unemployment is increasing. The figures give cause for great concern for the future of employment in that area as it relates to the community employment scheme. It is indeed significant that the proportion of youth unemployment in the total number of unemployed people in 1980 was 16.6 per cent. The figure has now grown to 18.2 per cent. If one looks at the situation in the rapidly growing areas of northern New South Wales, southern Queensland and some other regions of Australia, one sees that that level is still merely an average of the nationwide picture. In the regions to which I referred the level of youth unemployment is even higher. It is higher because of the rapid growth of population in those areas, because people have moved into those areas, with the hope and aspiration of obtaining work, and have had difficulties in finding a commensurate growth in employment. Why is that? It is because many of the economic policies of this Government fail to grapple with what is the basis of economic necessity-to encourage employers in the field of development in order to provide more permanent employment.

What we have found in this debate is a lack of recognition of what is necessary to build up the structure of growth in this country in the real world of permanency of employment, in the real world of productivity in fields that will provide permanent employment. Of course, the word `employer' seems always to conjure up in the minds of those who speak in this House on behalf of the Government some degree of what can be described only as criticism of those who are prepared to do something of real worth. In other words, what the Government is doing all the time is engendering a dislike for that section of the community that in the long run will provide employment in this country.

If we look at the taxation proposals and the whole gamut of economic management and what is yet to come from the tax package, we see that all of that discourages employers. Of course, employers are fundamental if we are to grapple with the real issues of employment. The Priority One campaign, so much publicised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by the present Government, has been an abject failure. In New South Wales it is virtually restricted to the Western suburbs of Sydney. It has failed to make any appearance of a worthwhile nature in the areas of high youth unemployment, certainly on the north coast of New South Wales. Officers of the Department have visited that area and attempted to interest employers, local councils and others in the possibility of participating in the scheme. But what do we find? There has been no incentive. The failure of the Government to be able to negotiate a junior wage or a youth employment training wage as distinct from the present awards has spelt doom to the whole proposition. The Minister in his second reading speech has certainly not given any hope in that respect. It is all very well for us to see millions of dollars expended on the community employment program, but those things are vital necessities for the encouragement of training and the provision of permanency in order to attain an ultimate real lift in employment.

The honourable member for Ballarat said that there was something for the Government to be proud of in the fact that there was a shortage of people to undertake work in skilled fields. All I can say is that he certainly has failed miserably in his Caucus. He certainly has failed miserably in influencing his Government to grapple with that issue. What have we experienced during the past year? We have had a cut in funds for technical and further education which further reduces the opportunities for the development of skills in this country. What have we seen? We have seen the failure of the Government to be able to negotiate with the trade union movement to make way for a positive training approach under any scheme, whether it be Priority One or any of the other propositions that have been advanced. Yet the honourable member for Ballarat was praised by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), who is in the House at the moment, for saying: `There is a shortage of skilled workers to take positions in many areas in this country'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unions have tied the Government's hands.

—As the honourable member for Lyne so correctly says, the unions have tied the Government's hands. They have tied them totally in this matter. If we were hearing in this debate of some approach to resolving this issue, the Government would of course gain some credit, but the embattled Government is facing a dilemma concerning the total spectrum of the economy. It is embattled over employment, but it is seizing on merely the superficial to say `Ah, look, employment is up and unemployment levels are down' without looking at what it really means and what it spells out for the immediate and long term future. Figures released the other day succinctly answer the whole question. These figures, from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, tell us that the average period of unemployment of people in this country has stretched from 30.8 weeks in 1980 to 51.9 weeks in July 1985. Average unemployment periods from 1981 through to 1985 have gradually climbed-to a level which is very unsatisfactory. We find in all the categories-those who are in the higher age bracket of the unemployed, those who live alone and of course those who are school leavers-that this enormous stretch in the period of unemployment is occurring. That is what those who are unfortunate enough to be unable to get into the work force are faced with. Is that something for the Government to be proud of? Is that something that it can make this veneered and superficial response to? Certainly it is not, and it is a matter that I hope it will address in the not too distant future. If it means some amendments to the CEP, let those amendments be introduced effectively and not blocked by adherence to a harsh attitude by the trade union movement.
—How many jobs did you create?

—The honourable member ought to come and have a look in my electorate at what is being done about jobs in some organisations in which I have some interest. Of course he would not want to know about that.
—Have a look at the record.

—Have a look at the record indeed! Our Government did provide permanent employment, to a far more satisfactory level than his Government has done and certainly is doing at present. I turn now to some of the impediments that exist in the CEP scheme. As I said, there are dedicated people in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, certainly in the regional areas. I want to pay tribute to those with whom I have worked. Mr Mark Raper, who is in charge of northern New South Wales, is an excellent officer who tries to be practical in all matters and to have regard to employment needs, to the spread of employment prospects that can be offered through the community program, and likewise tries to recognise the reality of projects advanced. It is unfortunate that we find intrusion from another level, from the political level. I refer to the New South Wales Government. What does it do? It has a part in the determination of programs, through the committee set up for that purpose, so there is a tussle with the New South Wales Government trying to use CEP funds purely to its political advantage.
—Shame!

—It is shameful, certainly, as the honourable member for Riverina says, for the Premier of New South Wales to go across the country, flag wave politically, perhaps when a project carried out under the CEP is being opened, and say that the New South Wales Government has done this, that it battled to get the funds for it, totally ignoring the fact that there is a Commonwealth employment content in it.
—It is not getting the credit for it.

—The honourable member's Government is not getting the credit for it; the officers employed by the department administered by his Government is not getting the credit for it. The Premier has done this to the extent that I have quite properly made it known to the people concerned. In particular I have had to give credit to those employed in the CEP project and to give some recognition to their tenacity in doing the job as well as they have. Credit must go also to the supervisors in charge of those projects and to all who have played a part in them. On occasions the New South Wales Premier has failed to give such credit, as have his Ministers, and if that is not a shabby political trick I do not know what is. There are other unfortunate aspects of CEP administration. There have been attempts to by-pass or disregard the work being done by officers of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations who have had the dedication to try to make this scheme effective and to make it useful in the interests of those who are given jobs under it.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by referring again to the fundamentals of employment. Unless we can mould into the community employment program a degree of understanding of what may lead to permanency in employment, the program will continue to have some disabilities. That can only be done if there is a more direct relationship in regional areas with the potential for employment, and that potential for employment can be developed only if there is recognition of what really generates local employment. So the excellent work being done by Commonwealth Employment Service officers, by those who have the task of encouraging employment, encouraging people to seek specific employment and encouraging people to undertake certain training so that their employment prospects will be greater, need to have a direct relationship with those involved in community employment programs. It is little use finding that funds, so precious at this time, flow through to State government departments merely to enable a slight extension in the dream run being experienced by those who just want to go out and carry out surveys into this or do a study into that and produce more paper. At the end of 18 weeks or 26 weeks-a favourite time scale for CEP projects-the dedicated person who has produced a report on the needs for this or the needs for that in welfare areas or a range of other areas, whose motivation has been lifted, wonders what in the world governments are all about, because it is the end of the road. The report is completed and stacked on an already huge stack of reports and there is no proposition for a continuation of that person's participation in the program. Unless these things are moulded into an administrative approach at Federal, State and local government levels, we will continue to see great disappointment on the part of those who are encouraged in the first place. I hope this is one aspect that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Government will look at seriously when reviewing the work of the community employment program as it progresses into the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The community employment program was officially launched by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 1 August 1983 in an effort to create additional employment opportunities for the unemployed through the funding of labour intensive projects of social and economic benefit to the community. It was part of the Government's commitment to the Australian people to ensure that the trend to ever-increasing unemployment would be reversed. The Fraser-Howard team proved for the conservative parties that creating long lines of unemployed was a relatively easy task-one in which they were highly skilled. They managed to achieve an unemployment rate of 10.3 per cent, or 720,100 unemployed men, women and young people in Australia. They are the fundamentals that the people of Australia should never forget, and they are the fundamentals to which the previous speaker, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Ian Robinson), referred. By contrast, this Government has striven mightily to reduce the rate to 7.8 per cent, or 583,500 unemployed. I believe that we cannot be satisfied with that. Even though we have created 608,000 jobs in our term of office we must continue to fight to reduce this rate of unemployment. Here we have the contrast of a government which is job oriented, seeking to bring down the number of unemployed and an opposition, which is unemployment oriented, with a proven record of creating record unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say something about some of the Opposition's speakers who have been quibbling about the program. This program has involved 16,772 projects, yet members of the Opposition want to quibble about a small minority of them. I think, on any fair assessment, this has been a tremendously successful project. I must say that I was bitterly disappointed at the comments of Mrs Judith Sloane from the National Institute of Labour Studies in Adelaide. She suggested, in the Institute's quarterly publication the Australian Bulletin of Labour, that 8 per cent is the current rate of full employment. This approach would condemn the western suburbs of Sydney, an area that I am very proud to represent, to being the permanent reservoir of Sydney's unemployed. I resile from those who can discuss unemployment in cold, statistical terms without considering the horrendous social and personal cost and the deprivations that individuals, families and communities must endure.

CEP was to be specifically directed at those who were especially disadvantaged in the labour market, such as the long term unemployed, the disabled, Aborigines and migrants with English speaking problems. Of course, I am extremely disappointed that the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia and the Party's spokesman on employment and industrial relations, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) had this to say in his speech:

We will also be suggesting that, at least on some occasions, the scheme is being used, not for the purposes of providing employment opportunities for the long term unemployed, but simply to undertake capital works programs and other sorts of works which could not properly be described as employment programs for the simple reason that they do not employ anyone who would not otherwise be employed.

I think that is a ridiculous statement. We have only to look at the previous Government's record in housing to see what devastation that caused amongst tradesmen and labourers. Many of these unemployed people have been picked up in the building programs. I think it is fair to say that the committees that were evaluating CEP projects have recently been cutting out many of the very worthwhile projects involving construction for the very reason that the industry has picked up. I think it is to the credit of the program that it is flexible and it seeks to pick up those long term unemployed.

CEP also aimed to give equal access to jobs for men and women. The program provides not only jobs for these people but also valuable work experience or training which will assist participants to gain future employment. The CEP has been extremely successful to date and I am pleased to be able to stand in this chamber and support the Bill. Since the program's inception in June 1983 a total of 78,595 jobs have been approved and 75,519 unemployed people have been placed on CEP projects. That is a magnificent achievement. The community has also benefited under CEP. The program has provided facilities and services that could not otherwise have been expected or provided, such as public meeting halls, improved health care facilities, environmental improvements, welfare services and improvements to local roads.

This legislation is an extension of what was a sunset clause in the original legislation. Of course, the CEP has three components. There is a State government component, a council component and a community component. If, in a tight budgetary situation, we are looking to review what has been the most effective parts of the scheme, I believe that the council and community components of CEP have been an outstanding success.

The period since CEP has been introduced has been marked by strong economic and employment growth. Between August 1983 and June 1985, employment grew by over 390,000 and the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell from 10.3 per cent, under the previous Government, to 8.7 per cent of the total labour force. However, whilst the increase in employment has resulted in some improvements in the position of the long term unemployed, those employed for nine months or longer still account for 36.1 per cent of the total unemployed. The extension of the CEP to 1989 is thus necessary and an important part of the Government's program. The longer a person is out of work the greater the loss of skills and confidence and the more difficult it is for that person to secure employment. Even looking at the situation optimistically the total number of long term unemployed is not expected to fall significantly over the next two or three years. Thus CEP should remain an important and integral part of the Government's strategy to assist the unemployed.

CEP has had large scale successes but, as in some schemes, improvements can always be made. I would like to point out that Blacktown and other western Sydney councils are receiving proportionately less than the Australian Capital Territory, although they have a markedly higher unemployment rate and greater needs. One of the aims of CEP was that priority be given, when approving projects, to those areas experiencing especially severe unemployment problems. The figures speak for themselves. Canberra, with a population of 250,000, has received $15.9m overall in CEP funding which has placed some 1,548 people in employment. Blacktown, with a population of 200,000, has received $7.5m which has provided a total of 738 jobs. Penrith, with a population of 130,000, received $5.5m which has provided a total of 525 jobs. Even though the Federal Government reduced the Australian Capital Territory unemployment rate to 3.8 per cent, this is cold comfort for the unemployed in the west and other needy areas where the unemployment rate can be as high as 20 per cent.

I suggest that, as the economy continues to grow, more money should and could be directed to areas most in need. I understand that part of the problem may very well be a lack of projects coming forward from community groups. I am very pleased to report that the CEP area project officers, Mrs Cathy O'Farrell and Judith Melocco with whom I have had many dealings and I respect highly, will be looking to see what we can do on a co-operative basis to ensure that that does not continue to be a problem. I would like also to point out that, although the CEP guidelines suggest that the duration of jobs can last for three to twelve months, the average duration of CEP jobs is only six months. Clearly, a significant number of projects do not last as long. I am a firm believer that, if we want to change some aspects of the guidelines, one area that we may very well want to give consideration to is extending the period of employment.

I know that research has been undertaken in post-job situation for CEP workers, both employed and unemployed, and the results are quite encouraging. However, I suggest to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) that we need to do a little more work on that to shore up the conclusions reached as a result of the research. The work experience from CEP projects has currently placed 41 per cent to 46 per cent of former participants in employment around six months after leaving CEP. But what of the other 59 per cent to 54 per cent? The answer may very well be that the duration of the average CEP projects is too short. It would serve not only to boost the self-confidence and self-esteem of job seekers but also to increase the extent of their acquisition of skills. They would have the opportunity to leave the scheme early, should they be able to find a permanent job.

A number of worthwhile projects which are under way in my electorate have been receiving CEP funding. Whilst I do not run through all those projects I do want to mention a couple. Narragingy Reserve at Doonside has received four CEP grants. The latest grand total is $364,141 and the local council matched the Federal Government grant with $98,000 of its own funds. The money will be used to employ 36 people for a period of 26 weeks to continue the construction of garden and lake areas as well as to complete individual family and general purpose picnic areas which will incorporate tree planting, turfing, water supply and an extended picnic area. To date a total of over $1.5m has been provided by the Federal Government for this 90 hectares of passive recreation area which, when completed, will be the envy of Sydney and will be a facility that the west will enjoy and is currently enjoying. It is the largest passive recreation project within my electorate and within the Blacktown City Council area. Although the project is far from finished, it is already proving to be very popular.

Mamre Farm is another project that is receiving CEP funding. This matter has been referred to by my colleague the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), who in large part deserves the credit for the arrangements he made with the Commonwealth and State departments in relation to this project. The project is exciting and is concerned with restoring the original Mamre homestead of Samuel Marsden. Honourable members may recall that he had an original land grant of 1,030 acres on the plains and he called his home Mamre. The home was sorely neglected and completely run down. It is situated on 300 hectares of land which has just been handed over. I take this opportunity to pay a few compliments in this connection. In the western suburbs vernacular, it took a very stroppy sister of the Sisters of Mercy, Sister Mary-Louise, to get this project under way. I would like to quote the words of Sister Ellen, the superior:

It is within this framework that the project will seek to provide an environment of beauty that can stimulate, calm, uplift and motivate; to nurture and enhance the ecology of the site in all its aspects; to provide efficient working models of land and energy practices that will act as a learning environment which enables and encourages others to adopt similar techniques; to adopt, in general, a concept of stewardship to care for the land, leaving it self-sustaining and better endowed than when we found it. ``Mamre'' hopes to provide a climate where individuals have a sense of identity, self-worth, dignity and belonging, regardless of their social or economic circumstances. ``Mamre'' hopes to foster the concept of self-help, local destinies which liberates and empowers local community. ``Mamre'' hopes to enlist the energies of young people in useful activities and to provide workshops and other activities that restore their self-image and confidence.

A sum of $139,268 was allocated in June 1985 and was to employ nine people, two clerks, a carpenter and other staff to assist in the development of the farm. The intention is to run an historical homestead at Mamre Farm as a tourist and recreational centre with a teashop and restaurant facilities and to run the farm as a working historical model. This will provide a focus and a base to run a number of other activities for youth and provide a range of services to other groups in need. An application for further CEP funding is presently up for consideration and I am sure will be granted. There is more I would like to say, but I have run out of time. I am pleased to support and commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate provides a welcome, if somewhat sobering, opportunity to review and reassess the community employment program-to ascertain, in light of the available facts and figures, whether or not the Government can legitimately claim that CEP is an effective and efficient measure to combat the continuing and worsening unemployment problem. Unfortunately for the Hawke Labor Government, the Australian taxpayers and, most importantly, the unemployed people within our community the answer is a resounding no. Under this Government we have been inundated with a plethora of so-called employment creation schemes-most of which are ill-researched and inadequately planned, and depend for success not on facts but on hopes. Many of these projects have desirable ends but doubtful means. The community employment program comes into this category.

SPEECH.PARA: Though no one would question the value and validity of any scheme which genuinely reduced long term unemployment, piecemeal, stop-gap, `seemed a good idea at the time' measures designed to create demonstrably false reductions in unemployment figures should be revealed for what they are-a waste of taxpayers' funds on yet another Government propaganda exercise. In its present form, the community employment program offers few real and lasting benefits for those most in need and deserving of assistance. Yes, we have more bicycle paths, more river banks being weeded and beautified; we have construction of some important and useful community facilities; we have the backlog of some government departmental filing being busily sorted and stacked; we have funding available for a wide range of projects and activities which could rightfully be classified as being of general community benefit. What we do not have is any real or immediate improvement in creating secure, permanent job opportunities for the long term unemployed. What was originally established as a means of creating employment and providing much needed on the job training facilities has, in fact, become a source of funding for a wide range of projects which, more by good luck than good management, create some temporary employment as an afterthought or side effect.

Let us be honest with ourselves and the community and remove the word `employment' from CEP. Let us recognise it for what it is-a source of supplementary funding for State and local government and community projects which would not otherwise qualify for Federal government assistance. If this Government really wants to reduce long term unemployment by creating permanent job opportunities for those who want to work, it should turn its attention to the free enterprise, small business sector. Small business has in the past and, given the right terms and conditions, can again in the future generate thousands and thousands of jobs for both skilled and unskilled workers. All they need is a little more encouragement and incentive, and a lot less government interference, red tape, and unnecessary regulation.

Australian small businesses have the desire, initiative, potential, knowledge, experience, resources and capacity to fill the unemployment gap. Give them the opportunity to do so, give them a fair go, and proper jobs will be created and funded from the proper source-the private sector. Over three years this Government has spent an average of over $8,000 per CEP placement. Imagine the effect if this amount of money had been invested instead in small business-almost $1 billion made available to the real job creators in our community. A lot more jobs would have resulted-a lot more jobs that lasted a lot longer than a maximum of six months each.

There are several obvious major shortcomings in the CEP. These include the transitory nature of the employment offered, the fact that many people are trained to develop skills which will be of little practical benefit to them in their quest for permanent employment, and the lack of any real accountability to taxpayers in regard to the proper and responsible administration of the scheme, particularly once the funds have been handed over.

The debacle recently referred to in another place by my colleague Senator Jim Short serves to highlight this problem of public accountability. In his adjournment speech on 13 February 1986, Senator Short revealed the disgraceful situation which has developed in relation to the CEP. Footscray swimming pool project. An estimated $2.9m of taxpayers' money has literally disappeared down the plughole. This enormous amount of public money has been frittered away in an extravaganza of incompetence and mismanagement. As an old-well, middle aged-Footscray boy, I have a certain vested interest in and continuing loyalty to this area, and I join with Senator Short in his call for an urgent and full investigation into the Footscray pool fiasco.

Fortunately, within my electorate of Casey, we have not encountered problems of the magnitude revealed by Senator Short's investigations, in Casey, the community employment program is administered as efficiently as possible within the current Government guidelines, which themselves are full of inappropriate constraints and obvious shortcomings, by the officers of the CEP eastern zone. Their task is not made any easier by the fact that the short term, now you see it, now you don't, approach of CEP allows-even encourages-the commencement of projects which have little hope of being completed.

It is extremely depressing for sponsors to see only partial realisation of their objectives. It is even more depressing for participants to see their hard work and dedication rewarded, after a brief six months, by a return to the ranks of those willing to work but unable to find appropriate employment. One of the basic concepts of the employer-employee relationship is, or should be, that in most circumstances loyal and dedicated service and the adequate performance of duties and responsibilities by an employee will result in continuing employment, hopefully even promotion. Under the present CEP guidelines there are no guarantees, except for the fact that after six months at most one's job will be terminated.

I have been contacted by many people, particularly young people, whose initial elation at securing work via the CEP turned to dismay when the realisation dawned-usually a month or two before the termination of a project-that they had no prospect of continuing in their present position, even if the project had not been completed and little chance of finding alternative work. Often they find that their training has been of no advantage and has no direct application in the real employment world. Time and again they say: `I have done my best. I have done a good job. The boss is pleased with me. Why am I going to lose this work opportunity? Am I not to be given another chance?' Should I not be entitled to some possibility of continuing employment? Of course they should, but under CEP the opportunity is denied them, unless they re-qualify again as long term unemployed. They are innocent victims of a system which says: `Be unemployed for nine months and we will give you six months work: and after being jobless for another nine months, we will give you another six months'. It is like a mouse on a treadmill, and just as cruel, unjust and unnecessary.

These people have experienced the restoration of their self sufficiency, dignity, confidence and self-esteem, which only employment provides. Unfortunately, like their CEP jobs, such feelings may be only temporary. Some, of course, are lucky. They find that CEP provides a welcome stepping stone on the road towards permanent employment. It is a shame that we are not able to establish just how many come within this category. For no apparent reason, other than to disguise the inadequacies of CEP, statistics are not available to enable dispassionate and factual assessment and monitoring of the success or otherwise of the scheme.

On 20th November 1985, I placed a question on notice to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) which, in part, sought information regarding the number of people, in categories of age and sex, served by Commonwealth Employment Service offices in my electorate, who were registered as unemployed on 1 January 1984, and who subsequently had been employed for a period exceeding three months but who were again registered as unemployed. I also requested details as to the average period of their employment and how many of the positions were directly created through CEP-funded projects. I further asked how many people registered as unemployed since 1 January 1985 and subsequently placed by the CES into CEP-funded employment, had not re-registered as unemployed. The Minister replied that it was not possible to provide the statistics sought, as they are not recorded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful!

—It is disgraceful indeed! If these basic facts and figures are not recorded, how can the Government accurately assess the results of the CEP scheme? How can it legitimately claim that it has had any real or lasting impact on unemployment? It cannot. It does not know. The figures are, perhaps very conveniently, not recorded.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members who loudly proclaim the creation of thousands of new jobs through CEP are giving us only half the picture. They are following the advice of the well-known song: `Accentuate the positive, eliminate the negative'. They are deliberately eliminating any reference to the fact that the vast majority of these thousands of so-called new jobs no longer exist. This can be described as the sand castle syndrome, one can build 100 sand castles a day and then watch as the incoming tide sweeps them away. Next day one returns to the same spot on the same beach and uses the same sand to build another 100 castles. By the end of the week, one has created 700 new sand castles. The fact that not one remains extant is inconsequential to one's claim. The fact that one has used the same sand time and again is immaterial. But, as one tells one's listeners of these exploits, one purposely and misleadingly create in their minds a vision splendid of 700 sand castles, when, in reality, at best there may be 100 and, by the time the tide comes in, there will be none. Recreating sand castles is similar to recreating jobs. Both can be created anew ad infinitum. But they are not really new, they are just recycled.

Let me take this opportunity to set the record straight in regard to my attitude towards CEP. On several occasions it has been quite wrongly claimed or implied by my political opponents that I am opposed to CEP per se. That is not true. I am totally supportive of any worthwhile measure that will assist in permanently reducing unemployment. I am totally supportive of any project which will improve community facilities and services. What I have opposed, and will continue to oppose, is the use of public moneys to fund activities which have no practical purpose, or are of no real benefit to anyone but a few vocal radical activists, who see a chance to pursue their own questionable causes at the expense of the long-suffering taxpayer.

I am opposed to CEP funding being directed towards projects which could and/or should be funded from other sources. I am opposed to pouring money into projects which can best be described as bottomless pits. I am opposed to spending money on training people for jobs which do not exist, or to waste their time on developing useless, non-specific or limited application techniques and skills which are not generally in demand now, and are not ever likely to be in demand in the employment market-place. In short, I oppose extravagant, unjustifiable, uncontrolled and unaccounted for spending of public money. If this offends some people, so be it. I do not intend to alter my attitudes or to condone the waste of time or resources.
