What I will continue to do, and what I believe this Government should be doing, is to consider carefully each CEP project on its own merits and to weigh up what individual or community benefits are likely to be achieved for each CEP dollar spent. So far, the available evidence indicates that in some instances current CEP guidelines are too restrictive and, in other instances, not restrictive enough. I question the Government's claims about the number of new jobs created under CEP and I challenge its conclusion that CEP is an effective method by which to reduce the problem of long term unemployment.

Finally, there is a world of difference between the permanent, long term, secure employment opportunities in the private sector and the short term, artificially created, taxpayer-funded jobs in the public sector. Until this Government adopts policies which will result in real employment, the long-suffering taxpayer will be faced with the massive costs associated with creating `pretend' jobs and funding the additional schemes, services and facilities, such as the community youth support scheme, the community employment program, the new enterprise incentive scheme, the jobs on local roads program, Youth Access, Jobstart, et cetera, which are used to patch up the damage caused to individuals and the community by the continuing, unchecked problem of unemployment and this Government's refusal to recognise that job creation is the province of the private enterprise sector, particularly the small business sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What great knockers members of the Liberal Party of Australia are! What great knockers members of the National Party of Australia are! As a team, one would have to say they are totally non-inspirational. Their ideas are totally forgettable; their initiatives are desperately meagre. The rare good ideas they have fall off the back of an Australian Labor Party truck. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), mentioned the word `inadequacies'. I hope that he does not leave the chamber; I have a few pertinent remarks to make. The word `inadequacies' is one with which the coalition parties have a very close relationship. It epitomises the conservative cronies of the honourable member for Casey, who saw fit to refer to community employment program recipients as `useless good for nothings', as `useless recipients of public money'.

SPEECH.PARA: I am prepared to publish a few facts about the honourable member's electorate. In that electorate to date approval has been given for 83 projects. The total expenditure on CEP projects in the honourable member's electorate is $7,082,779. If the honourable member does not appreciate that amount of money-that $7m-which has been given to his electorate by a Labor government perhaps he would like to hand it back. If the kids in his electorate, the people who are being helped by this program, are useless no-gooders, let the honourable member give back the money. Some 565 jobs have been created. We will have those figures in his local paper, together with some of the honourable member's comments regarding those people. Five hundred and sixty-seven kids in the honourable member's electorate would be delighted to know the honourable member's opinion of them.

I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Community Employment Amendment Bill for two reasons. The first is that I live in Cessnock, New South Wales, in the centre of Australia's historic coal mining history, so I am not unfamiliar with the agony of unemployment. The second reason I enjoy speaking on this Bill is that it allows me to compare and to contrast the sympathetic attitudes towards the unemployed of the conservatives and the Labor Party in this great nation of ours.

When one speaks of unemployment the mind turns immediately to the Great Depression. Let us dwell on that period for one moment. Nothing much changes in politics, particularly with the conservative parties-the Tory parties in Australian politics. The coalition has changed its name from the Nationalist Party to the United Australia Party to the Liberal Party, and from the Australian Country Party to the National Party; but has its attitude changed?

The one thing that never changes is its incompetent handling of the economy. Throughout the 1920s we had the boom and bust economic measures of those paragons of conservatism-Stanley Melbourne Bruce and the Country Party's Sir Earle Page-who teamed up to plunge this country into economic ruin. Matching the incompetence of Bruce and Page with greed and a lack of sympathy for working class people were people such as coal baron Brown, whose great lockout brought the Depression to the coal fields months before it fastened its steely jaws on the rest of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the CEP?

—I am comparing attitudes. Coming from the coal fields of New South Wales it is hard not to become bitter about unemployment when one recalls moving stories of evictions by conservative governments and the necessity for hundreds of people to queue outside the soup kitchens. It was economic incompetence and rapacious conservatism that took this country into the Great Depression. It was a hostile Senate that denied James Scullin the policies needed to soften the blow of economic tragedy. Conservatives, then and now, are prepared to demean their fellow human beings by making them go through all sorts of indignities because they are not able to obtain worthwhile employment. We remember the pittance of a susso in those days. The conservatives have never had any decent schemes to aid employment. We remember the Depression days, when the country was plunged into economic gloom. What ideas did the conservatives have? Sir Otto Niemeyer from the Bank of England was invited here to advise the conservative Government. What did he say? He said: `Tighten your belts'. The whole attitude of the conservative forces to those who are unemployed is: Tighten your belts fellows, life was not meant to be easy; things will get better, perhaps. They never get better under a coalition government.

SPEECH.PARA: Latham, Lyons and Menzies did not have a clue about solving unemployment. They had to wait until World War II came to their rescue. The unemployed were then soaked up in the defence forces. However, the conservatives were equally hopeless as managers in war as they were in peace, so much so that the Australian people spurned conservative leaders and turned to that great Australian and Labor leader, John Curtin, who, as Prime Minister, gave his life to bring this country through World War II. Is it not significant that in times of crisis it is always Labor to which the people turn and which saves the day.

Menzies was lucky and blessed with a bright economic outlook. He did not have to contend with serious unemployment. What did conservatives have to offer when the unemployment blowtorch was applied to their bellies? The old cry from Malcolm `life was not meant to be easy, bear it fellows; the poor we will always have with us' epitomises the Opposition's attitude. There is no doubt about which party cares most for the unemployed. The Party that cares most for the unemployed is the Labor Party. Labor believes that it is the right of every man and woman to have a job, to escape the soul-destroying trauma of the unemployment scrap heap. We care for the dignity of the individual. What have members opposite ever done to generate employment? They have never given a determined commitment to jobs, jobs, jobs. Sure, they will use labour when it suits them for profit, profit, profit; but they have no thought, no care for the dignity of labour. The wage pause has been mentioned. It was a piddling, trifling little effort.

This century there have been two great employment schemes. Everyone knows the names of those schemes. First we had the Whitlam Labor Government's regional employment development scheme, and what a great success it was. People on the other side of the House are prepared to knock it, but as, member of the Labor Government throughout that period I know the great benefits, the everlasting benefits, it brought to communities throughout the length and breadth of this country. I am prepared to take honourable members opposite by the hand to my electorate-or to any electorate-and show them the substantial projects which were undertaken as a result of the RED scheme. Of course there was some small waste because local government authorities did not have the forward planning to complete successfully every project in so short time. However, overall it was an outstanding success, and the Australian populace knows that it was an outstanding success.

The second great employment scheme of this century is the Hawke-Willis community employment program. Those schemes come readily to the lips of every Australian. If one went into the streets and asked the average Australian to name an employment scheme initiated by the conservatives one would be met with a deafening silence. Labor cares for the workers and Labor makes a genuine effort to create jobs in times of economic adversity. This Bill seeks to extend for a further period of three years this outstandingly successful program CEP, which is aimed at the most disadvantaged in our labour force-the long term unemployed and special target groups. This is unlike the Opposition's wages pause program, which was very selective and did not go to the heart of the matter, to the long term unemployed, those who most needed to have their dignity restored. This program has given hope to this special group in our society and has enabled a large number in that group to be fully employed following participation in the program.

I will not canvass the reasons for the unemployment problems in Australia. I do not have the time. I will only re-emphasise that the conservatives opposite have never had an answer to unemployment problems. I believe that all speakers on the Government side have emphasised the great achievements which have been made by the CEP. The unemployed in Australia welcome the scheme. They want it to continue. It is a marvellous scheme. It is achieving remarkable goals. We are creating jobs for those who need them most-the long term unemployed, other groups or disadvantaged job seekers, Aborigines, the disabled, migrants with English language difficulties and women and youth. It is very important to recognise that the community employment program is the largest labour force program ever implemented by a Federal Government, and it was a Labor Government that delivered it. Statistics readily indicate that the community employment program is even more successful than the marvellous Whitlam regional employment development scheme, and it has been targeted to assist those whose needs are greatest. Work experience and training for unemployed people to obtain permanent employment have succeeded beyond everyone's expectations. Those who had little hope of returning to the general labour market have had their dreams realised.

The community employment program has been invaluable and has led to a high level of participants going on to full time employment at the conclusion of their particular project. Research clearly indicates that the probability of gaining employment declines noticeably the longer a person is out of work. This vicious circle of unemployment means that the problems faced by these people in getting back into the labour market cannot be addressed through economic recovery alone. But this program has been able to restore the confidence and psychological well-being of many long term unemployed and has provided the impetus to get them back into the normal work force.

One of the most outstanding achievements of the community employment program has been its success in meeting its objective of equal female representation in jobs created under the program. The overall participation of women in the program has been 38.6 per cent. I suspect that honourable members opposite have never done such a remarkable thing for women or shown much fairness towards women.

Particularly gratifying to me is the level of funding that has been allocated to my electorate of Hunter. I pay tribute to Mr Gavin Farley and his staff and all the people involved in Community employment program in the Hunter Valley. To date, a total of $7.5m has been approved for the Hunter electorate. This has financed 139 worthwhile community projects. These projects have enabled 757 people in the target groups to participate-359 women, 43 Aborigines, 167 disabled people, about whom we care, and 38 migrants. These figures also reveal that among the participants were 502 long term unemployed and 376 young people under the age of 25 years. I have mentioned that the spread of community employment program spending throughout the Hunter electorate as pleasing. The honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) was not pleased that his electorate had received $7m. He tried to suggest that community employment program funds were spent on all these left wing, way-out, fantastic sorts of projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is that a job?

—All right. Just listen. These are the way-out, left wing, non-useful projects on which money has been spent in the Hunter Valley. This week I received advice that the Denman Children's Centre in the northern sector of my electorate has received almost $22,000 for two clerical assistant positions to provide assistance to the child care centre. All those child care centre kids-oh, mate!-they are way-out. They are left wing as far as you can move, brother! Numerous projects have been approved for funding at Maitland, Cessnock, Singleton and Merriwa, which include the Walka Waterways Corporation, which has just received funding for phase 2 of its development, which will create a magnificent tourist attraction in the city of Maitland. This project will provide employment for nine people and the CEP component is $102,000. Also this week I was advised of CEP funding for the Maitland District Tourist Association, the Greenhills Church of Christ Nursing Home-a very radical left wing organisation, I assure you, brother-the Maitland family support scheme, the Maitland Youth Crisis Centre, the Singleton Child Care Centre, and a remarkable program for greening the Hunter River banks at Singleton. At Cessnock, the Cessnock Police Boys Club, the Cessnock Multi-Purpose Children's Centre, the Allandale Hospital Auxiliary and the Hunter Music Academy will all benefit from substantial CEP grants.

SPEECH.PARA: During 1985 many worthwhile community projects were funded throughout the Hunter electorate and throughout every other electorate in this great nation of ours. These programs have provided the necessary work experience and training for so many of the nation's disadvantaged people. Needless to say, all the projects were deserving of funding and were of great benefit to the community at large. I commend the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and my Government for taking positive action to assist those most in need in our society by continuing CEP funding. It is a salutary lesson to those opposite, who could never achieve anywhere near what we are achieving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Employment Amendment Bill, as others have said, extends the centrepiece of the Labor Government's labour market support programs. I rise to give the Bill some support, but I do so with very significant reservations. I think one point which was raised by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) and which needs to be challenged is the assertion that conservative parties have never done anything to help the unemployed. Of course, during the 16 halcyon years of the Menzies Government we did not need expensive job creation programs, because throughout that period the so-called conservative Government maintained full employment in this country-something the Whitlam Government was never able to do and something that this Government is unable to do, either. Instead of addressing the fundamental causes of unemployment, as the Menzies Government did, the Australian Labor Party has looked at some sort of a quick fix answers, and a temporary one at that, such as the community employment program, which, of course, does alleviate some of the hardship of unemployment-that is incontestable-but, at the same time, Labor also runs away from the real causes of unemployment and the very real issues that should be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not only the view of a back bencher on the Opposition side; this was a view also of the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs in Australia. At the very beginning of the report, in a chapter entitled `The Context', Mr Kirby said:

Labour market programs, no matter how extensive or well co-ordinated, are not a panacea for achieving full employment. The links between labour market programs and policies and the achievement and maintenance of full employment are not as strong or direct as many may have thought in the past. Macroeconomic policies have a far more significant influence on the demand for labour . . .

I do not think that I have read a truer statement from an independent inquiry of that kind for many years. The fundamental macroeconomic problem in Australia relates to the nature of our labour market and the rigidity that is built into that labour market by the Government and by its partner, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. For reasons of their own, they will not accept a less rigid labour market. They will not move gradually towards a greater degree of flexibility in that market which would create employment opportunities for those tragically out of work. Instead, they believe that the whole of their economic policy must rest on the foundation of a deal with the ACTU-a deal which guarantees wage increases for everybody, regardless of whether they are in a strong or a weak industry, but which keeps the unemployed out of work. The Government does a deal with the ACTU, but it will not do a deal with the unemployed. We are now faced with a 3 per cent productivity deal on top of all that-a quite extraordinary initiative from a government that claims to be concerned about the unemployed. To take one example from rural Australia, with incomes declining, many farmers now existing on negative incomes will also be asked to pay the full 3 per cent increase in so-called productivity. Clearly there has not been an increase in productivity on the land in Australia in the last couple of years and it is absurd to expect primary producers to do that.

Over the last three years there has been some economic growth in Australia as the cyclical pattern in the economy has turned up, just as it did between 1978 and 1981 during the period of the Fraser Government. The present Government, since it came to power, has benefited from the world economic recovery. It initially also benefited from the breaking of the drought. But one of the things it also benefited from in the employment sector was the wages pause initiated by the Fraser Government. The wages pause is an example of a policy which was a direct assault on the problem of unemployment. It froze wages to help employers have the capacity not only to survive during a recession but also to provide additional jobs for Australians. It also provided some $200m for job creation schemes. The CEP is largely modelled on those schemes. In addition, $100m was put into the Commonwealth Development Bank to help small businesses as well.

Honourable members opposite may remember that this wages pause program was supported by every State government in Australia whether Labor, Liberal or National Party. It was also widely and strongly supported by the Australian community. But who did not support it? Only one section of the community opposed it and that was the Federal Labor Party, the Federal Opposition at the time. Labor says it is concerned about unemployment. It says that people should have the opportunity to have jobs but it opposed one of the most constructive job creation policies-the wages pause-and worse, the now Attorney-General and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) in January or February 1983 called for the unions to take industrial action in order to support the breaking of the wages pause. That is a staggering initiative from what is now a government supposedly concerned about the problem of unemployment.

That high unemployment at the time of the Fraser Government was, as I said, due to a very severe world recession. That is well documented. It was also caused by a substantial wages explosion in 1979, 1980 and 1981. Who was behind that wages explosion? Was Mr Fraser behind the wages explosion? No, the person behind that wages explosion was none other than the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He was the man who as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in 1979 went out and called on the unions to take industrial action in support of as great a wage claim as they could possibly achieve. He was the architect of the massive unemployment that existed, and still exists, indeed, in Australia. He was the man who, as President of the ACTU, also oversaw, I might mention, the loss of some 32 million man days throughout his period in that job.

Of course, there have been some improvements, as everybody knows, in the raw unemployment figures since March 1983 as a result of the economic upturn. When we look at these figures fairly carefully they are by no means as bright as one would hope during a period of some global and, of course, national economic recovery. After all, during the three main years of economic recovery during the period of the Fraser Government-1978 to 1981-just under 500,000 new jobs were also created. At the end of that economic upswing there was a lower level of unemployment in Australia than there is at this time at the end of the subsequent economic upswing.

It is also worth noting, since members on the other side continually berate us for the performance of the Fraser Government, that for 82 of the Fraser Government's 86 months in office, unemployment was lower than it is this very day after three years of growth in Australia. The other significant point about the present level of unemployment is that the duration of those on the dole has also grown. That point has been made by other speakers and I do not wish to labour it. It is important to recognise that in 1983 the average duration of unemployment was 33.2 weeks and now it is getting up close to a full year. For those people who are in long term unemployment things have became worse and not improved during the period of this Government, in spite of some economic upturn over that period.

Unemployment in Australia is still a very massive problem. It is a problem that all humane Australians should be doing their best to address. As I said, the Government is attacking the symptoms of unemployment with the very expensive community employment program and it is not attacking the causes. Consequently we have a community employment program which is costing the Commonwealth Government alone $880m or so a year. If one adds on the costs paid by States and local governments the figure is very much higher.

It is incontestable that the community employment program has provided some benefits. In my own electorate there is no doubt that benefits have come to the community through the creation of much needed facilities. We have a major problem in the Adelaide Hills and in the Fleurieu Peninsula with bushfires and a large number of Country Fire Service sheds have been built as part of the community employment scheme. There has also been some assistance with the construction of community halls. I suppose the best known CEP project in my electorate and, indeed, the best known in South Australia is the Victor Harbour railway project, where the State and the Federal governments agreed to use CEP funds to upgrade that railway. I called for that initiative, I might say, back in January 1983 and I congratulate the Government on adopting my proposal.

Having said that, I point out that there are many substantial weaknesses as well in the CEP. I believe in many respects that it is an extremely inefficient way to both provide facilities and to create jobs. I will just use a couple of quick examples from my own electorate to show that is the case. In the town of Normanville near Yankalilla a caravan park has been built under CEP. The cost of creating that caravan park, which has involved the clearing of some land, the building of toilets and showers, and the building of a very small house and store as well, has been $820,000. It has cost nearly $1m, and to build the caravan park has taken about a full year. It is not as though at an enormous expense to the taxpayers many jobs had been created. Only 38 jobs were created for nearly $1m. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), in giving the cost of CEP, used a figure of between $9,000 and $10,000 per job. If that were the case, in the instance of the Normanville caravan park we would be looking at more like 100 jobs rather than 38 jobs. It is an example of a fairly inefficient sort of project and I hope that similar projects will not be repeated, at least in such an inefficient way.

In the town of Murray Bridge, a toy library provides a very important service and facility to many people in that community. I have given a lot of support to the work the people there have been doing. Under CEP a young woman was trained as a librarian for the toy library and I think her training period was something approximating one month. She then worked in the toy library, supported by the CEP, for six months. At the end of that six months, though, this hard working and enthusiastic young woman was retrenched because, of course, on average the program lasts for only six months. Instead of her being able to continue in employment, that poor woman was thrown back on to the dole and somebody else is in the process of being trained and will be put into that job. I suppose one could say that at least two people have had a turn at being trained and working in the Murray Bridge toy library but the simple fact is that in human terms somebody who has been trained, somebody who could do the job proficiently, has now been thrown back on to the dole. That is a tragedy for that woman. As far as the community is concerned, two people are being trained to do one job for a period of one year and there is a clear inefficiency in that.

Obviously there are examples too of some projects which one would have to describe as fairly futile. In that instance I move away from my own electorate and take a very good example of a project in the electorate of the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) where the CEP secretariat has agreed with the local council and the State Government to pave about three kilometres of what is known as King William Road at a cost of $4m. That is quite absurd. The road was a reasonably adequate road before it was paved. Four million dollars of the community's money was pumped into repaving that road. I looks nice and some people say it is the best road in Australia. I would not doubt it at that sort of cost, but it provides no real addition to the stock of resources for the community, considering all the other very great needs in our society.

Other projects are completely ignored. In my electorate, in country towns there is still a need for community houses. There are shortages of labour for various voluntary organisations such as Meals on Wheels. None of these necessary and important projects can be assisted by the CEP under the guidelines, yet all that money-$4m-was poured into what was frankly absurd, the paving of King William Road. The other really major weakness of the CEP is the fact that it creates jobs for just six months. In other words, for many people it creates jobs without hope. No doubt the Minister's figures are accurate and 41 per cent of those who worked under the CEP have subsequently found permanent jobs. I recognise that, but 59 per cent of people who have worked on the CEP-the example of my constituent in the Murray Bridge toy library is a very good one-have really found that CEP jobs are jobs without hope. After six months, on average, those people have been thrown back into the tragedy of unemployment.

Apart from changing the macroeconomic policies of the Government-I do not want to debate that any more-are there many real, constructive alternatives to the CEP in terms of job creation? We need to look at the total cost of unemployment to the community in dollars and cents. It is interesting to see that the cost to the Commonwealth Government is in the vicinity of $4.5 billion. On top of that, there are a large number of State schemes. I have not been able to establish their exact cost but I believe that it is about $2 billion. Most of the Commonwealth's $4.5 billion expenditure is paid out just in dole payments. They are really compensation for failure for the poor people who are unemployed. I regard that compensation for failure as a fairly inadequate and unimaginative response to a very real, human problem.

We should be looking increasingly at paying the dole as a reward for achievement rather than as compensation for failure. I urge the Government to look at some of the alternative schemes that have been thrown around in the community, not least the sorts of work benefit schemes which propose that the unemployed be given at least some community work in return for their unemployment payment. All unemployed people should have the opportunity under that sort of scheme to do some kind of part time work. Those who choose not to do that-and as a Liberal I am a great believer in choice-should continue to receive a basic allowance. Those who choose to participate in a work for benefit scheme, in other words, those who choose to contribute to the community, should receive not just a basic allowance but, on top of it, should be able to earn the casual award rate of, say, $4.50 or $5 an hour up to and a little beyond the full unemployment benefit.

An 18-year old with no dependants who is single and unemployed at the moment gets $88.20. Under a work for benefit scheme-I use these figures as an illustration-that person could receive a basic allowance of about $50 and work on a community project of some kind for $4.50 an hour, up to an income of perhaps $90 or $100 a week. That scheme would give all unemployed people who want it some involvement in the community. One of the great problems with unemployment, as I am sure all honourable members know, is the psychological and debilitating effect it has on the jobless. If we gave them something to do-all those who want to participate-they would have the chance to raise their dignity and the community would get something in return for its investment whereas, at the moment, it gets practically nothing.

I believe that this sort of scheme could replace all the existing unemployment schemes such as the CEP and the large number of State schemes. That would have the advantage of reducing duplication and waste. The State and Federal governments could draw up a list of approved programs that would be used for a work for benefit scheme and those programs would be based very much on submissions coming from both local government and community groups. It is worth mentioning that that sort of approach was taken by the Fraser Government when it introduced its wages pause, but it did not have much time to develop it as a result of the shocking outcome of the March 1983 election.

This sort of work for benefit scheme would not just be directed towards major capital projects, as the CEP tends to be, but also towards labour intensive projects. In other words, people would be able to assist with the provision of voluntary services in the community. In Stirling, in my electorate, 59 people receive assistance from Meals on Wheels, which can no longer find anybody to provide that much needed service to elderly people. I would have thought that that was an example where a work for benefit scheme could use the unemployed to provide a much needed community service. I do not have a dogmatic commitment to this sort of scheme, but I think there is a very great advantage in the Government and all members of this House giving consideration to some sort of scheme that provides not compensation for failure for those unfortunate enough to be out of work but opportunity for them to be rewarded for achievement in the community and to gain some dignity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very interesting to hear the contribution of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I congratulate him. It was the best contribution we have heard from the Opposition so far, including the speech of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) the other evening, which was disgraceful. The honourable member for Mayo was very quick to get off the subject of his electorate. He did not point out to the Parliament or the Australian people that under the community employment program his electorate had received $8m. He pointed out a couple of projects that he had supported, but I wonder what happened to the other $8m worth of projects. Did he support them or refuse them? The honourable member nods, and I appreciate that.

SPEECH.PARA: I also noticed that the honourable member for Mayo was very quick to mention Bob Menzies. We all know that in his own right he was probably one of Australia's great Prime Ministers. I did not agree with him, but he contributed to the nation in some small way. The honourable member was very slow to mention Malcolm Fraser, the famous former Prime Minister. I pay him the tribute that he tried to justify Malcolm Fraser's record by manipulating the figures a little, but he and the Australian people know Malcolm Fraser's record and they will never forget it. The honourable member will be on the Opposition benches for many years because of that so-called famous Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser. The shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), also knows Malcolm Fraser's record.

Let me tell the House about the Hawke Labor Government's record on the CEP. I am very proud to support the Community Employment Amendment Bill. I am sure that all Australians who are concerned about unemployment will also support the CEP. Since its inception, the Federal Government has allocated $968,763,000. It has approved about 16,772 projects with the creation of 93,216 jobs. In Queensland, to which I will give special mention, the allocation was $160,390,000, for the creation of 16,373 jobs. I am very grateful to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the Government for the great contribution to my electorate of Griffith of $25,401,000, and the creation of 2,214 jobs. The other night we had the opportunity to hear the Deputy Leader of the Opposition take half an hour to rant and rage about the disgraceful CEP. At the end of his speech, he said: `Well, the Opposition is not opposing the Bills; we are supporting the community employment program'. Of course the Opposition supports it, and so it should. It was a disgraceful episode and a disgraceful speech by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

This is my first opportunity to speak in the Parliament since returning from the United Nations. When I left the country, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) was in charge of Opposition business as Leader of the Opposition. But on my first day out of the country Andrew, the honourable member for Kooyong, shot himself in the foot and I found out that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The country went to pieces when you left.

—I know that the country went to pieces when I left but the Opposition also went to pieces. I thought that, when the honourable member for Bennelong took over control of the Opposition benches, everything would be different and that we might get some honesty and integrity from Opposition members. But we found that, although the Opposition front bench had changed, nothing was different within the Opposition. Opposition members-with a few exceptions-were still trying to deceive, and to lie to, the people of Australia--
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. You know that the term used by the honourable member for Griffith has been ruled unparliamentary. I ask him to withdraw.
—Which word?
—I am sorry; I will not repeat the word but he suggested that members of the Opposition had been deliberately untrue.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.

—I was referring to the whole of the Opposition and not to one member but, in deference to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will withdraw and say that members of the Opposition have been handling the truth carelessly since that change. I would like to point our a few of the points made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The Opposition has criticised no more than 15 projects approved under the CEP in Australia. Opposition members have homed in on a few areas. I will mention one project that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition criticised and that was the peace and disarmament project. We have also had criticism of this project from the honourable member for Moreton, Mr Donald Cameron, through letters in the media. It is very misleading when the Opposition homes in on these few projects. Opposition members continue their effort to try to deceive the people of Australia. But the people will not be fooled by them. It is a very interesting point that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition criticised the peace and disarmament project, especially the peace bus.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of letters from the then shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), which he sent to Mr Worth from the peace and disarmament project. One letter states:
Thank you for your letter of 24 October 1984.
As you know the Opposition has released an expanded policy paper on disarmament and arms reduction and I am trying to get 500 copies printed for you.
As soon as they are available . . .

I inform the House that I have another letter here that I will be happy to table for anyone to see. It is from the then shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Mackellar, in which he stated that he could not supply 5,000 pamphlets for this bus to distribute. Opposition members have criticised the peace bus but they used it to distribute their literature during the election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right; hypocrisy.
—We have the hypocrisy of them criticising a project that they have been using.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at another criticism. I have an article from the Brisbane Courier-Mail of 19 February entitled `CEP money is used to fund leftist groups . . .'. It reports that a Queensland senator from the National Party of Australia asked a question in the other place. He referred to the allocation of $47,000 to the `unilateralist' Campaign for International Co-operation and Disarmament. He criticised what he called leftist CEP projects. Let me make a point about this honourable gentleman. I wonder what he will say to the people from the Queensland Lawn Tennis Association about a grant of $111,866 to the Queensland Lawn Tennis Association for repairs to the grandstand. Senator Glen Sheil is an official of that club. I am sure he will not mention anything about that, but he criticises the CEP projects.

But there is more to be said about Queensland. We have heard Opposition members saying how bad the CEP is. Let me just mention a few of the projects that have been approved in my electorate in Brisbane. An amount of $2,100,000 went to the Brisbane City Council-a Liberal council-for bikeways. The National Party's Lands Department received $456,633 for computerisation of reserves records. There is a grant of $491,000 to the Liberal Brisbane City Council, yet another grant of $320,000 to the Liberal Brisbane City Council and yet another grant of $280,000 to the Brisbane City Council. Then we have a grant of $460,000 to the Greek Orthodox Community of St George in Brisbane. I wonder what Opposition members will say to the Greek community if they consider that a leftist program and that it should not receive those funds. There is also a grant to the Justice Department-another National Party Government instrumentality. I could go on and on with grants that have been given to the National Party Government in Queensland. I refer to grants under the CEP program that the National Party and the Liberal Party do not believe in. Yet we have a National Party Government and a Liberal council taking all these funds from the CEP. They are very quick to accept the money.

I will quickly read out some figures from State Government departments in Queensland that receive CEP money. They have applied for it from the committees and from the Federal Government. They are: Department of Health, $954,242 and $1,244,000, Railway Department, $386,000 and $1,116,000, and the Police Department, $476,000. They are just a few of the examples of how bad the CEP is according to the National Party Government in Queensland. There are more examples. I draw the attention of the House to the operation of the CEP in Queensland, in particular the Queensland Government's participation in the State sponsored CEP. I have read out the figures but it is very interesting that I continue on this line. I will try to be as quick as I can.

I am sure all honourable members will be most amazed to know that this is one of the few joint State-Federal programs in which the Bjelke-Petersen National Party Government participates zealously. We always hear from the Bjelke-Petersen Government how bad the Federal Government is and how bad all these programs are. But the Premier loves this project. Let me tell honourable members how much he loves this program.

TALK.START.PARA: —He never sends the money back.
—We all know why he loves this program.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, and I am reliably informed, that directives have been issued to State Government departments instructing financial planners within the departments that wherever possible CEP applications are to be made for work carried out by the departments. On 9 August last year my office received copies of 46 applications submitted to the CEP secretariat by the State Government. I will cite a few examples of the types of work put forward in some of the submissions from this particular batch of applications. There was one from the Queensland harbours and Marine Department, one from the Railway Department and one from the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service which I will come back to. The Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service has been in the Press recently. I think we all know about that and I will mention some more figures shortly. Other departments which lodged applications were the Queensland Forestry Department, the Lands Department, the South Brisbane Hospitals Board, the Queensland Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, the Department of Mapping and Surveying, the Mines Department, the Police Department, the Works Department and the Department of Primary Industries. They all love the CEP program, as do all concerned Australians. Bjelke-Petersen especially loves it.

I believe that the State Government, through the community employment program, is reducing the number of its permanent employees by employing CEP participants to carry out what are in most cases normal clerical duties in the State public service. My claims are supported by factual evidence which I will be happy to supply. I can supply that from the Queensland Public Service Board's annual report and CEP records. They are all available for honourable members on the other side and I am sure honourable members from the Government side will be interested in those figures.

I want to mention one special department in Queensland; we need look no further to see how money is manipulated by the Queensland Government. I refer to the Department of Tourism, National Parks, Sport and the Arts. Honourable members all know that until a few days ago that was administered by none other than the Queensland Premier's ex-Press Secretary, the infamous Mr Allan Callaghan. As a good example of the misuse of Commonwealth funds, that Department had received a total of $7.2m CEP funds as at January this year. We know how some of the money has been disappearing. We all know who is responsible for that. People have had to resign. The Federal Government has paid $7.2m to this Department. We have been paying while they have been manipulating the funds. We all know that until a few days ago Mr Allan Callaghan was running that Department, so I do not think it is too hard to work out what has been going on. Although I have much more evidence here, I cannot continue because time has run out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll move an extension.

—I am happy for the honourable member to move an extension of time, but it would be taken off his side's time. I have much more information here about the Queensland Government and how it is manipulating CEP funds. CEP is much more important than our concern about the State Government manipulating funds. The program was originated to help young unemployed people. As a businessman for 20 years I know all about employing people and I know about how staff should be handled. I can recall that when young people came to me for a job I would be happy to employ them if they had had experience but if they had not had experience I would have to think twice. I have spoken to the people who have participated in the CEP projects in my electorate. All of the young people who had jobs under the CEP were given references by the employers so that they could go to other employers with those references and with job experience. That is what it is all about-giving young unemployed people a job and giving them experience so that when they front up to employers they have a much greater chance of being employed. I congratulate the committees in the different States that have assisted the Federal Government on CEP projects. I congratulate all the bureaucrats involved in the Commonwealth Employment Service who are doing a marvellous job for the Government. I congratulate the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations on this very worthwhile program. I hope it continues for many years, as I am sure it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we start talking about schemes designed to lower unemployment it is worth while spending some time considering what causes unemployment. Labor is a commodity and is subject, like any other commodity, to the laws of supply and demand. If the demand cannot match the supply, which it cannot at the price being asked now, we get an unsold product called unemployment. The 8 per cent unemployment that we have is the amount of the product that remains unsold. Clearly the product is overpriced. Both wages and the on-costs of wages are too high. A former Australian Labor Party treasurer, Frank Crean, summed all this up beautifully with the expression: `One man's wage rise is another man's job'. This is particularly pertinent when we consider youth employment. While we have 7.8 or 8 per cent unemployment, the youth unemployment rate has now risen to 21.4 per cent-some to two to three times the adult unemployment rate. Obviously the level of youth wages is not only pitched too high but also pitched too high relative to adult wages.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that the best way to lower unemployment would be to lower wages, especially youth wages. In fact, a complete deregulation of the youth wage market would be the greatest gift this Government could give to our unemployed youth. Much better that they can get a job at $200 a week than that they can get no job at $250 a week. Of course such a proposition would be too easy to implement and, heaven forbid, it has the twin evils of being common sense and it would work.

Governments of all colours have not been able to resist dabbling with makework job creation programs. Whitlam had the disastrous regional employment development scheme; the South African tourist, Mr Fraser, had his special youth employment training programs; and now the Hawke-Crean Government has the community employment program. All have wasted money like it is going out of fashion and all have failed in that they have usually destroyed more jobs than they have created. Let me explain. To set up one of these jobs costs about $20,000 of taxpayer's money for a year, plus 20 to 30 per cent more from the sponsor-a community group, local council or whatever. On top of that there is a stack of other costs-supervision and the like. The total cost is quite substantial. With that sort of outlay we naturally have some responsibility to the hard pressed taxpayers of this country to see that the unemployed people placed in those high cost jobs actually do something worth while.

However this has not been the case and I would now like to turn to some examples of what I mean so the taxpayers of this country can see how carefully-or rather, carelessly-their money has been spent. Here are some of the community employment program projects that have been funded since the Government started this wonderful program in August 1983: I refer firstly to the Campaign for International Co-operation and Disarmament. It is a group which has close links with the pro-Moscow Socialist Party of Australia-

TALK.START.PARA: —All pinkies.
—That is right. It received $47,568. What for? To employ three people for a year to celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary. Some party that must have been.
—On taxpayers' money?

—That is right. The People for Nuclear Disarmament received $78,482 to employ five people on a peace bus project, as has been mentioned here previously, but on top of that it was given $15,392 to employ one person on disarmament education. I quote from the organisation's left wing magazine Challenge:

SPEECH.PARA: The bus is equipped with all sorts of propaganda aids.

The mind boggles. It advertises in the communist newspaper Tribune for staff, so ends up with many communist members. The Victorian Trades Hall Council got $81,640-no figure is too high-to employ four people for a year on cataloguing industrial information. As if that is not enough, it received a further $157,839 for 12 people to work for eight months on-listen to this-a trade union art and working life program.

How about these other groups? The Friends of the Earth received $23,697 for two people to conduct research into recycling. Its magazine Chain Reaction was a bit short of cash so it received $34,696 to employ two people for editorial and promotional activities. FILEF, the Australian operation of the Italian Communist Party, received $36,766 for the construction of new offices and staffing. The Victorian branch of the Union of Australian Women, a communist-led organisation if ever there was one, got $35,631 for three people to write the history of this esteemed organisation. Can you believe it?

TALK.START.PARA: —On taxpayers' money?

—That is right. Melbourne's left wing community radio station, 3CR, was looking a bit tacky. That would not do for our comrade announcers, so it received $26,203 for renovations. That was not enough; it received $29,970 for three people for seven months to carry out an ethnic broadcasting development program. Canberra's radical radio station 2XX recently was granted $112,987 to train seven people in audio production for a year.
—What is our deficit?

—God knows. The Australian Capital Territory Trades and Labor Council received $245,230 to employ 13 people for a year and Actors Equity, that fine moderate group, received $15,426 to make representations to `eliminate current exploitation of announcers by employers'. Have you ever heard anything more ridiculous? The Printing and Kindred Industries Union, another fine bunch of moderates, received $172,644-no figure is too high-for nine people to `investigate the extent of sub-award employment practices'.
—And they complain about poverty in this country.

—That is right, they do. The Womens Sub-Committee of the Newcastle Trades Hall Council, that lovely group of even-handed people, received $45,641 for three people for 10 months. The Victorian Teachers Union has been given $110,617 to fund its women's affirmative action handbook. I ask honourable members to listen to this one which must surely be the daddy of them all: The Gay Publications Co-operative and one of its affiliates, between them, have received $123,280 to do things such as produce their homosexual magazines Outrage and Gay Community News. It is an outrage all right! It is an outrageous waste of taxpayers' money. If the Australian Labor Party wants to support and fund such deviant behaviour, as it so obviously wants to do, let it fund these practices out of its own pocket. But it should not do it with taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.PARA: The list goes on and on. In the last few weeks alone I have been deluged in my office with a mountain of Press releases from the office of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), all bragging at just how quickly they can waste taxpayers' money. Let me read from a sample of them so that honourable members can judge for themselves just how worth while they are. There are numerous amazing examples. Twenty-one young unemployed people are to work for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation at a cost of $334,890. What is the aim of this project? Let me quote from the Press release which states:
The major aims of the project are for young people-so far so good-
of non-Anglo Celtic backgrounds to provide an opportunity for `accented' voices to be heard on air and win acceptance within the community.
If people have an Australian drawl, like me, they cannot get on. The Hobart City Council-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Here is one for the honourable member for Franklin. An amount of $24,800 has been allocated to the Hobart City Council to employ two people for 29 weeks to paint murals on three inner city sites. Here is another one, involving the South Australian Health Commission. An amount of $71,481 has been allocated to employ 10 people for up to 32 weeks to obtain information on the health needs of women. The Ministry of Planning and Environment has been allocated $1.3m for six projects, one of which includes sending people out to investigate and assess shipwreck sites.
—What have they done for Australian families?

—It makes one wonder. Nothing, according to the list that I have. The Association for Community Theatre Inc. is to receive $41,873 for rehearsals and performances of a multicultural play in English and Polish. This is for primary school students, not adults. That association is to employ six persons on the play, five of whom must be migrants with English language difficulties-if people can talk English they cannot get on-and these people will be employed for 16 weeks. It is beyond belief! Central Sydney will get $86,226 to train Aborigines in the objectives and activities of trade unions in New South Wales. I am sure that that will do them a lot of good in Redfern. Seven people are to be employed at a cost of $81,975 to beautify a museum site. There is nothing wrong with the project so far. The project is for six months and the Press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . they will gain experience and training in gardening and landscaping, a vocation much in demand in the Canberra region.

If it is much in demand why does the Government have to support these people? Why do they not just go out and get the jobs? Another project involves research into women's unemployment issues involving $138,487 for 12 small-scale projects aimed at improving the position of women in the work force. The Press release states that only women need apply so I guess that that will achieve the objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are all coming from news releases from the Minister?

—That is right, they are. Here is a good one. A project involving the recording of oral history of Aboriginal communities in the far north-west of Australia will have $98,057 spent on it and will employ five Aborigines to collect stories about Aboriginal experiences over the last 150 years. When they have done this they will translate the text into standard English-whatever that is-Bardii and Creole. Bardii is a local Aboriginal language and I am told that Creole is not a north American Indian tribe but pidgin English. That is one of 19 projects. I will not read the others as time does not permit, but let me mention another great one. An amount of $60,438 is to be allocated to employ some people to go along and compile a checklist of plants in the Alligator Rivers region. The Press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: The project will provide the participants with valuable work experience-
honourable members can imagine them stepping over crocodiles-
which should greatly enhance their prospects of future permanent employment.

I am sure that it will. A sum of $98,700 will be given to enhance the environment and appearance of the Albion Explosives Factory. An amount of $137,000 is to be given to a theatre to employ 12 people for 26 weeks to put on two plays and a community theatre play. They will be worth seeing! Here is a ripper. That Arts Council of the Australian Capital Territory--
