SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) acknowledges and applauds the Government's record in focusing public attention on the problem of road safety;
(2) encourages the Australian community to join with and assist governments in fostering better attitudes towards road safety, especially amongst the young, and

(3) urges all State governments to heed the federal Minister for Transport's call for the introduction of a graduated licensing scheme whereby the nation's youth might be better trained and qualified before being licensed to drive independently.

Last year almost 3,000 Australians were killed on our roads-3,000 of our most precious asset, Australian people. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said, the road toll is one of our most horrific social problems. More Australians will die on our roads in the first four months of this year than during action in both the Korean and Vietnam wars combined. This is an appalling waste of life. In fact, it costs the Australian community about $3,000m every year. Each week it costs the Federal Government $3m in welfare payments alone. None of us can afford to ignore this human and economic cost, and yet we do. To keep the public aware of the war on our roads, we would need banner headlines, screaming: `3,000 Australians killed', `30,000 seriously injured'. But that type of headline would be needed at least every week.

In addressing this problem of trying to keep the public continuously aware of the carnage on the roads, I would like to propose that the Government encourage and assist in the setting up of a national organisation of those who have been most directly affected by road accidents-the bereaved families, the injured and those in the community currently striving for improvements in road safety and reductions in the road carnage. Such an organisation or association could and would become a community lobby group capable of keeping pressure on legislators and keeping the public aware of the massive costs in human suffering through road accidents. Returned servicemen have the Returned Services League, consumers have consumer associations, and Vietnam veterans have their Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. Road accident victims, the injured and the bereaved, should have an organisation, a road accident bereaved and injured organisation, which could play a vital role in addressing the road carnage. Just look at these costs: In 1984, 2,812 were killed and 29,231 were seriously injured. The annual cost to the community was over $3,000m, with $3m in welfare payments each week being paid out by the Federal Government alone. All of us should be getting together as a community to put an end to this carnage.

May I say how pleased I am as a member of this House to see the initiative and support being given by the current Government to the effort of saving Australian lives. It is a national issue, requiring national leadership and initiative. In saying this, may I congratulate the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) for his efforts. In the three years of this Government we have seen the most comprehensive overhaul of our national transport system. Part of this effort has been a much enhanced contribution to improved road safety. One of the most significant contributions this Government is making is in the area of research and promotion. We have in the Federal Office of Road Safety an excellent unit dedicated to identifying the elements needing attention and prescribing remedies. It is, I might suggest, a world leader. In fact, we as Australians are world leaders in road safety and we have the figures to prove it. Initiative from the Federal Office, in conjunction with some of the more enlightened States have brought us a long way. However, there is still a long way to go.

Promotional activities are high on the list of Government initiatives and it is most gratifying to see the excellent material being produced, particularly for use in schools, aimed at teaching our young the fundamentals of better road safety. Recent campaigns on helmet wearing for cyclists featuring Molly Meldrum are an excellent example. Similarly, the Out and About campaign where exercise books and teachers' guides have been produced for primary school children, is an excellent product. The motor vehicle itself, for long the focus of much attention, continues to be improved in both its primary and secondary safety. Much of the credit for this is due to the role of the Federal Government. The development of the Australian design rules has given us, for the first time, a set of national standards to be followed by industry. The renovation of these this year to remove a number of small anomalies will see the finalisation of a truly national system. We are now leaders in motor vehicle safety, for not only do we have common national standards of manufacture, but we have an unobtrusive system for checking that those systems are maintained as part of the normal quality control process. There will, of course, always be some gaps in the motor vehicle safety system. Defects will always be found, but at least we now have a system whereby vehicle weaknesses can be quickly detected and rectified.

While speaking of vehicle defects and weaknesses, I have been concerned for some time about the multiplicity of seat-belt release buttons and their location. Some are located on the top of the buckle, some are on the side, and some are in the centre. Surely the manufacturers could at least standardise the size and location of the seat-belt release button. One does not need a great deal of imagination to understand the type of problem that could be encountered if there was need to make a fast exit from a burning car and the seat-belt release button was not in the familiar place.

Continuing on with this matter of safety systems in motor vehicles, let me say that there are a number of factors causing this road carnage. Speeding vehicles, particularly through intersections, are very high on the list of cause factors. There is currently available a cruise control option that maintains the speed set by the driver. It operates by using the manifold vacuum to pull down the throttle. This automatic control is immediately cancelled when the brake pedal is depressed and the throttle control is immediately returned to the driver.

There are other variants of speed control and speed warning indicators. However, the issue I wish to canvass is a proposal that vehicles be fitted with a light on the top of the vehicle, similar to the police and ambulance vehicles. This light would come on when the vehicle went above 60 kilometres per hour. The proposal is technically not difficult and the cost would be very small. For such a safety addition to the vehicle, the driver would be seen to be exceeding the speed limit when his outside roof light came on. There is currently a requirement that a vehicle show when the brakes are applied. We call it stop lights. There is currently a requirement that a vehicle show when it is being driven round a corner or changing lanes. We call it indicators. It should be a requirement that a vehicle indicate to other road users, and to the public generally, that the vehicle is exceeding the speed limit-a flashing speed light on the roof of a person's vehicle proclaiming to the general public: `My car is speeding'. I believe such a development would be more effective than, or equally as effective as, radar traps. I hope the Minister will give this proposal serious consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly.

—He is a very good Minister, too. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) also deserves commendation, and I refer here to the amendments to the Trade Practices Act providing for product recall. The voluntary system we have had now for so long is clearly not good enough. Australian lives are too important to leave at the discretion of manufacturers alone. Similarly, with heavy vehicles a great deal of effort has been made, especially in improving braking, to ensure that the standard of vehicle safety is improved. In connection with this, it is worth noting that the interstate road transport legislation which passed through Parliament in the last period of sittings, will significantly boost heavy vehicle safety. Safe operations of interstate transport will be, under this legislation, a fundamental requirement for the retention of interstate registration.

SPEECH.PARA: To move from the motor vehicle, the second important ingredient in the recipe for improved road safety is better roads. On road construction and maintenance this Government has increased funding by over 80 per cent since being elected to office. This year we have a record budget for road construction of $1,245m.

This brings me to the essence of the motion, for no matter how safe our vehicles are, no matter how much we spend on better roads, it is the person behind the wheel of the vehicle who is the greatest problem. An increasing proportion of the Government's research and promotion budget is therefore being directed to the human factor. The importance of developing appropriate road safety attitudes among youth should not be underestimated. Young males under 25 represent 21 per cent of the population but 35 per cent of fatalities. In 1984, 47 per cent of those killed and 54 per cent of the seriously injured were under 25 years of age. For youth, getting a driver's licence, as we all realise from our own experience, is an exciting time. It coincides with the end of school and starting life on one's own. Driving a car is a symbol of independence and responsibility. Unfortunately, however, learning to drive and learning to drink also coincide. This is a fatal combination. Drinking and driving are simply not compatible. Attitudes must be changed. Over the last few years we have seen a concentration on the human aspects of road safety. Advertising campaigns initiated by the Federal Government and pursued by the States aimed at combating drink driving are excellent examples. Learning to drive is much more than knowing how to steer, park, reverse and perform all the physical functions to get the vehicle from A to B. This is called car craft. Learning to drive should be a process of acquiring road craft-the ability to look ahead, to anticipate and to understand. Sadly, many have never learned road craft and much work needs to be done in developing better training schemes to overcome these attitudes of `She'll be right', or `it can't happen to me'. We need to replace our impatience, aggression and frustration with courtesy, consideration and concentration. We need to anticipate better the needs of other road users.

The Minister for Transport has proposed a graduated licensing scheme whereby learner drivers are subject to a longer probationary period under the varying degrees of supervision and restriction as one part of the solution. This is an excellent concept. For many, to learn to drive at a young age contradicts conventional wisdom. They mistakenly believe that the driving age should be raised. However, it is not the age at which the learning process begins that is relevant, but the quality and the length of the learning process. The basis of the graduated scheme is that over four 6-month periods a learner driver would progress through four phases, the restrictions decreasing from one to the next. While a young person might get a permit much earlier, he would, under this system, take two years to get a licence whereby he could drive without supervision and restrictions.

We should be backing our young drivers more effectively than we do at present and we should also be doing as much as we can to maintain and develop higher levels of driving skills amongst those who have gained their unrestricted licence. Government action though will never be enough. As I have said, it is not a matter of `they ought to', but a matter of `we as a community ought to'. Parents, schools and community groups have a vital role to play.

Mr Deputy Speaker, may I, in concluding, urge all members of this House to consider what I have said and to bring some pressure to bear on State governments so that a more imaginative and sensible system of driver training and licensing is introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) for bringing forward this motion. It proves to all Australians that we can agree on certain aspects and we do not argue the toss about the importance of road safety. It is pleasing to see the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) at the table and to see the Chairperson of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety, the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), and the Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), as members of that Committee. We do work in harmony and we do work to try to overcome the carnage on our roads in Australia. We all know that every day 10 people die as a result of road accidents. One in 10 is a motor cyclist, usually under the age of 21. So we have a massive problem and we have to work in concert with each other to try to overcome this massive problem. Some of the points that the honourable member for Hindmarsh made today-he is not a member of the Committee-prove that he does think about road safety, that he does come up with ideas. Hopefully some of those ideas will be implemented and will be a move towards overcoming the problem that we have.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety was set up by the House well before 1975, but I would like to list a few of the reports that have been handed down by the Committee since 1975. It is not a very fashionable Committee, Road Safety-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good committee.

—It is a good committee but it is not a very fashionable one in the eyes of some members of this House, and that is the point that I was going to make. A lot of honourable members seem to think it is far more fashionable to get on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence or some other committee that they think might be a leg up the ladder. But some members of the Committee have been with the Committee ever since they have been in parliament, for example, Bruce John Goodluck, since 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: Sometimes I think the work of the Committee is repetitive, sometimes I think `Oh, what is the heck of going over the same old ground all the time?' and then all of a sudden I get that resurgence of enthusiasm, knowing dashed well that what I am trying to do may save the life of some Australian. We all know the misery; we all know what occurs within a family when a person loses a loved one. So we have a job to do, and I congratulate the Minister for what he has been trying to do. He has given the Committee a lot of support. He comes to the meetings and he makes us feel that it is an important committee. And that is terribly important. All of us in this place like to feel important and just because we may not have the views of other people sometimes we think that that importance goes away like a leaf from a tree.

It is a good committee and we have gone through many aspects of road safety. I would like to mention a few of them. There was the passenger motor vehicle safety inquiry. Of course, the improvement of the motor vehicle has illustrated that some of those improvements have been brought into play, that recommendations have been brought down that have improved motor vehicle safety. It is up to every manufacturer to prove and make certain that he can improve the vehicle so that it is safe. Of course that does not take away the fact that there are many old cars on the road; many people cannot afford their motor vehicle for one reason or another-lack of finance, et cetera-and sometimes they allow that motor vehicle to deteriorate. All honourable members know the point that I drive at. So there is a problem with vehicle safety.

I am one of those who would like to think that every State in Australia has a means of checking vehicles every year. I know it is expensive. I know some States have it. But every vehicle in Australia should be checked every year to make certain that if it is changed from wider wheels to shorter wheels, or whatever, it is safe. The point is that it is important that we have safe vehicles on our roads so that we do not worry when we let our children go out in motor vehicles. Then it would not be an horrific thing when daughters or sons first get their licence and they go out at night, with the parents lying awake waiting for them to come home, waiting to hear that car come up the driveway, to know that they are safe. There are many problems associated with vehicle safety. We know that scales of economy are such that some people cannot afford a very good vehicle. They buy the cheapest vehicle possible to get them from point A to point B. We hope that we can improve safety by compulsory inspections.

In April 1977 we had a very involved hearing on heavy vehicle safety. Of course that is a very intricate one to look at because one needs to be a professional mechanic or engineer to make certain some of the modifications on those vehicles will be improvements, not just to make it safe for the driver but to make it safe for the person who may be coming in view of it. Of course we all read of the horrific crashes that occur with heavy vehicles. We brought down recommendations on motorcycle and bicycle safety in May of 1978, and many of those recommendations have been brought into play. There is a little bit of petty jealousy within the States and everybody likes to think that they did it; but we know that we brought down recommendations that some of the States have adopted. The Minister would agree that the Federal Government can only recommend to the States that they take up these good points. If they do not want to, the Government can only say to itself: `I wish to goodness that they would'. Some of them do not take it up because of their little jealousies and their little confines. That applies with many things in Australia-people are sometimes jealous to take up certain good points that the Federal Government may bring down, whether it be Labor or Liberal. The Minister knows the point that I drive at there. So we need to do a bit more work in that regard.

We need more uniformity in Australia so that when a person drives from one State to another, he has an idea of what the roads are like and what the rules are. I come from Tasmania, as all honourable members know, and many times in Tasmania I have watched certain vehicles-cars that are hired from Avis or Budget, or whatever-and of course the drivers do not know the roads in Tasmania; they do not know that some of them are very narrow; they do not know certain things about one-way streets. Sometimes I think it would be a dashed good idea if all cars hired in Tasmania had a different number plate. I always look at the back of a car to see whether it has a Qantas sticker or something else on the back to indicate that it is a hire car. If it had a different number plate-it would be very easy to implement-we would know that it was being driven by a stranger and we would know that he was having difficulty finding a street. Sometimes those difficulties of finding a street or finding a way can create a massive accident, and we have all seen that. So there is a suggestion that we may take on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good point.

—I am full of good points, that is the trouble with me. We had an in-depth inquiry into alcohol, drugs and road safety. We all know the recommendations and we hope that those recommendations will come into play and save lives on our roads, which is the important thing. Of course we also went into the tyre safety aspect and we found that the majority of tyres in Australia are safe; it is just that some of them are not being used correctly. Some people are lazy, some people do not want to pump them up and some people do not want to look at them, and of course expense comes into it in that some people cannot afford good tyres. But of course continuous road safety inspections would pick that up and that would add to the safety. I agree with the honourable member for Hindmarsh: If it were the Korean War or any other war and 3,000 Australians were killed, there would be banner headlines day after day, but because it is a road safety matter we take the numbers involved for granted. Sometimes we take those lives that are lost each day, the untold misery to their families and the cost to the community, for granted.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the motion of the honourable member for Hindmarsh. Whilst I am in the House I will be one who takes it on a bipartisan basis; I will always try to work with my chairman. Somebody said yesterday that I was against affirmative action. I say to Madam Chair, the honourable member for Lilley, that when the Committee has an inspection on balloons I hope she goes up in one and not me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) for opening up this discussion and giving us the opportunity in this House today to discuss the initiatives of the Federal Government in the area of road safety, a subject of particular interest and significance to members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety or Transafe. I would like to identify members of the Transafe Committee who work hard in the interests of safer roads in Australia, not all able to speak today but all ready and willing to do so and, more importantly, ready and willing to do the hackwork that goes into compiling reports and recommendations that will ultimately benefit people in Australia. The honourable member for Franklin, Mr Goodluck, the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, has already spoken, but also with us today is Mr Colin Hollis, the honourable member for Throsby; Mr Tony Lamb the honourable member for Streeton; Mr Alexander Downer, the honourable member for Mayo; Mr Russell Gorman, the honourable member for Greenway; Mr John Mildren, the honourable member for Ballarat and Mr Peter McGauran, the honourable member for Gippsland-all working across party political boundaries in the interests of road safety.

SPEECH.PARA: As Chairman of the Transport Safety Committee and its predecessor, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, since 1983 and recalling that period, I can state quite confidently that the present Government's commitment to road safety has been unswerving and its determination to analyse broad issues of safety has led to the introduction of a range of programs and initiatives that have contributed enormously to this important community issue.

No one could doubt the importance of road safety as an issue of concern. The honourable member for Hindmarsh has eloquently demonstrated his concern and the statistics which he has presented to this House are telling indeed. They tell a story of an Australian disease which claims lives and transforms, detrimentally, the lives of able-bodied young Australians, accounting for thousands of people becoming paraplegic every year. That disease is road trauma.

Maybe the most poignant statistic is that of road accidents being the single largest killer of children up to the age of 16 years. Road safety is a fundamental part of government policy at both the national and sub-national level. I am pleased to say that the commitment of this Government and in particular of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), who was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety before becoming Minister for Transport in this Government, has led to workable solutions to the complexities of this formidable problem.

While the problems of road safety are immense, the Government has accepted its legitimate responsibilities with a sense of purpose that has facilitated the effective promotion of safety and the conservation of our human and physical resources. This is evident in many current road safety trends. The number of fatalities per 10,000 vehicles fell by 21 per cent, from 4.3 in 1980 to 3.4 in 1985. Over the last decade this rate has halved to 3.2 persons per 10,000 vehicles, one of the lowest rates in the world. The number of fatalities per 100,000 population fell by 15 per cent, from 22.3 in 1980 to 18.7 in 1985. The proportion of road deaths involving blood alcohol levels above 0.05 per cent, one of the major factors in road deaths, has fallen from 44 per cent in 1981 to 36 per cent in 1984.

I am not suggesting for one moment that we should rest on the laurels of such encouraging trends because road safety remains one of the most serious problems facing the Australian community today. People continue to die on our roads in large numbers. Much more must be done and the buck stops not only with governments but with all Australians. I feel that under this Government we are taking steps in the right direction. These directions have been established to a large extent by the efforts of the Federal Office of Road Safety and the Department of Transport, already mentioned in the course of this discussion. The problem of road safety is being addressed through the resources of the Department and initiatives in this area are manifest in public awareness and education campaigns, formal discussion and consultation, research, funding of improved road works, and other measures, in an overall commitment to lessening the tragic hardship and waste of human lives caused by road accidents. Public awareness and education is one of the particular priorities of this commitment as the Government has recognised road user attitude and behaviour as one of the key aspects of road safety.

Attitude underlies safe driving. In this context several initiatives have been undertaken to promote principles of road safety among targeted groups. These targeted areas comprise those who are over-represented in road crash statistics, including young people, both young drivers and pedestrians, cyclists and road users under the influence of alcohol-one area which some people do not like to face up to but which statistics identify as the single largest identifiable cause of road fatalities.

The effect of road safety measures on the young has been of particular concern to the Government. In 1984, 357 children were killed on Australian roads and over 4,000 of these youngsters were seriously injured. Although the proportion of children killed on the roads is actually declining, thank God, there is a definite need to explore all possible means of road use education for the young. This is why the Government has introduced innovative educational schemes to alert children to the dangers of road use and to encourage safety conscious attitudes and behaviour. The bicycle helmet safety promotion using a popular youth figure, Molly Meldrum, is a perfect example of how selective publicity can be successfully used by governments and this particular initiative of the Government, the Office of Road Safety and Minister Morris, was an excellent one.

The Transafe Committee is now awaiting a response from the Minister for Transport to our report on the safety of bicycle helmets. One thing is certain: Use of a helmet by cyclists can save lives but parents should look for an Australian Standards Association approved helmet as some helmets on the market are little more than shoddy toys. There is another promotion I am particularly impressed by, that is, the Out and About campaign. It is targeted at school age children and incorporates principles of road safety and characterisations to which young children can relate. In recent years, the Federal Office of Road Safety has spent approximately $1m annually on road safety education and has ensured that this expenditure reflects the most effective use of the resources available through research of its programs. Other recent education and awareness programs include community liaison for safer road use by elderly pedestrians. That is another major risk group. Elderly pedestrians account for 37 per cent of all pedestrian fatalities. Included in these programs are motor cycle promotions, in co-operation with the rider associations, which have alerted motor cyclists to the dangers associated with a vulnerable means of transport offering little structural protection-another targeted area. The need to educate and publicise road safety has been evident in the Government's negotiations for advertising guidelines associated with vehicle use and road safety. This was one recommendation, by the way, of the Transafe Committee.

Mention of this point draws me to comment on the quality and frequency of consultations which have characterised the Government's road safety policy. I want to make it quite clear that the Transafe Committee which I chair is bipartisan; there are people from both Government and Opposition. But I believe credit is due here and it should be stated: There has been a mutually beneficial association between the Transport Safety Committee and the Government on a number of issues and the willingness to support or adopt the Committee's recommendations has added a positive perspective to a mutually shared commitment to the problem of road safety.

Consultation is an essential part of road safety policy as the effects of road accidents are felt by all sections of society. In implementing policies and programs the Government has undertaken wide-ranging consultation with governments, community groups, the police, trade unions, special interest groups, manufacturers, who come in really well, researchers and the media, all concerned and all consulting in an attempt to define accurately the most appropriate means of advancing road safety. This is the basis of our really finding an effective solution to this problem. It was exemplified by the National Road Safety Symposium. That was held in October 1984 here in Canberra and it drew a number of different people together. The same sort of consultation and comprehensive analysis will again be evident in the Bikesafe 86 campaign. A conference is planned for Newcastle in April next where the significant issue of bicycle safety will be discussed by a widely representative group.

In the area of road improvement and construction, I believe the Government's record has been remarkable. Federal road grants have increased by over 81 per cent since the last full year of the prior government and I think that really should be commented upon.

One thing I would like to see is the introduction of random breath testing in Queensland where, regrettably, the number of people being killed on the roads has increased a little this year. However, we in that State still hope that we will join other States which have introduced random breath testing.

In closing, I would like to make a personal comment regarding the need for a mature society, that is, parents, governments, and business people, to adopt responsible attitudes towards the up and coming generation. I quote what the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare said in its 1977 report, `Drug Problems in Australia':
Alcoholism among the young is increasing dramatically and as many as 10 per cent of school children between the ages of 12 and 17 get `very drunk' at least once a month.

Other statistics are that over one-quarter of a million Australians can be classified as alcoholic and one in every five of our hospital beds is occupied by a person suffering from the adverse effects of alcohol. I quote from an article in a magazine of the liquor trade in Britain, the Morning Advertiser, of 1978:
Ask most marketing men who they are aiming their drinks at and the answer will almost certainly be the young drinker. For some that age may reach as far as 30. For others it stops as low as 25.
But it all adds up to the same thing-a ready `target' who is willing to experiment with drinks and pay the price.
And if he--
that is, the average young drinker-
takes to drink in his youth there is always a good chance that he will stick with it as he grows older.
It is this new breed of drinkers who are changing the habits of a lifetime. It is they who have boosted wine sales to 10 bottles a head and lager to nearly a quarter of the total beer market.
And it is they who are now, albeit slowly, beginning to change the drinking pattern of spirits.
Statistics on drink driving and the number of people under 25 involved in accidents suggest to me that it is also they who are dying on our roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the member for Hindmarsh, Mr Scott, on bringing this motion forward in General Business and enabling some of us here in the House to say a few words on it. In congratulating Mr Scott I would also like to congratulate the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety on the excellent publications it has put out over the years and on the work it is doing for road safety throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some other people I would like to mention here because some of the members of the House may not know of other great work that has been done in an effort towards road safety. One member I would like to mention is Mr Tim Fischer, who is now the member for Farrer, but who was previously the member for Murray in New South Wales. Mr Fischer did a great amount of work, particularly in New South Wales and was one of those people responsible for the bringing in of random breath testing in New South Wales. Of course for that he received a great deal of flack from certain sections of the community. He weathered that and he was one of the major contributors there to saving lives in New South Wales. I am one of those people who believe that if random breath testing saves one life, it is worth having. So I congratulate Mr Tim Fischer on that. The Hon. Bob Katter, who has done so much in regard to road safety throughout Australia, also a-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Riverina-Darling will refer to members by their proper title.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for Kennedy has done a great deal of work throughout Australia in regard to road safety. Peter McGauran, of course, another National Party colleague, the member for Gippsland, who is on the Standing Committee at the moment and last but not least-
—I do not want to interrupt the honourable member again.
—The honourable member for Gippsland, Mr Deputy Speaker; and the honourable member for Gwydir, Ralph Hunt, who has-
—The title of the honourable member for Gwydir is either the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the honourable member for Gwydir, fullstop.

—The honourable member for Gwydir. I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker, I know these people rather personally. I bow to your ruling. I would like to make particular mention of the honourable member for Gwydir for he was the man who introduced the Australian bicentennial road development program which has done so much. I have worked for many years in the road design and construction field. I do not know of any project that has done so much for our road systems in Australia as that project has done and is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: My main reason for wishing to speak here today is that I am one of those members of the Parliament who travel anything from 50,000 to 100,000 kilometres a year in trying to cover the electorate so I would like to put to the Parliament some of my personal observations in that travelling. We all know, of course, that much more money has to be spent on roads. Certainly the bicentennial road development program is a great leap forward but it is still not good enough. In saying that, we must be realistic about the whole situation. Let us look at a section of road; for example, the State highway that has to be constructed from Ivanhoe to Booligal, which is in my electorate. To construct one kilometre of that road would cost approximately $250,000. The reason for this, of course, is that the road is so isolated that the materials that have to be put into the road construction have to be brought from great distances. We know that today the cost of fuel, the cost of labour and the cost of hiring machinery makes construction very difficult, so we find that price. One does not get many kilometres of road for $1m.

I draw honourable members' attention to the Hume Highway, for example, and in particular the Tumblong deviation, which is south of Gundagai. To construct one kilometre of dual carriageways there, which is part of the bicentennial program, would cost approximately $1.5m. So one can see the problems that governments face, both State and Federal, in trying to upgrade the roads system. I would say that $1.5m would be only a minute amount compared with the cost involved in building a system within the city of Sydney or the environs of Sydney. By the time one takes into account acquisition of land and property the cost would be much more than $1.5m. So it is important in the construction of these roads that we have the maximum amount of efficiency, not only from the machines but also from the people employed in that area. I am hoping that governments, both State and Federal, ensure that this is the case.

Looking at outback New South Wales, particularly in the Riverina-Darling electorate, we have many bad roads. These, I believe, are one of the major causes of road accidents in my electorate. We have the Rankins Springs to Lake Cargelligo road, which I have described on many occasions as a death trap. Something really has to be done about that because it has all the major features of those roads which cause the most accidents. It has bad sight distance; it has dips and curves; it has a bad road base; and after rain we have a great number of pot holes. It definitely is a disaster. The Booligal to Ivanhoe road is similar. The Broken Hill to Tibooburra road is not much better. The Cobar to Bourke, and Mossgiel to Hillston roads are similar. All these roads are in need of urgent attention. Of course we all know that the ultimate in road construction is to have a bitumen surface and, as I mentioned before, in some of those roads we are looking at about $250,000 a kilometre, so there is little hope in the future that they will be done in the short term. Some of the dangers on those roads include cattle grids and races, and animals-native fauna-crossing the roads. As a matter of fact, I have been told by one hire car company that I am not to call them; they will call me, because I have written off two cars in two weeks by hitting animals and other obstructions on the road. These are very real hazards on the road. I think that on many of these outback roads the only thing we can do in the short term is to fix the major trouble spots, the major safety problem areas, and hope that that will get us through until we can get these bitumen surfaces down.

I would like to mention a few of the problems I have noticed on roads, particularly bitumen roads. Some shires and some organisations repair the roads or reseal the roads and do not replace the centre line. I think that is a major hazard. I think the ultimate in road construction on a bitumen road is to have an edge line as well as a centre line. I am sure that this contributes to making the road very much safer. I noticed the other day in a newspaper in Wagga that the Finemores company has suggested that on the Hume Highway we have some warning to let people know that they are on dual carriageways. Sometimes, particularly on the Hume Highway where there are four lanes-two one way and two the other-we find that if they are not in sight of each other we forget whether we are on dual carriageways or single carriageways, and that can cause very serious accidents, particularly with the number of transports going up and down that highway.

The major thing I want to speak about here today is the problem of fatigue on our roads. I know that a lot of research has been done into drink driving on Australian roads, and I notice that an analysis was done in 1983 when the Committee commissioned research into the problems of road safety. A number of people were asked what they thought were the major causes of road accidents in Australia. I notice that eighth on the list is driver fatigue. Only 1.2 per cent of the people said that driver fatigue was a cause of major accidents. I would say that in outback New South Wales particularly in my area, a major cause of road accidents is fatigue. One sees accidents that just cannot be explained; where people are driving in one direction and all of a sudden they veer across the road in front of oncoming semi-trailers or buses or into each other or into trees. Recently there were four people killed in my electorate, and such accidents are almost a weekly occurrence. So I would ask the Government and the Committee in particular if they would take up this matter of fatigue on the roads. I know that alcohol is a problem but I think fatigue, when one is driving long distances-and Australia is a big country-is a major problem. Perhaps the community employment program grants we are looking at today would be a good way of obtaining some people to research this problem. Once again, congratulations to the Committee and to all those people who try to do something for road safety in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BALTIC STATES OF LATVIA, LITHUANIA AND ESTONIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
Noting that-
(a) the 3 Baltic States, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, were independent sovereign republics and members of the League of Nations from 1918 to 1940;

(b) in 1940, as a consequence of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact between the USSR and Nazi Germany, the 3 States were incorporated into the USSR by military force and in a manner which violated elementary principles of freedom, democracy and justice;
(c) like other democratic governments, Australia does not recognise de jure the incorporation of the Baltic States into the USSR;
(d) under Soviet rule, well-documented violations of human rights have occurred and continue to occur in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia-

(1) acknowledges the concern felt by members of the Australian community over the situation in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, particularly the repression of individuals engaging in the non-violent expression of their ethnic and cultural identity and religious convictions;

(2) commends the Government for its action in bringing this concern to the attention of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights at the Commission's meeting in March 1985 and invites the Government to continue to pay attention to this important issue;

(3) calls upon the Government of the USSR to end acts of repression against the Baltic peoples and to abide by the commitments which it has entered into under the various international covenants on human rights to which it is a signatory, and
(4) requests the Speaker to bring this resolution to the attention of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR.

The motion in many ways is self-explanatory and I doubt whether there would be many members of this House-or any members of this House-who would take objection to any part of the motion. I wish to amplify it significantly, and I think it is important for people on both sides of the House to express their support for it as they did, I think some two years ago, to a similar motion in the Senate. Because an amendment will be moved-as I understand it, notice has been given by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock)-I will refer to the amendment before I go further into the motion.

I regret that the Opposition is playing politics rather than giving maximum time to publicising the plight of the Baltic people, and for that matter, other inhabitants of the Soviet Union. We have, of course, brought the issue before the United Nations Commission on Human Rights and that is not referred to in the amendment proposed to be moved by a member of the Opposition. We have a lot of people, and not for the first time, on the Opposition side always talking about doing things about the Soviet Union but then never taking any stand on it. I remember well when the previous Prime Minister wanted to sell his wool and wheat to the Soviet Union while at the same time getting all rhetorical and paying lip service to the lack of democracy and the sorts of things that were happening in the Soviet Union. The same sort of thing happened back in about 1974-75 when an inquiry into human rights in the Soviet Union was set up for a Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs and Defence. The motion was moved in this House by a member of the then Opposition, but I think any person, even supporters of the Liberal Party, who looks at how that Sub-Committee went about its work would say that the then Senator John Wheeldon, Senator Sibraa, my close colleague the honour- able member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) and I were the backbone of that Committee and used to attend those Committee meetings, listen to the evidence, and do all the work. The Liberals never turned up. They just talked big about the Soviet Union. The Committee, in fact, held its hearings under the then Fraser Government, so the Liberal and National parties could have appointed a majority of members to that Committee. In fact it had a majority of Labor members. I emphasise that it not only had a majority of Labor members but a huge majority of Labor members amongst its active members.

The important thing to remember is that we on this side of the House are really concerned about freedom, unlike those on the other side who promise the world and then do nothing. I regret, because I consider myself fairly friendly with the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), that he has chosen today to take the line not, I assume, to oppose our final resolution when his amendment is defeated but to go to the extent of moving the amendment.

There are only two significant differences, as I see it, between our motion and the proposed amendment. One is the failure, I suppose, of the Liberal Party and Senate resolution to refer to what we have already done-that is, raise the issue-to refer to the promise that we would do so again at the current sittings of the Human Rights Commission, and to refer to an intensive process of Russification taking place in these occupied countries aimed at the elimination of the indigenous languages and culture. I think that our reference to the repression of individuals engaging in non-violent expression of their ethnic and cultural identity and religious conviction is really the same. We can argue about it, but I certainly would not go to the wall about it.

It is important for me, because I have been one of the people who have been active on this issue for many years, to emphasise my point of view-and it is not necessarily the point of view of all members of the Government-with regard to the Baltic States and many of the other problems concerned with the Soviet Union. Many of the objections to the Soviet Union are fairly nationalistic objections by ex-residents, for example, or by current residents, of course, of many of the Soviet republics. That is not my main objection. My main objection-and I consider it to be the main problem as far as the Soviet Union is concerned-is that the Soviet Union is a dictatorship. If the Soviet Union were run according to its own constitution, whilst the residents of the Baltic republics, the Ukranian republic or any of the other republics might still wish to secede, firstly, they would be able to do so under their own constitution and, secondly, they might wish-and I emphasise `might'-to remain part of a union of democratic republics. We know that the Soviet Union is currently run like Tsarist Russia. The only thing that has changed is a different jargon to justify imperialism. That is the great pity about what is happening in the Soviet Union.

I note the prominent members of the Baltic Council in the gallery of the House. I do not know what their view is on this, but it is my view that the best chance of getting freedom for the people of the Baltic States and, if necessary, for their national aspirations is to change the Soviet Union from a dictatorship to a democratic country. I am not suggesting for one minute that that is easy, but to my mind it would be easier to do that than to somehow persuade the current regime in the Soviet Union to give freedom to all the republics that currently make up the so-called Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

I wish to emphasise-I come back now to the Government's policy as distinct from my own views-that obviously the Government, unlike a previous Labor government which made a shameful decision never endorsed by either the parliamentary Party or the Party outside, would not recognise de jure the incorporation of the Baltic States into the Soviet Union. That was clearly and unanimously stated by the Federal parliamentary Labor Party. It is a matter which I know is of great importance to ex-residents of the Baltic States who are currently living in Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) asked me to convey a message on the occasion of the sixty-seventh anniversary of the Declaration of Independence of the Republic of Latvia in November last year. Inter alia, he said:

In my message of greetings to you last year, I undertook that the Government would raise before international bodies its concern at violations of human rights which continue, under Soviet rule, in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. The Australian representative did so before the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in March this year--
That is, last year-
in Geneva. The Government will continue to pay attention to this important issue.

I have been assured that, in fact, it will be raised again by our delegates at the Human Rights Commission, I think in March of this year. We have expressed those concerns, and I think it important that they keep on being expressed. We are also obviously concerned at the number of prominent Baltic dissidents who are in gaol or otherwise very unpleasantly dealt with by the Soviet Union. We have been extremely impressed by the action of Baltic organisations to mark the tenth anniversary of the Helsinki Accords. The Baltic peace and freedom cruise in July of last year and the tribunal held in Copenhagen were well attended and received widespread and very favourable publicity in international news media.

The Government, in its statement, also said that it supported the idea of bringing the concerns of the Baltic community before Parliament and that the Government's aim is to endorse these concerns and express its own position as clearly as possible without, however, raising unrealistic expectations about what might be achieved, for example, at the United Nations. Most of us are aware of what the numbers are at the United Nations. It is difficult to do anything at the United Nations which would significantly help the Baltic States. At the same time, it is my view that it ought to be raised continuously; it ought to be raised by our delegates to Inter-Parliamentary Union conferences; it ought to be raised by our delegates at other organisations. The main thing is to keep on pointing out to our own people, to people all over the world, that the Soviet Union is a dictatorship, that it is, I am afraid, an extremely nationalistic dictatorship and that that, in turn, creates nationalistic objections to that dictatorship.

I commend the motion to the House. I would be happier if we could have come to some agreement to make some mild amendments to the motion rather than have a vote on it, which would somehow imply that there is significant disagreement on the basic points, because I am sure that honourable members on both sides of the House feel very strongly about the basic points incorporated in our motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 109 as amended for this session, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the time for the discussion of Notice No. 3, General Business, be extended until 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, Mr Deputy Speaker. My time is very short. I would just like to make a few quick points. Whilst not going over what the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) said, it is worth noting that the Australian Government raised this before the United Nations Commission on Human Rights last year and intends to do so again this year, as emphasised by the letter of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 15 November that the honourable member for Prospect has just read out. It is around four-and-a-half decades since the three States of the Baltic area were overrun and we have seen the Russification of those three States ever since, with great pressure on their peoples, particularly in regard to social and cultural positions and their religious beliefs. It is a credit to the three nations of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia that they have kept their religious beliefs through great pressure and over the last four-and-a-half decades of oppression by the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government has made a number of high level representations to the Soviet Government on behalf of family reunion for residents of the Baltic States with relatives in Australia and we will continue to give priority to this matter, which we know is of great importance to the Baltic community in Australia. I have great pleasure in seconding the motion and recommend it to everybody in the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all the words after ``That'' (first occuring) be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``this House-
Having regard to-
(a) the desire of all people to live in peace and freedom and to enjoy basic human rights, including the right to self-determination;

(b) Australia's membership of the United Nations and regard for the principles of its Charter, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the United Nations Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples, adopted by its General Assembly on 14 December 1960 by resolution 1514 (XV) and the Final Act of the Helsinki Agreement, and
(c) the fact that, whilst the Australian people have acquired these rights and freedoms, other peoples are deprived of them, and
Noting that-
(d) the Resolution of the European Parliament on the Situation in the Baltic States was adopted on 13 January 1983;

(e) the 3 Baltic States were independent sovereign republics and members of the League of Nations during 1918 to 1940, when they were occupied by the Soviet Union in consequence of an agreement between the then German Government under Hitler and the Soviet Government under Stalin-the so called Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact;

(f) the occupation of these states by the Soviet Union still continues, but that in accord with other democratic governments the Australian Government has not recognised de jure their incorporation into the Soviet Union;
(g) the peoples of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are being denied many basic human rights but that they have not given up their struggle for self-determination and freedom, and
(h) an intensive process of ``Russification'' is taking place in these occupied countries aimed at the elimination of the indigenous languages and culture-
Resolves therefore that-

(1) Australia, as a member of the United Nations, fulfils its obligations to promote and encourage respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, and supports the European Parliament's Resolution in respect of the Baltic States;

(2) in order to do so, the Australian Government should, on its own initiative and by seeking the support of like-minded governments, bring the question of human rights and self-determination for the Baltic States before all appropriate forums of the United Nations, and especially before the United Nations Human Rights Commission, and
(3) the Department of Foreign Affairs be directed to take all necessary steps in order to implement this resolution''.

In relation to that amendment I would like to make some brief comments, firstly, to enunciate the reasons for supporting both the resolution and the amendment and, secondly, to give detailed reasons why the amendment should be preferred. Before I do that, I would like to thank my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) for making time available by deferring his motion in order that this important question could be discussed and for ensuring that this matter came on today. It has been listed for discussion since 23 May last year and it is terribly disappointing to many members on this side who have taken a long-standing interest in the Baltic question that time will not be available today for this matter to be given really the detailed and comprehensive discussion that it should have.

In relation to generally why the resolution and the amendment should be supported, I think it needs to be understood that each of the three Baltic countries has enjoyed freedom. Lithuania enjoyed it for most of the period after Christ, except for this century. It needs to be understood that each of those nations existed as separate states between 1920 and 1940. They were the subject of peace treaties in which the Soviet Union promised to respect their integrity forever. Of course, in 1939 Joseph Stalin and Adolph Hitler signed a non-aggression treaty and allotted the Baltic States into what was called the Soviet sphere. So when the Germans and the Russians were carving up the world at that time, and while world attention was focused on France and Germany, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics presented ultimatums to the Baltic States and then occupied each of those countries. Between 1940 to 1953, at various stages the Baltic people were subjected to war, mass deportations, imprisonment, executions and arbitrary terror. This had such a significant effect that 25 per cent of their populations were lost, and of the order of 14 per cent of that large number of people were the victims of Soviet executions, imprisonments and deportations.

It should be understood that there have been, as has been mentioned by honourable members opposite, significant denials of freedom in the Soviet Union, and particularly in the Baltic States. This remains a significant problem while each of those countries is denied national self-determination and independence. I think it needs to be understood that some of the specific rights that Soviet citizens are denied, particularly people in the Baltic States, are the right to emigrate and visit abroad, and the right to peaceful political opposition and peaceful assembly. There is an absence of independent mass media: All television and newspapers are substantially controlled by the state. There is an absence of an independent judicial system, with coercion by the state and the possibility of arbitrary arrest. There are no free trade unions. There is a ban on business activity and business ventures generally. There is censorship of the mail, art and literature. One political ideology dominates, that is, Marxist-Leninism, which we know has had such a significant impact and which intrudes into every area of teaching, whether it be medicine, engineering or whatever. Of course, religious practices are restricted.

As to compulsory military service, Balts in particular, as victims of Soviet aggression, have to undertake police action, as it would be termed I guess by the Soviets, in Czechoslovakia and also in Afghanistan today, many losing their lives as a consequence. In education we have seen a substantial indoctrination take place over time, with history being changed by the way in which the Soviets present it, particularly in relation to the occupation of the Baltic countries. We have seen also large scale immigration into areas of the Baltic States from the Soviet Union itself, such that in many of its cities no longer do the original population constitute a majority, but rather a minority of the inhabitants.

What are the grounds for supporting the amendment? The amendment, it needs to be understood, adopts the words precisely of the resolution carried unanimously, that is, with all parties' support, in the Senate on 28 February, 1985. The proposition can be seen to be the collective view of the Parliament only if it is carried in identical terms in the Senate and the House of Representatives. It also needs to be understood that the Soviet Union and its supporters might well read silent messages into the changed wording that has been used by the honourable member in his motion if we do not carry the amendment. I am concerned about the solace that the Soviets might find in the significant omissions in the motion drafted by the Government and proposed by the honourable member for Prospect.

What are the changes? Firstly, the preamble is deleted. It needs to be understood that the preamble uses words from paragraph 10.1 of the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence to which the honourable member for Prospect himself was a signatory. It abandons the linking of Australia to other international protests about the situation in the Baltic States. While the motion of the Government is used as a vehicle to commend it for raising this question before the United Nations Commission on Human Rights-and for this I too commend the Government-and is a far cry from the Whitlam Government's recognition of the incorporation of the Baltic States, it nevertheless offers no continuing commitment and direction to Australia's Government to continue to raise this question before the United Nations generally and the Commission on Human Rights. The Government's reason for supporting this watered down resolution is hard to understand, given the assurance by the honourable member for Prospect today and in the message of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Latvian community that this matter would be one of continuing attention for the Government.

Finally, I want to make this point: The final and most significant difference is the deletion of the notation of the intensive process of Russification taking place in the occupied Baltic States aimed at eliminating their indigenous language and culture. Given the Government's commitment to multiculturalism in Australia, one can only assume that its deletion of comment on the process of Russification coupled with only a vague reference to a concern about repression of ethnic identity and cultural identity, was effected to signal a lack of concern on the Government's part about the concept of Russification. It is not as if the honourable member for Prospect is unaware of this issue. He was a party to the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee report which I cited earlier and which at paragraph 4.30 concluded particularly-I will not read the whole quotation-that to a large degree the impact on minority cultures was due to the steady Russification of the non-Russian Soviet Socialist Republic. It is not as if the Government was unaware of the concern of the Baltic communities at this watered down proposal of the Government. The Baltic Council of Australia has had continuous contact with the Government and has put its view to it. The Council's view is that, while matters covered by the motion of the honourable member for Prospect are commendable, the form of resolution adopted by the Senate is preferable for its more detailed preamble and its stronger commitment to future activity by the Government. I put it strongly as possible that the reasons I have advanced should cause all honourable members to support the amendment and to carry it today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I am honoured to second the amendment moved by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock).

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I support the motion moved by the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman). Let me make a few observations on the remarks by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock).
