INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling on questions without notice, I have to advise the House that the standard of behaviour over the past few days from both sides of the House leaves much to be desired. Yesterday's Hansard will explain exactly what I mean. In my acceptance speech to this office I made a call to all members to lift the standard of debate and behaviour in this House. Regrettably, not all members have seen fit to accept this advice. Parliamentary politics is tough and tough things will be said in the heat of debate. Honourable members recognise and expect this. While remarks may be made about a member politically, I will not tolerate, from either side, allegations or imputations of a personal nature, particularly remarks or interjections which go into the private lives of members.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Chair is particularly concerned about interjections, which often it cannot hear, and appeals to members, again, to exercise their individual responsibility to the House by lifting their behaviour and observing the standards which are expected within the House. Many members of this House have expressed their respect for the institution of parliament, for the Standing Orders and for the position of Speaker. I suggest they now put that respect into practice and avoid bringing the House into disrepute.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the honourable gentleman to his recent and highly publicised visit to three rural families in Australia. In view of the parlous economic plight facing rural Australia, is it fair that farming families such as those he visited should be forced to pay a 3 per cent productivity payment into a union controlled fund under the backroom deal made between his Government and the ACTU?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The families I visited-and I guess they are the ones best placed to make a judgment about the worth of the visit-were kind enough to say to me directly that they appreciated the fact that I had come to visit them. From my point of view I certainly found the visit informative. It fleshes out the bare bones of the statistics that come across one's desk in terms of national aggregates. As the matter has been raised, I express my appreciation for the way in which those people were prepared, willingly and quite directly, to share with me their exposition of the difficulties of the rural sector as those difficulties affected them personally. When these matters come before the Cabinet, my consideration of them will be enhanced as a result of the visits I paid to those people.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the substance of the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition, let me make the point that, as usual, coming from him and those opposite is a quite hopeless analysis of the impact on the rural sector, in particular, and the economy generally, of aspects of this Government's economic policy in the wages and conditions area. I point out that under this Government the rate of increase in rural costs faced by farmers has decreased significantly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—Honourable members opposite can guffaw. Unfortunately as in so many areas of economic analysis, they are incapable of reading and understanding statistics. The fact is that the rate of growth of farm costs was significantly greater in the period when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer than it has been under this Government. The rate of increase in farm costs under the previous Government averaged 12.2 per cent per annum. Up until this year it has been of the order of 7 per cent under this Government. One of the reasons why the rate of inflation and the rate of increase in farm costs has diminished significantly under this Government, as compared with our predecessors, is the prices and incomes accord and the way in which we have been able to get a more sensible outcome in the area of wages and conditions of employment than emanated from the free-for-all nonsense that was espoused by honourable members opposite when in government, from which experience they have not learnt and which they would seek to visit upon this community again. Fortunately, whilst those opposite have not learnt from their ineptitude, the people of Australia have.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Commerce and Technology to the bid by the Bell Resources Group for control of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the possibility that this could mean a transfer of ownership of the Australian steel industry. Can the Minister say whether the Government is concerned about the consequences for the steel industry plan? Is the Minister aware that there is widespread fear across the whole community of Whyalla of this proposed takeover? What can the Government do to safeguard the interests of those employed in the steel industry, particularly those in Whyalla?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Grey is notable for his advocacy of issues affecting his electorate, and I visited Whyalla with him only a short time ago. The Government is monitoring very closely the details of the Bell Resources Ltd partial takeover bid for BHP. The issue is primarily, at this stage, for the shareholders of BHP. As the Prime Minister has made clear, we are concerned that, in the event of a successful takeover bid by Bell Resources, the future viability of the Australian steel industry and the job security of its employees, including the employees at Whyalla, are maintained. A major concern in this matter is the integrity of the steel industry plan, which incorporates a commitment by government to provide assistance by way of bounties and the safety mechanism, commitments by unions on wages, productivity and dispute settlements, and commitments by industry on an investment program and job security. To date, the steel plan, promoted by my colleague Senator John Button, has been outstandingly successful. The Government is committed to the future of the steel plan and to the honouring of commitments of all parties, including industry, under the plan.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Button has met with Mr Holmes a Court, who has said that he is very interested in developing the steel industry with new processes and technology. He has indicated to Senator Button that his bid should not be seen as a threat to the industry or to its employees. It is too early to make a more definitive statement on this matter. However, I repeat: The Government is monitoring the situation closely and will have continuing dialogue with both parties concerning development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Attorney-General confirm that, after the enactment of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, the Government intends to request the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission to inquire into all State electoral laws, including the electoral laws of Western Australia, and to legislate under the external affairs power to override those electoral laws if they do not comply with the Bill of Rights?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present position is that the Bill of Rights Bill is before the Senate and the Australian Democrats have indicated that they want an assurance from the Government as to its intention should the Bill be passed in its present form. The Government is anxious that the Bill be passed in its present form. Accordingly, it has always said-as is a matter of record in an answer to a question asked last year by a member from Western Australia-that if the Commission found that the electoral distribution in Australia contravenes the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the State concerned was not prepared to amend its electoral distribution, the Government would legislate pursuant to the external affairs power. That is a matter of record. To that extent, I am concerned to think that the Democrats are still asking for an assurance from the Government that if they pass the Bill we will proceed along that course. It is a matter of record. So at present the position has not changed.
—What about the Senate?

—The Government has the difficulty of not having the numbers in the Senate. That is its position. The Senate is asking for an assurance on a matter on which the Government has already given an assurance. It is a matter of ordinary intelligence to realise that if we pass legislation pursuant to the International Covenant, which we are endeavouring to do, and creating a commission to monitor that legislation, which is part of the package, and if the Commission, in the course of its normal duty to police the Covenant, finds that the electoral distributions in Australia are contrary to the principles of the Covenant, of course there would be a report to this Government and we would need to act accordingly.
—Would you legislate then?
—The only way to do that would be to legislate pursuant to that provision.
—So you would legislate then?
—We would legislate pursuant to that provision. That would apply in the normal sense as to the distribution we were talking about.
—And other laws contravening the Covenant?

—No, I gave an undertaking to the State Attorneys-General last year when I gave them the draft Bill, which I think was on 2 May, that the Bill would not apply, in the overall aspects of the law, to State administration. Honourable members know that the Bill is drafted that way. However, at all times there is a provision in the Bill that the Acts and practices of the States will be the subject of investigation by the Commission. We are talking about the obligation of the Government to an international covenant. I remind the honourable gentleman, as he would know from when he was in government, that it was his Government that acceded to the International Covenant and created the Human Rights Commission. That is the present position. It would be a bit of a sham if we did not give the Commission some teeth to work out whether the Acts, practices and laws of Australia complied with the International Covenant.

ANSWER.PARA: In summary, the honourable gentleman knew what I would say, but I am thankful that he asked the question because, apparently, the Democrats are not prepared to accept the Government's view, which is a matter of record. A government does not legislate to introduce a national covenant and then walk away from its responsibilities-not at all. As a matter of interest, I hope that the people of Queensland start to express a view as to what they think ought to be their rights when it comes to having a State election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Special Minister of State tell the House what role market research plays in the work of the Australian Electoral Commission? Is such research a valuable aid to the work of the Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to confirm to the House that market research has been a very valuable tool in the work of the Electoral Commission since it has been established. Two major surveys have been carried out by the Commission since its establishment. One has been held recently-since the election-on the Senate ballot paper. We would hope that the results would be of particular relevance to any future elections in overcoming any problems that may have been faced by electors at previous elections. The other survey related to difficulties that may have been experienced in the various electorates. The surveys are also of very valuable use to the Commission in ensuring that all citizens take part effectively in the electoral process.

ANSWER.PARA: Market research is so much a part of our lives, not only for the Electoral Commission but also in politics generally. I noticed a bit of research that was published yesterday in reference to Australian politics. It is becoming increasingly accurate. The Leader of the Opposition is now held in favour by 22 per cent of the electorate as against 42 per cent when he was first elected leader. The popularity of the honourable member for Kooyong has jumped from 22 to 29 per cent since he lost the job of Leader of the Opposition. Malcolm's popularity has jumped from 12 to 17 per cent since we gave him a job. The popularity of the honourable member for the Northern Territory has jumped by one per cent since he shifted. The popularity of the honourable member for Goldstein has jumped by 100 per cent-from one to 2 per cent-since he was demoted. The popularity of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party has gone down by 100 per cent-from 2 to one per cent-since he was promoted.

Mr Elliott now has the support of one per cent of those surveyed and he would like to thank the board of Elders IXL Ltd for its continued loyalty. Mr Hodgman has the support of one per cent of the electorate and he would like to thank his brother and his father. Here is the coup de grace of the market research surveys which are having so much impact on our lives, and it may cause some disturbance to honourable members sitting in the chamber, both to those on this side as much as to those on the other side. The survey shows that if anything unfortunate should happen to our Prime Minister-God help us-the Deputy Prime Minister, the Treasurer, the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the Premier of New South Wales, I am next in line. I do not know what Gareth thinks about this. I thank the honourable member for Melbourne for his question and I hope that I have enlightened him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the capital gains tax which has been operative since 19 September last year and which is already seriously affecting the investment decisions of ordinary Australians and their families. I ask this question so that he will explain his policy in this area. If a family farm was owned by a trust prior to 19-

QUESTION.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —These matters are affecting families at this moment and we require an answer. If a family farm was owned by a trust prior to 19 September 1985 and a child is subsequently appointed as a discretionary beneficiary, will the child acquire an asset that will come under the capital gains tax? If so, how will this discretionary interest be valued?

—I do not intend to answer similar questions but I will give the honourable member an answer on this occasion because obviously, as I have indicated, much of the detail of the balance of the tax package pre-legislation is still in the course of being considered. The Business Council of Australia is meeting with the Department of the Treasury today.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—There is no point of order. I am giving an answer.
—Will the honourable gentleman resume his seat. The Treasurer is answering the question.

—The answer is in the affirmative-yes. A capital gains tax will apply on any discretionary interest or any new interest in a trust and that interest would be a proportion of the value of the current market price of property. In other words, that amount would be assessed. Of course there would be no capital gains tax to pay until there was a built-up interest in the property. Of course that would be after the indexation of inflation was adjusted so that tax was paid on the real gain. The more general point is that if there were the purchase of an element of what was an exempt property prior to 19 September 1985, that would be capital gains taxed.

—Will the Special Minister of State comment on the final outcome on the Scullin by-election as announced by the Australian Electoral Commission? Has further analysis been carried out on the results of the Western Australian election?
—What about the Tasmanian one, Mick?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask me a question about it, Bruce. That is what you are here for. I will write it for you. The Australian Electoral Commission has announced final figures for the Scullin by-election. The new member for Scullin received 73.17 per cent of the two-party preferred vote, a very commendable result by any standards. The swing against the Government in this by-election was 4.46 per cent. This is hardly a remarkable result for the Opposition. According to figures supplied by the Parliamentary Library, the average swing against the government of the day in by-elections has been 3.4 per cent. The average swing in by-elections against the Hawke Government has been 2.3 per cent. Against the Fraser Government it was 3.4 per cent in spite of such outstanding results as those obtained by the honourable member for Lowe, who had a swing of 8.5 per cent and the honourable member for Werriwa who had a swing of 11.9 per cent. In addition, we have substantially reduced the informal vote in the by-election compared with that at the 1984 general election.

ANSWER.PARA: The first analysis that presented the result of the Western Australian election as a rural revolt against the Australian Labor Party has not been borne out by any later examination. Rather, it was a rural revolt against the Liberal Party of Australia. The total ALP vote in farming seats rose slightly, whereas the Liberal vote in those seats fell by over 10 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his Government's economic trilogy. Is it true that the trilogy permits the Government to keep tax revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product at 25.3 per cent, the highest peacetime rate ever and considerably higher than the average of 23.8 per cent during the seven years of the former Government?

—A statement regarding the trilogy has been made on several occasions and I think it is quite clear. The Government has undertaken that the deficit, as a proportion of GDP, will not rise. I simply again make the point to the House that I made yesterday. The people of Australia do not see this as something esoteric and assisted in any way by such silly questions as this one from the Leader of the Opposition. They simply look at the fact that before we came to office there was a Treasurer-he is now the Leader of the Opposition-who had absolutely no sense of fiscal responsibility and who, in a desperate attempt to hang on to office, allowed the deficit to blow out. We inherited the situation where the deficit, as a proportion of GDP, was 5 per cent. We have successively, by careful and responsible economic management, brought down that figure to where in 1985-86 the deficit, as a proportion of GDP, is 2.1 per cent. We will continue the responsible economic management of this country which has transformed it from the worst economic recession in 50 years to the most prosperous economy in the Western world.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. Can the Minister inform the House of the increased consumer and community participation in his Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Representations were made to the Commonwealth Department of Health in May 1985 for a review of community participation in the Department. In response to that, a committee was set up involving community representation. It has now produced a report to the Department which recommends access by the community, consumer and user groups to decision-making within the Commonwealth Department of Health in areas including policy, research priorities, budget allocation and regulatory and legislative changes.

ANSWER.PARA: This review also recommended the formation of a health forum, the membership of which would be open to all community organisations with an interest in health issues. The activities of this health forum would be co-ordinated by a core group of 16 organisations. This core group would meet four times a year and would have the responsibility once every two years of bringing together a whole meeting of the health forum and keeping the other member organisations informed. I think it is important to note that the report recommended that the Department review the relevance of all committees and working parties with a view to discarding any that did not have an important and useful role. Certainly that recommendation has my strong support. These recommendations are now before the Government and we will be coming up with a specific response to them.

At this stage I anticipate real benefits from increased community participation in the working of the Department. First of all, for the first time it would give an effective community voice on health issues to balance the views of the profession, government and industry, all of which are well represented within the Department. Secondly, I think that more effective programs and services will be produced if decision-making is informed of community needs. Thirdly, I think that a more informed community would lead to improved understanding of the difficult decisions that governments have to make in the health areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications. In view of the importance and great value of regional television to non-metropolitan viewers and advertisers throughout Australia, will the Minister tell the House what action he is taking to save Australian regional television from being gobbled up by the Packer and Murdoch media monsters and spat out again as mere relay stations for major metropolitan networks?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. As he is probably aware, the first commitment of this Government in broadcasting is to the equalisation of broadcasting services, particularly in regional areas. At this stage how that will come about is, in fact, yet to be finally considered by Cabinet. However, I think it is reasonable to say that the justifiable concerns expressed today by the honourable member on behalf of regional television have been represented more than adequately on behalf of regional television by Regional Television Australia. Any decisions this Government reaches in relation to this matter will take all of those matters into account.

—My question is to the Minister for Defence. I ask: On what basis was a decision made to close the Albion explosives factory? What is the likely future for the workers who will be displaced from the factory and what benefits will flow to the local community from the eventual release of the factory land for redeployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. The decision to close the Albion ammunition factory is related entirely to establishing a more effective production of explosives and ensuring an efficiency in government factories, which I would have thought would be a position shared on both sides of the House. As it happens, it appears that that is not a position shared on both sides of the House. Some quite ignorant and untoward criticism was made of the honourable member for Calwell during the course of remarks in a grievance debate last week and I think also in some public comment in that regard. It seems passing strange that, having been thrown into confusion on the question of privatisation, our opponents now appear to want to cross all the way over and will not permit us to establish effective and efficient production in government-owned factories. The Opposition has gone right across the board.

ANSWER.PARA: There were several factors involved in the decision. That was one of them. The fact that the decision has been taken will open up substantial opportunities to the communities in both the electorate of the honourable member for Calwell and the electorate of the honourable member for Lalor. This decision has been very much welcomed by them. They both brought a delegation to me this week and I was able to give some assurances on opportunities that would be available to develop parts of the area for community use and also to put a road through, which will be of some considerable convenience. I did point out at the time, however, that those developments will have to be carefully paced because they must move in accordance with other developments that will take place, both at the factory at Maribyrnong and at the factory at Mulwala, because we are not going to place ourselves in a position where, were an emergency to occur over the next few years, an essential element of production would not be possible as a result of one element being closed down at Albion in advance of it actually being opened at one of the other two sites.

The honourable member has been diligent in his concern for the workers at the factory at Albion. Some 210 workers are affected. Forty-odd of those workers will continue to be employed at the factory site for maintenance and other purposes while it is being run down. The rest will very quickly be able to take up positions at Maribyrnong, Mulwala or one of the other government factories in the immediate vicinity which employ several thousand people. These opportunities will arise for them. Of course, in these circumstances there are always cases in which a worker may well not want to shift. In those circumstances, even though we feel that we will be able to find alternative employment, we are holding discussions with the unions and with the Australian Council of Trade Unions to ensure that appropriate termination arrangements are met.

The decisions this Government has taken will result in efficiencies in those areas-efficiencies which have been sought repeatedly, I might say, by parliamentary committees. They are going to be achieved with considerable difficulty in some circumstances and with sensitivity in all circumstances. However, our objective is to ensure that production in government factories is as efficient and as effective as possible, while always recognising that factories which form substantially a part of the reserve of what we might require in wartime are not going to achieve totally commercial standards, in regard to anything. However, that is still no excuse for not addressing a requirement for efficient production. I am glad that there remain at least a few people on this side of the House concerned about that, even if the concern does not spread across to the other side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister aware that the Fleet Air Arm Museum has many extremely rare and valuable aircraft which are currently based at HMAS Albatross at Nowra and are left out in the open where they are slowly rusting away? Is the Minister aware that these extremely rare and irreplaceable pieces of Australia's aviation history have absolutely no protection from the weather and that, despite constant attempts to have an appropriate hangar built, this Government continues to ignore the needs in regard to these valuable pieces of Australia's history?

—I am aware of the circumstances to which the honourable gentleman draws my attention. It would be extremely difficult to find a defence justification for constructing a hangar for those purposes. However, I think those aircraft are an important part of our national heritage and need protection. I am hopeful that, when decisions are ultimately taken on the Maritime Museum and the Aviation Museum, in one or both of those places an appropriate place will be found for those aircraft. There has been some expression of interest in the aircraft by private people. I will look into the matter again, on the basis of the interest shown by the honourable gentleman, to see whether we can do anything in the interim. I approach it from the point of view that we do not have all that much money to fling around in the Department of Defence. We have to be reasonably careful and selective about how we expend it to ensure that it is done effectively. Again, I qualify that by saying that the matter of ensuring that a very important part of our military history is preserved is also of some significance.
—Has the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs noted a report that the Imam of the Lakemba Mosque, Sheikh Al Hilaly, is due to leave Australia by the end of February? Is the report correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted the report and it is correct. Sheikh Al Hilaly arrived in Australia in 1982 on a three-month visa. He has had his visit extended four times by various Ministers from both sides of politics. The Sheikh applied for resident status in November 1984. In considering his application I had particular regard for two of the basic principles of our immigration policy, which has been developed by governments from both sides of this Parliament. First, it is fundamental to national sovereignty that the Australian Government alone should determine who will be admitted to Australia. No person other than an Australian citizen has a basic right to enter our country. Secondly, policy governing entry and settlement is based on the premise that migrants should integrate into Australian society.

ANSWER.PARA: For a number of reasons, I decided that the Sheikh's resident status application should be refused and that he should leave at the termination of his present temporary entry permit, which terminates at the end of this month. I made this decision recently after the most thorough review of all the factors over the Christmas period. The Sheikh has given me a written undertaking to leave Australia voluntarily by 28 February. He has subsequently assured me personally on two occasions that the commitment will be honoured should his resident status application be refused, as it has been. I expect him to honour his word and leave Australia by tomorrow week-Friday, 28 February.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. It is allied to that asked today by the honourable member for Cowper. I refer to the Minister's statement on the Government's announcement that it will introduce supplementary television and radio licences. Is it still the Government's first and preferred option to continue with this scheme? If not, is the Government prepared to continue with the present monopoly policy in some radio and television markets? If so, will he pay compensation to the many small companies that have invested hundreds of thousands of dollars in research and for applying for and showing interest in supplementary television and FM radio licences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member will be aware, the supplementary licence scheme was the policy of the previous Government and was endorsed by this Government. However, over the past year or a little longer the initial enthusiasm of the industry for the supplementary licence proposals has waned, to say the least. I well recall that in the early days of this Government there was a very strong view within the industry that this Government should endorse the policy of supplementary licences-which we did-and proceed forthwith. However, that does not seem to be the position within the industry at this stage. In relation to television particularly, one of the concerns which the industry started to feel very strongly arose as a result of the Perth hearing, which has been dragging on, as the honourable member will be aware, for a long while. As a result we have looked at the hearing procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in an attempt to solve some of those difficulties. I think that will be achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: However, which way we should proceed on supplementary licences, and particularly on the issue which is central to the honourable member's point-the role of independent applicants-is currently being examined by the forward development unit within the Department of Communications. It will come back to me, as the Minister, not with recommendations but with options. The problems that the honourable member has raised in his question are real because the independent applicants are concerned. Their representations have been put very strongly by the organisation FM Applications for Independent Radio Inc., FAIR, which is known to the honourable member. They are being considered in the overall context of broadcasting policy. On the other hand, representations from the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, FARB, are equally as strong in the radio area. That matter relates to a problem of the availability of FM frequencies, for existing AM operators as well as independents. All the matters raised by the honourable member are under consideration. I can add very little at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of an article by journalist Peter Costigan which appeared in yesterday's Melbourne Herald and which suggests that the Australia Card proposal would include a huge centralised computer containing personal data under, as he states, `the secret care of the bureaucracy'? Can he inform the House what the effect would be of adopting Mr Costigan's undoubtedly expert advice that the Australia Card would not be necessary if the Government were to make tax returns public documents? Does such a system operate in Sweden, as Mr Costigan suggests, and with what success?

—I take a point of order. Again, Madam Speaker, I draw your attention to standing orders 142 and 143, which specify that questions asked of a Minister must relate directly to his portfolio. When some journalist writes something, the Minister is not responsible for that.
—Order! The Minister for Health is responsible in this area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the article to which the honourable member for Fowler refers. Unfortunately, it typifies a number of articles written in the Press which do not seem to face up to the intellectual challenge presented by the Government in the very full reports which have now been widely distributed. It seems to me that, if people are to engage in worthwhile debate on this admittedly complex issue, those sorts of arguments have to be addressed. For instance, the Australia Card proposal will not result in the creation of a huge central database. I have assured members of the House and Australian citizens time and time again that there is no proposal to create a single information file on citizens. Nor, as alleged in the article, will there be any unrestricted access by legions of bureaucrats to the register of the Australia Card. Insofar as clerks will have access to this material, it will be simply for identifying information such as name, address and Australia Card number. That will be simply as a check on similar information provided to those clerks in offices around the country. We have made it very clear in the Government report that there is no intention of breaching individuals' privacy. In fact, with the introduction of the Data Protection Agency, we are offering better protection for privacy in relation to computer files than anything available in this country at the moment. Indeed, that Data Protection Agency is modelled on the Swedish model-it is very interesting that that is not referred to in the article but there are numerous references to Sweden-and there it has proved extremely effective over a much wider range of computer files than simply those held by government. It is true, as Mr Costigan has said, that Swedish taxpayers do have a reputation as a pretty honest taxpaying nation and their tax returns are publicly available. But he did not mention that Sweden has a most sophisticated national identification system which allocates a unique identification number from birth in that country. That means that in Sweden the tax board is effective because those numbers are used throughout the system. In fact the Swedes do not have in effect to lodge tax returns because their income from all sources is identified through the use of that single identification number.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I believe that Mr Costigan's most revolutionary suggestion that we would solve most of our tax and welfare fraud problems by making tax returns publicly available, as happens in Sweden, is a nonsensical suggestion. If a person failed to declare bank interest or a dividend payment or other payments, the public availability of the tax return would do nothing to deal with those sorts of problems unless, of course, it is suggested that the banks and other financial institutions should be turned into institutions responsible for tracing tax in that way. The Government accepts the responsibility for tracing taxes. It needs that kind of number to do it effectively.
