SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In May last year, I made a statement in this House on Australia's Trade Situation and Policies, accompanied by a Department of Trade background paper entitled `Australia's Trade Performance and Prospects'. The fundamental situation outlined in that statement and background paper has not changed. The terms of trade have been moving steadily against commodities over a long period and Australia is a commodity dependent exporter. Since then the international trading environment, particularly for agricultural commodities, has deteriorated further. At the moment there are particular difficulties which substantially reflect the market distortions generated by the European Economic Community's common agricultural policy practices and the accompanying surpluses of beef, sugar, cereals and dairy products that have found their way onto an already overcrowded world market. Markets have been further weakened by the reactive subsidies enacted by the United States Congress. Such a situation with its misallocation of resources is not desirable either for the world economy in general or efficient producing countries in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand we must learn to adapt to market realities by seeking through our trade and industrial policies to alter our trade mix. On the other, we must seek to reform the rules of international trade so that they provide the same basis of fair play for our existing agricultural commodities as applies in manufactures trade. The largest and most serious deficiencies in the operation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are in agricultural trade.

My visit to Europe and the United States of America was particularly timely in enabling me to put squarely Australia's grave concerns about the world-wide developing crisis in agriculture. In addition to pressing for urgent and aggressive reform of agricultural policies, particularly the common agricultural policy, my intent was to emphasise the need for subsidies and protective barriers in agriculture to be tackled as a prime objective in the new round of multilateral trade negotiations.

The new round of multilateral trade talks provides the Government with a valuable chance to focus attention on the current bias in the rules against agricultural trade. We can encourage a climate of opinion that facilitates structural adjustment and reduced protectionism. It also provides an opportunity to create conditions for improved export performance in the fastest growing areas of world trade-manufactures and services-concomitant with the Government's industry and trade policy objectives, and to reduce the structural distortions plaguing commodity markets. I received full support from the United States Special Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter for making agriculture a prime objective in the new round. We and the United States agree that the GATT disciplines in respect of subsidy practices, particularly export subsidies, must be significantly improved. The United States Administration is determined that real trade liberalisation in agriculture is at last addressed in a substantive way. In turn this will enable the Administration to repel those forces in the United States Congress who want to fight the EC subsidies fire with fire to the overall detriment of us all.

In discussing these issues in Europe with EC Commissioner for External Relations and Trade, Will De Clercq, I stressed our concerns at the distortions resulting from common agricultural policies now evident in agricultural commodity trade and our concerns at the growing use by the US and the EC of competitive subsidies. I pressed him for more urgent review and reform of their common agricultural policies, emphasising our disappointment at their failure to make any substantive reforms to these policies in their recent reviews of sugar and dairy policies. I took the opportunity to reinforce these views in my discussions with Trade, Industry and Economic Ministers in Spain and Portugal, the two newest members of the Community. Indeed, Spain has become the fifth largest member of the 12.

The European Community's agricultural policies have had particularly debilitating effects on developing country agricultural producers. Although some receive access for significant amounts of their products, the price depressant effects of dumped EC surplus production on world markets destroys overall export earnings of these countries. For debtor nations the dilemma is very real. In the face of declining earnings their ability to import declines. The pressure to restrict their imports increases. Protectionist and discriminatory non-tariff barriers among major industrialised countries to their trade in manufactures further reduces their ability to improve their standard of welfare. The deepening crisis will turn the attention of these developing countries to searching for a better way to organise world trade-fairer rules, fewer subsidies-and the need to make a concentrated effort to convince the older industrialised countries of the real need for reform.

The recent Bureau of Agricultural Economics study on the effects of the common agricultural policy make it plain that the costs of the policy to Europe in terms of lost employment and growth opportunities are such that they should share our desires for reform. We will continue to highlight these facts. In recent discussions with the National Farmers Federation I suggested that industry groups must also carry forward the initiatives the Government has taken to publicise amongst European consumers the burdensome costs of their agricultural support policies. For the first time in over 20 years it may now be possible to tackle agricultural trade problems constructively. Only by generating within the EC and globally recognition of the deleterious effects of the CAP will be able to achieve a change in views on subsidy practices. In the months ahead we will be working closely with the United States Administration, with affected developing country agricultural exporters and with countries in our own region to ensure that the mandate for a new negotiating round adequately addresses agriculture and trade liberalisation.

Getting the issues into the open and on to the negotiating table is only a first step. We will have set the stage for a broad-based negotiation on access, subsidies and non-tariff barriers that will improve the world trading environment. But the going will be extremely tough. It is completely unrealistic to imagine that the distortions in world agricultural trade can be wiped out overnight or that radical change in the direction of the common agricultural policies will be easily achieved. Such an approach offers the prospect of replacing the threat of trade and subsidy wars with detente and mutual reduction of the arsenal of trade barriers and subsidy distortions-and the prospect of greater prosperity for all trading nations.

Both US Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter and the Director General of GATT, Arthur Dunkel, share my view that we must be aggressive and creative in seeking to strengthen both the rules and the GATT institution itself. This is essential if we are to reverse the self-seeking protectionist policies that have become so much the mark of international trade practice over recent years. I believe I have developed an atmosphere within which co-operation to secure these goals will be a major element of the current Preparatory Committee discussions in Geneva. Such objectives require full and vigorous participation by all trading nations-something that Australia has not always been prepared to undertake in previous negotiating rounds. The Government has committed itself to the gradual reduction of industry protection levels in key industries as part of our strategy to secure an efficient, competitive and expanding manufacturing sector. While these policies stand on their merits they also provide us with more scope to obtain real benefits in a negotiating round.
United States Farm Program

A crucial point in the subsidy battle has been reached with the enactment of the new farm legislation which mandates subsidy expenditures on a range of agricultural products vital to Australia. These developments made it imperative to register our concerns at ministerial level and press the Administration to minimise the impact of these programs on Australian export markets. This was the purpose of my visit to Washington. These personal ministerial representations have been reinforced by letters from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and myself to the Secretary of Agriculture and the Special Trade Representative, and also from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to President Reagan following the signing into law of the Farm Bill, just before Christmas. There are also the ongoing efforts of Australian Embassy staff directed towards those involved in the United States legislative process. To underscore the depth of feeling among Australia's farming community, I invited Mr Michael Shanahan, Senior Vice President of the National Farmers Federation, to accompany me. I was most appreciative of his support and assistance during my discussions in the United States.

As a result of my talks with five members of the Reagan Cabinet-Secretary of State Shultz, United States Special Trade Representative Yeutter, Secretary of Commerce Baldrige, Labor Secretary Brock, and Agriculture Secretary Block-there is now widespread understanding of Australia's concerns about the new United States farm legislation. I received strong expressions of support for Australia's position. More importantly, while the threat of damage remains, I received assurances that the Congress will be asked to repeal the mandatory provisions of the export enhancement program which threaten Australian wheat exports. I also received assurances that, to the extent that it was necessary in the continuing administration of the EEP, the United States Administration would do all that was possible to minimise damage to Australian interests. On wheat, I stressed at each of my meetings that the mandatory export subsidy expenditure provisions would be very damaging to Australia's interests. Our concern has been that competitive subsidisation of wheat by both the United States and the European Economic Community would simply result in world prices being forced down to levels that seriously damage efficient producers such as Australia. In this situation Australia would be forced to carry the cost of adjustment in the world market while inefficient, subsidised producers did not.

The validity of these points was clearly recognised by the senior U.S. Cabinet members with whom I spoke. Indeed, President Reagan himself when signing the United States Farm Bill had expressed his opposition to mandatory export subsidies. I am confident that the Administration will, within its area of discretion, administer these programs in a rational and responsible way while attempting to change these debilitating provisions. A decision by the Administration to seek the repeal of the mandatory provisions would signal a victory for those of us seeking to maintain a more open and fair international trading situation for agricultural products.

Both in my meeting with Mr Yeutter in Washington and during our preliminary discussions a week earlier, I registered strongly Australia's continuing concern at the reduction in United States sugar import quotas. I emphasised our particular disquiet that, in implementing the provisions of the farm legislation, further cuts could be made which discriminated against Australia. The severely depressed state of world sugar markets and the Australian industry, in particular, is largely attributable to the highly protectionist subsidised production policies being pursued by the European Community and the United States. The objective in Washington on sugar was to put the case for non-discriminatory application of future sugar quotas fairly and squarely before the Administration.

It was fortunate that I was able to schedule my meetings with Cabinet members immediately before their Cabinet consideration of the future implementation of the sugar program. I emphasised that discriminatory action against Australia would be unacceptable and that basic quota shares should remain as they are. I am confident that our case for non-discrimination will carry the day.

One element of particular concern in the United States Farm Act is the provision that 90,000 tonnes of United States beef be exported as a consequence of the dairy-herd buy-out program. While some of this beef will be used to supply United States defence establishments overseas, there is the danger that a substantial proportion of this beef may find its way into commercial markets at subsidised prices. The Australian Government is working closely with our cattle producers to try to prevent this happening. The United States National Cattlemen's Association recently told Australian cattle producers that it does not agree that United States beef should be subsidised into open commercial markets. It recognises the dangers for the stability of the world beef market of entering into subsidy-assisted trade; a market which is already being undermined by the subsidy practices of the European Community. The National Cattlemen's Association has agreed to prior consultation with our industry should exports proceed into the open market. Our cattle producers are urging United States cattle producers to make their views known to United States officials.

The provisions on beef slipped through the Congress in the final hours of the debate on the Farm Bill and the potential effects on inter-national beef markets were unintended by its sponsors. While in Washington I proposed that changes in the legislation be sought or that it be administered in such a way as to prevent this beef distorting commercial markets and normal patterns of trade. In my discussions with Secretary Schultz I also canvassed these issues. Having regard to our wide spectrum of shared alliance interests I stressed, as the Prime Minister did in his letter to President Reagan of 20 January, that solutions to the problems with the European Community should not be sought on a bilateral basis but should be addressed in the new multilateral trade negotiations; additionally, that interim measures contemplated by the United States to combat the European Community's subsidies should not unduly harm innocent and efficient trading partners.

I made a special effort to travel to Texas to the home town of Congressman De La Garza, who is Chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, to put directly to those primarily involved in the legislative process the strength of our concerns on the United States farm program. As a result, Congressman De La Garza has written to the Secretary of Agriculture pointing to the crucial nature of agricultural export earnings to Australia's economic well-being. He has noted the concerns I raised with him on the impact of the beef buy-out program, possible discriminatory application of sugar quotas and the overall impact of the United States farm legislation on our agricultural sector. He has requested that the interests of allies, such as Australia, be fully considered in the administration of these programs.

In a recent discussion with the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), Congressman Solarz has also undertaken to make similar representations to the United States Department of Agriculture. It is extremely important that the progress we have made in the United States in pressing Australia's views on these agricultural issues be followed up in the critical months ahead. This will involve continuing and intensifying our approaches to the Congress as well as the Administration.
United States-Australia Trade Talks

United States Special Trade Representative Yeutter and I agreed that it would be helpful to hold regular talks between Australia and the United States on trade matters. The precise format for these meetings will be settled shortly. They will provide the opportunity to discuss not only bilateral issues but also the development of mutually acceptable strategies for the multilateral trade negotiations and improvement of the world trading system.

The Hawke Government is adopting an active and aggressive approach to defending our competitiveness and access to world farm product export markets. It is this competitive position that I have been seeking to preserve and improve in my discussions in the United States and elsewhere. The Government is not mesmerised by one fixed line of approach or by past practices. Nor do we pursue ideological shibboleths such as wage deregulation under the guise of producing simple panaceas to complex problems. International trade in agriculture is not simply a result of free market forces. In many areas improvements can be achieved only by the co-operation and good-will of the Governments of foreign countries. In achieving these ends both industry organisations and the Government have important roles to play. I will be developing further proposals to reinforce these activities.

Both in respect of our multilateral negotiation strategies and our immediate concerns in respect of the United States farm program important progress has been made. The undertakings I have received from the United States Administration will help to ensure a better deal this year and next for Australian farmers. Also they will help us in our objective to achieve, through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations, fairer market structures for our products in the years ahead. For our part, we are endeavouring to adopt a flexible response to the most critical crisis in the world trading system since the present institutions were devised following the Second World War. We are endeavouring to create conditions within which bilaterally, regionally and multilaterally a fairer and more liberal trading environment can be created; an environment conducive to Australian export achievement across the agricultural, mining, manufacturing and services sectors-an achievement vital to our future prosperity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Everybody supports efforts to ensure the effects on Australia of the common agricultural policy of the European Economic Community and the United States of America Farm Act and export enhancement program are minimised, and to this extent the initiatives of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) in this area are welcomed by the Opposition as is the promise of continuing discussions with the United States and European Economic Community officials.

SPEECH.PARA: The effects of the European Economic Community's subsidisation and dumping policies on Australian agriculture are well known. The common agricultural policy pursued by the European Economic Community has led to massive distortion of world markets, with accompanying surpluses of beef, sugar, cereals and dairy products. To take just one example, the European Economic Community's subsidisation of sugar is equivalent to $US300 or $A430 per tonne. This causes massive distortion or world sugar markets to the detriment of Australia's sugar producers, whose industry is in a parlous state, and it has also allowed sugar stocks throughout the world to grow to record proportions.

The effects of the United States farm Act and export enhancement program are less well known, because they are, more or less, recent acts of the United States. The United States farm Bill, signed by President Reagan just before Christmas, will provide more than $6 billion in subsidies to United States grain, dairy, sugar, cotton and rice exporters, to enable them to compete better on world markets. There is also the possibility of a $2 billion subsidy over three years to help United States wheat producers, which would mean a drop in the world price, resulting in turn in a loss to Australian farmers of $250m a year. As far as sugar is concerned, the United States is almost certain to cut its sugar quota, with dire consequences for this beleaguered industry in Australia. I wish to say how much I appreciate the work done by the Minister for Trade in the sugar area.

There is also the prospect that, under the dairy herd reduction program, the United States could flood the international market with 90,000 tonnes of subsidised beef. Today the Minister said that his Government is working closely with our cattle producers to try to prevent this happening. We hope that it succeeds. There is a clear need for a bipartisan approach on such issues, as the standard of living of all Australians depends on how effectively and reliably our country trades.

As recently as January, the Deputy Leader of the National Party and shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), visited Brussels, where he urged the European Economic Community to adopt more rational pricing and export policies. In three days of discussion with senior members of the European Commission, the Deputy Leader of the National Party vigorously impressed upon the European Community the need for agricultural commodities to be included under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. On his return home he urged the Hawke Government to increase its pressure on European countries and the United States to adopt more realistic and rational agriculture pricing and export policies.

In this context, the visit of the Minister for Trade to the EEC and the US is to be commended. We in the Opposition accept that. However, our support for the Minister's initiatives in this area must be qualified by some very important provisos. Before the Minister left for overseas, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) suggested that the Minister's mission to the US would carry more clout if the Federal Government were not itself severely hurting Australian farmers and exporters. He particularly drew attention to the high interest rates that are currently crippling Australia's primary producers, our miners and manufacturers. These high interest rates are discouraging our exporters from expanding and taking advantage of new export opportunities and the devaluing dollar. This is certainly true. When we ask any primary producer, any miner, any manufacturer or anyone in a service industry we are told that Australia's real interest rates are the highest they have been for more than 50 years.

Let us look at Australia's interest and inflation rates in comparison with those of the countries visited by the Minister, which are our major trading partners. These are the current short term interest rates on the basis of three-month treasury bills for November-December 1985: Australia, 18.65 per cent per annum; USA, 7.26 per cent per annum; West Germany, 4.84 per cent per annum; UK, 11.01 per cent per annum; France, 8.96 per cent per annum; and Japan, 7.29 per cent per annum. Basically, Australia's rate is more than twice the average rate of the other countries. Let us compare Australia's inflation rate with those of our major trading partners. The current annual inflation rates represented in terms of the percentage change on the previous year are: Australia, 8.2 per cent; USA, 3.6 per cent; Germany, 1.8 per cent; UK, 5.5 per cent; France, 4.8 per cent; Japan, 1.9 per cent; and Canada, 4 per cent. Again, the inflation rates are about half our rate. The average for the OECD, in fact, is 4.5 per cent. Needless to say, Australia has higher interest and inflation rates than our competitors, both of which act as a major disincentive for our export industries.

Thus it is all very well to go off overseas and tell other countries that they should be treating our farmers better, when the Government back home is doing all it can to drive them off their properties.

I would like briefly to talk about the excursion of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) into the bush, shown on last weekend's Sunday program. Australian farmers would have been left completely unimpressed by this cynical public relations exercise, in which the Prime Minister tried to avoid his Government's share of responsibility for the current rural crisis. The Prime Minister did not want to talk about interest rates. It is no wonder, since today's crippling interest rates, double those of our trading partners, are directly due to the tight monetary policy his Government is using to prop up the dollar and maintain the accord. It is this policy which is pushing interest rates into the ridiculous 20 to 25 per cent range, while inflation is running at 8.2 per cent.

Repeatedly on the Sunday program the Prime Minister tried to put the blame for the current rural crisis entirely on the EEC for its `corruption of international markets'. The Hawke Government is very keen on pointing to the corruption of international markets by the EEC, but it is doing everything it can to corrupt the domestic market-place. Its intervention in the domestic money market to support the Australian dollar is keeping interest rates 6 to 8 per cent above what they should be. Its persistence with highly centralised wage fixation is allowing exporters no flexibility to adjust to individual trading conditions and economic circumstances. Its failure to pass on the full benefits of import parity pricing is placing all Australian export industries at a competitive disadvantage with those overseas. Thus, in talking about `corruption of international markets', the Prime Minister clearly neglected to talk about his own Government's corruption of financial markets, the wage fixing process and international parity pricing, all of which are steadily eroding the competitiveness of Australian industry. Just compare the labour conditions of our overseas competitors with those enjoyed by Australian workers, who have four weeks annual leave, compared with two weeks overseas, 17.5 per cent holiday loading, which does not exist overseas, and penalty rates after 8 hours, which exist overseas only after 40 hours work in a week. Now there is the likelihood of so-called productivity based superannuation.

The fact is that, since coming to office, the Hawke Labor Government has mercilessly sucked the lifeblood from Australia's rural sector. What is more, it appears that it has no intention of stopping. Despite his crocodile tears on the Sunday program this year, the Prime Minister still intends to slug Australian farmers with a new capital gains tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —Capital tax.

—A capital tax, as my colleague suggests. He still intends to slug them with the quarantining of farm losses and will expect them to bear the full brunt of the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions wages productivity deal. None of the details of these imposts are before this House, and that leads to uncertainty in the production place. It goes without saying that the Prime Minister does not intend to pass on to them the full 11c per litre benefit of the fall in world oil prices.

SPEECH.PARA: Twice on the Sunday program the Prime Minister described Australian farmers as `the most efficient in the world'-a sentiment echoed by the Minister for Trade when in Europe and the United States. This being the case, the Government should get off farmers backs, and give them, rather than the ACTU, some bonus for productivity. The fact is the ALP's diabolical union with the ACTU is preventing this Government and its Prime Minister from offering anything but sympathy to Australia's exporters and beleaguered primary producers.

I notice that the Minister for Trade has been pushing an education campaign for trade unions through his Department to alert them to the adverse affects of industrial disputation on international trade. Certainly something has to be done in this regard as the sort of union behaviour typified by the Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets disputes achieves nothing but the retardation of our nation's development. As a result of the Mudginberri dispute Australia lost about $4m worth of exports, some to the very markets where the Minister was speaking to overseas officials, namely, the European Economic Community. So it is not very good lecturing them about the problems they have and their effect on Australian industry when they can see how the unions and industrial relations generally in Australia are affecting our industry. At the same time, the Dollar Sweets dispute caused massive disruption to an important industry as far as import substitution is concerned. This Government is paying Queensland Mines Ltd over $100m as compensation for not exporting uranium to France-again, a member of the EEC. People must wonder how fair dinkum we are about trading our produce and resources overseas.

Today the Minister for Trade has said his Government is `not mesmerised by one fixed line of approach', nor does it pursue `ideological shibboleths such as wage deregulation'. Australia's unions have their incomes protected by the accord. Australian farmers and exporters, on the other hand, have to survive on what they can get in the international market-place. Thus the accord selectively and automatically maintains the standard of living for Australia's unions, while the standard of living of Australia's rural exporters is eroded. The most telling figure to emerge from the recent Bureau of Agricultural Economics conference was that the average income per farmer this financial year is expected to be $3,800, or only 18 per cent of average weekly earnings. This is a national scandal, and it is not all associated with the corruption of international markets. As I have already said, it is little good the Trade Minister going gallivanting around the world when his Government at home is doing all it can to penalise our farmers and exporters.

What about the Minister's achievements, represented in this statement while in Europe? On the eve of his departure he issued a Press release which contained promising suggestions about his proposed meetings in Spain and Portugal. In Madrid, we were told, he would be promoting Australian exports of coal and agricultural machinery. In Lisbon, we were told, he would be promoting Australian participation in the development of the proposed coal unloading facility at the Port of Sines. Since then, however, nothing has been heard, and nothing has been heard today, on that, so I ask the Minister what he achieved in both these areas which are very important to Australian exporters.

In Switzerland the Minister attended a European Monetary Fund Symposium at Davos-a major gathering of world economic representatives. He apparently failed to impress chief executives of Japanese, Swiss, German, French and Saudi Arabian firms. These businessmen, as reported, were critical of Australia's high wages, high interest rates and the restrictive practices of our trade unions. All the Minister could do was recycle the prediction of a possible 4 to 5 per cent fall in interest rates in the near future, which he should know rests on the assumption of an improved current account. This would have been hard for the Davos Symposium to believe when in Australia headlines such as that in the Australian of 14 February-`Trade Deficit Blow-out Forces Down the Dollar'-were appearing with increasing regularity. Of course, now the Government is not prepared to make any predictions as far as interests rates are concerned, and the Prime Minister says that his tight monetary policy will continue as long as is necessary. Given such flimsy and hypothetical evidence for future improvement in the Australian economy, its no wonder the Davos Symposium treated our Trade Minister with scepticism.

As I said, the Opposition commends the Minister's talks with EEC representatives, but the Minister has been able to give us no indication that he actually managed to do anything to improve Australia's disadvantaged position. In the Press release issued on the eve of his departure for Europe he said:

. . . the comprehensive study of the effects of the Common Agricultural Policy on agricultural exporting countries like Australia, published by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics a few months ago, was having an impact on raising the levels of consciousness in Europe about the cost of the CAP.

The Opposition commended this BAE study, which concluded that the EEC's common agricultural policy costs our exporters $1 billion annually. I would like to quote to the Minister the following article, entitled `Anti-dumping book dumped', from Australian Business of 15 January:

The Federal Government's hopes of influencing European public opinion, in its campaign against dumping of subsidised agricultural produce on Australia's traditional markets, appears to have struck a predictable snag-a not unprecedented one-lack of funds.
The Foreign Affairs Department is unhappy that its plans to promote the Bureau of Agricultural Economics' book `Agricultural Policies in the European Community' have been stymied.
The government's stinginess is nicely complemented by the European Commission itself, which managed to have scrapped a planned OECD seminar on the Australian research.
So much for the efforts of this Labor Government in counteracting the predatory actions of the EEC.

What of the Minister's visit to America? One particularly disconcerting aspect of the Trade Minister's United States visit was his tendency to act as Foreign Minister rather than Trade Minister, a preference the Minister intimated in an interview with Michael Gill in the National Times of 13-19 December 1985. In this regard perhaps in his joint capacity acting as Minister for Foreign Affairs he might have an answer to promoting the BAE study on the common agricultural policy by transferring the $3.5m which is being spent on peace projects to this other and more worthy project.

We have heard the Minister's summation of developments in agricultural and multilateral trade issues here today. What of the tangible results of his trip? I quote from an interview he gave to Jim Middleton on The World Today:
Middleton:

It (the Farm Bill) was opposed tooth and nail by the Reagan Administration, and the President only signed the legislation under duress, after it became clear that any veto he might impose would be over-ridden by Congress. The measure is a matter of deep embarrassment to the President who remains a committed free trader and who has promised to work to repeal both sections of the legislation necessary to give him the power to apply the subsidies more selectively.

So make no mistake, the Reagan Administration was opposed to mandatory legislation before the Minister's visit. What did the Minister actually achieve? Again according to Jim Middleton on The World Today:

Mr Dawkins emerged from his talks in Washington expressing confidence that President Reagan would carry out his commitment, but admitting he had no specific promises from the top administration officials with whom he'd talked.

So, there we have it. There were no specific promises. This fact was confirmed by Tuesday's Canberra Times which said Mr Dawkins failed to give any assurances to Australian farmers about the threat posed to them by the US Farm Bill. Later on in the World Today interview the Minister admitted that if the United States Administration was able to prevail over a hostile Congress on this issue, it would be because of the American public's horror about extending the benefit of subsidised exports to the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics.

The question we should really be asking is how far the American Congress has been moved by the Minister's pressure to support the Australian position. The answer is, obviously not at all. In this morning's Australian Financial Review we hear that the Minister managed to muster a letter of support from Congressman Kika de la Garza, a major power broker in deciding agricultural issues in the Democrat dominated American Congress. Who did Mr de la Garza send this letter to? It was not to the United States House of Representatives Agriculture Committee, of which he is Chairman, and not even to the members of the House of Representatives. He sent it to the United States Administration who, as we already know, were already and remain opposed to the mandatory provisions of the Farm Bill.

We commend the Minister's efforts, but for the sake of all Australian farmers we hope that his letter has more value than that with which Neville Chamberlain returned from Germany before the commencement of the Second World War. There we have it. Despite all the Minister's claims here today, he received no specific undertakings or promises and, if there are going to be any changes to the United States Farm Bill and export enhancement program, they will occur anyway.

We commend the Minister's efforts, but at the same time we should be under no illusion about the realities that prevail in world trade at the moment, and under no illusion about the value of his visit in the light of his Government's treatment of Australian farmers at home. We particularly wish the Minister well in his efforts, in conjunction with the upcoming round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations, to have agricultural commodities included within the GATT. But if his Government is really serious about helping Australia's beleaguered rural export industries, it should adopt the plan enunciated this week by the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Gwydir. Specifically, it should immediately pass on the full benefits of the fall in world oil prices; abolish fuel price indexation; remove all sales tax on fuel and lubricants used on farms and in fisheries; and restore a more equitable fuel freight equalisation scheme--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear. It is 60c a litre in Tasmania at the moment.

—Sixty cents? If we are going to get exports off the ground, we have got to get some justice in that regard. Furthermore, it should scrap quarantining of farm losses and the new capital gains and fringe benefits taxes; back off from the 3 per cent productivity-superannuation deal; adopt a more flexible wages policy, taking account of industry's capacity to pay; renegotiate the accord to ease interest rates and the pressure on the dollar; provide an immediate major injection of funds for debt adjustment, carry-on purposes and reconstruction; replace the tariffs on agricultural chemicals, farm machinery and parts with bounties; abolish export inspection charges for producers; instigate steady, predictable cuts to tariff protection; and restore the tax benefits of income equalisation deposits.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker,Mr McArthur and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lee and Mr Maher.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Aerospace Agency
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

Whereas space technology involves many of the very highest engineering and scientific disciplines that Australia possesses, which may be applied at an international level to reap significant economic and technological return to the nation, and;
Since an appropriate space program for Australia must involve presently unco-ordinated industry, government and research agencies, united together with Federal Government funding;

Your petitioners therefore pray that you will support the establishment of an Australian Aerospace Agency to manage aerospace programs under a Federal Budget, promote technology transfer, and market our expertise overseas, while ensuring the continued operation of existing space-related facilities within the nation.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Australian Government Centre, Mordialloc-Chelsea Area, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The area between Cheltenham and Frankston is lacking any C.E.S., Social Security or Medicare Offices, despite the clear need for such offices.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that an Australian Government Centre containing a C.E.S., Social Security, Medicare and other appropriate Government Offices be established in the Mordialloc-Chelsea area as soon as practicable.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed New Army Artillery Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned are deeply concerned that the decision to place an Army Artillery Base in the Orange/Bathurst/Mudgee area and the manoeuvres area in the Cobar region, would cause undue hardship to the families affected.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to:
1. Abandon its decision to resume land in the Orange/Bathurst/Mudgee and Cobar areas for military purposes.
2. That no site is chosen which includes productive, agricultural and/or pastoral land.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marine Band Radio Licence Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, Parliament House, Canberra. ACT 2600.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That we, the undersigned, are greatly concerned by, and totally opposed to, paying a licence fee to operate a marine band radio which is carried in any craft, and which may be relied upon to summon assistance in emergency situations.
We wish you to rescind the Regulation under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905, which prescribes this fee.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Commonwealth Government of Australia will protect us from payment of this fee.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the pricing of petrol in this country;
2. That under a Labor Government petrol prices have continued to rise excessively, with recent Government decisions adding over 8 cents per litre to the price of petrol in some country areas;
3. The proposed consumption tax could lead to a further rise of 6 cents per litre; and
4. The high cost of petrol discriminates against country residents who rely on their cars for essential communication and transport.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government honour the committment given by the Prime Minister during the 1983 election campaign to reduce petrol prices by 3 cents per litre.
Further we strongly urge the Government to adopt a petrol pricing policy which does not cause unnecessary rises in the cost of petrol.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principle stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that `States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women'. That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26-1-85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House set aside a National Park for these horses and ensure that killing of feral animals is undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully sheweth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And you petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Common Law Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under Common Law,
2. Deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. Give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. Could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives should:
Completely reject both the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Services in Illawarra Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government's decision to force, at the expense of viewers, the transfer of WIN TV (and any future local broadcaster) from VHF to UHF transmission, while excluding Sydney metropolitan T.V. stations from this requirement, has placed in jeopardy the future of the Illawarra and South Coast region's only local commercial T.V. operator.

Your petitioners request the House of Representatives to protect the interests of the hundreds of thousands of television viewers within the area from Wollongong to the Victorian border served by WIN TV, by preventing the government from taking this unwarranted and discriminatory action which disadvantages both viewers and advertisers on the South Coast to the benefit of the metropolitan networks.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons: Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled;
And, to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all Nuclear Weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destablising Nuclear Weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. The Australian Government-

(A) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the Governments of Nuclear Weapon States-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all Nuclear Weapon tests in all environments for all time,
(B) Call on all Nuclear Weapon States to declare an immediate moratorium on all Nuclear Weapon Tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal members of Parliament and Senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are greatly concerned at:
[a] The ready availability of X-rated videos and other pornographic material; and
[b] The increased tendency to highlight so many forms of sexual activity in the media without regard to the susceptibilities of the general public; and
as a consequence, Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action to
1. Prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography and grossly obscene publications.

2. Require the censorship authority to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes in determining classification and suitability of films and videos to be shown to Australian audiences; and
3. Ensure greater propriety in television productions, local and overseas, telecast to Australian audiences.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has announced its intention to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, currently the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government has no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in this manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but is handing over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australians citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to prevent this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia,
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Cobb.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Depreciation on Buildings
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's ban on negative gearing and restrictions on property depreciation will adversely affect thousands of disadvantaged people who rent their homes.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
End its ill-considered and discriminatory policy on rented property and allow depreciation on all buildings used to produce rental income.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Parkes in New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Rights to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade unions.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that: Your petitioners pray that Your Honourable House will reject the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 for the following reasons:

1. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and its implementation will result in attacks on the Christian church and the promotion of a State religion based on secular humanism;
2. That there is no need for legislation of this kind since the principles of freedom are already enshrined in Common Law and that it will cause more problems than it seeks to solve;

3. That there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many of which do not share a common heritage and do not practice many of the principles that they have convenanted to uphold;

4. The methods being used to introduce this legislation are secretive and a blatant misuse of the external affairs powers under Section 51 of the Australian Constitution and that furthermore are contrary to the spirit of the Constitution;

5. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Sutherland Shire respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights.
