DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The drop in living standards and loss of security suffered by Australian families as a result of the Hawke Government's policies and in particular the broken promises of the Prime Minister.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past two weeks the Opposition has sought in this Parliament to highlight the impact of the policies of the Hawke Government and, in particular, the broken promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who has now broken more promises than the infamous drover's dog has fleas, on the living standards and the security of Australians and average Australian families. During those debates the impact of those promises has come home to many people in the Australian community. They remember the infamous promises made by the Prime Minister which have been broken. They remember the promise on capital gains tax, which was broken. They remember the promise on the value of the pension, which was broken. They remember the promise on interest rates, which was broken. They remember the promise on petrol prices, which is about to be broken.

SPEECH.PARA: Let there be no mistake. Unless the Australian motorist gets a cut of 11c a litre in the price of petrol the Prime Minister will be directly cheating the Australian public of the full benefit of something that he and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) promised repeatedly, both in government and in opposition, the Australian public would receive. It is, therefore, no wonder that neither the Prime Minister nor the Treasurer is present to respond in this debate. Perhaps the heat of the last two days has been a little too much for the Treasurer. He has demonstrated a tenderness, a sensitivity and an inability to take a bit of heat which has become very plain. Who has been sent in by the Government to respond to a matter of public importance dealing with the family? Apparently, the organ grinder will not come out, the monkey has chickened out and we are left with the letter writer who leaked information, along with his six mates earlier this week, in revolt against the Prime Minister and the policies of the Hawke Government.

We are left with the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) whose epitaph may well have been written by none other than his factional ally, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), the Victorian President of the Australian Labor Party who made a remark that will ring in the ears of many people in the Australian community, that is, that poverty and homelessness have continued to rise under the Hawke Government. Who is responsible for that? It is the man who would moralise and hector about the impact of social security policies of former coalition governments on Australian families, the man who prides himself on having presided over policies that have reduced poverty and homelessness. One of his closest friends in the Australian Labor Party has said, in as many words, to him: `You have been a failure because under your policies the level of homelessness and poverty in the Australian community has increased dramatically'.

The policies of the Hawke Government are affecting the living standards, the sense of security and the actual security of Australian families. The Prime Minister does not like to be reminded of the fact that since he came to power the real value of family allowances has declined by 18 per cent. He does not like to be reminded of the fact that since he came to power the real value of the dependent spouse rebate, which is so important to many single income families on low levels of income who have children, has also declined by 18 per cent. He does not like to be reminded of the fact that before the last election he made many promises, over and above the promises I have already mentioned. He does not like to be reminded that before the last election, in his desperate bids to validate the early election which he had called without proper reason, he said: `We expect inflation to be less than 5 per cent in the year ahead and we are determined to keep it below 5 per cent'. That was the Prime Minister's promise. It was made in November 1984. It is now February 1986 and the inflation rate has been steadily climbing ever since the Prime Minister made that commitment. It has climbed to the extent that it is now more than double that of our major trading partners.

Yet the Prime Minister and his colleagues are on the brink of making that comparison even worse by their imminent decision not to pass on the full benefit of the fall in the world price of fuel. Not only will their failure to pass on the full benefit rob the Australian motorist of the 11c to which he is entitled for every litre of petrol he buys and earn for themselves the justly deserved title of the bowser bandits of 1986-not only do they stand indicted for that reason-but also, to the extent that we do not get the benefit of the fall in the world price of oil, they will make an already parlous competitive position even worse. All the other countries are going to get the benefit of falling oil prices. How will we hope to compete with the countries that get benefit and whose inflation rates are now less than half of Australia's inflation rate and, in the case of Japan, about a third of Australia's inflation rate? Apparently, the Prime Minister is as oblivious of that as he is of the impact of interest rates and the Australian Council of Trade Unions prices and incomes accord on rural Australia.

When asked at Question Time whether the families the Prime Minister visited a couple of weeks ago are the sorts of Australian families who should pay a 3 per cent productivity rise into a union-dominated superannuation fund, the Prime Minister prattled on about the alleged benefits of his Government. Rural Australia is not interested in platitudes from this Prime Minister. It is not interested in gimmicky public relations stunts. It is not interested in generalisations. It wants a few answers and it wants a bit of action from a man who, since he became Prime Minister, has loaded the rural community of Australia, in three short years, with enormous additional imposts.

If we go around rural Australia and talk to people, away from the glare of television cameras, and ask them what their problems are, they will tell us that they are essentially the problems of government imposed costs. They are the costs of fuel, the costs of capital gains taxes, the costs of other taxation measures imposed by the Hawke Government and above everything else they are the costs of interest rates. In November 1984 the Prime Minister said in his Adelaide address ``that we had sown the fields and we were going to reap the harvest''. It has been some harvest for those Australians who are now paying the highest interest rates that this country has suffered for more than 50 years. That is the legacy of the dishonoured promises of this man who now poses as an Australian Prime Minister who will bring the country together again.

I say to the Prime Minister and to all of his colleagues that the Australian public is fast running out of faith in a Prime Minister who thinks that advertisements in daily newspapers showing the Prime Minister with headphones on a talkback radio program is a substitute for creating jobs for young Australians. Just as the farmers of Australia were not impressed by the Prime Minister's visit to rural Australia a couple of weeks ago so the young people of Australia are not impressed with Priority One: Young Australia. The only priority of Priority One was the colossal ego of the Prime Minister. There were more advertisements and more photographs of the Prime Minister on talkback radio than there have been jobs created under Priority One.

The Prime Minister talks about the cynicism of the young. He got his mate Mr Young to inquire into why young people do not vote. One of the reasons why young people do not vote is that they are cynical of a Prime Minister who thinks that con tricks and public relations stunts are a substitute for job generation.

This Prime Minister, along with his Treasurer, has built up an unenviable record of broken promises. The reality of those broken promises is now starting to sink into the Australian community. Over the past week in particular we have seen evidence of them on the petrol price front, on the interest rate front and on the mortgage loan front. In the last five months there has been a 25 per cent fall in new housing loan approvals. The housing figures that were released today are catastrophic in the story they tell about the impact of high interest rates. We have another two or three months of tight monetary policy up to now to be reflected in subsequent statistics.

Over the past two weeks we have seen, perhaps more than at any other time over the past year, evidence accumulating not only of the wilfully wrong policies pursued by this Government but also of the deceit and the deception of this Prime Minister who promised so much before the last election, who mortgaged his political freedom of manoeuvre through all the promises he made. The Treasurer, knowing that the world price of oil could collapse within months of making his taxation statement of September last year nonetheless in this Parliament promised tax cuts in the next two Budgets. He now seeks to be excused from the heavy burden of discharging that promise by saying that he did not know that the price of oil would fall.

I can say to the Treasurer and to the Prime Minister that there is no way on earth that this Opposition or the Australian public will, for a moment, relieve them of the heavy political burden of honouring all of their promises. We intend to see that this Prime Minister and this Treasurer are made accountable for the promises that they made. The reason they must be made accountable for them is that their deception and their policies have affected the living standards of average Australians.

The Government should ask a Sydney family what it thinks of the rate of inflation. In Sydney over the past 12 months the price of bread has increased by 11 per cent, the price of cereals by 9.9 per cent, the price of petrol by 11.7 per cent, the price of coffee by 11.7 per cent, the price of detergent by 14.2 per cent, the price of soap by 13.5 per cent, and so the list goes on. This is why more and more Australian families are starting to believe that this Prime Minister and this Government have lost contact with them.

A Government which claims to represent the interests of ordinary families, of ordinary people, presides over the highest interest rates for more than 50 years, presides over a fall in the real value of family allowances of 18 per cent, presides over an inflation rate which is double that of our major trading partners and presides over a youth employment scheme that is nothing more than an expensive public relations gimmick to feed the ever increasing ego of the Prime Minister. In the area in which the Government has claimed to have achieved so much-that is unemployment-despite all that it claims to have done, despite all of the benefits of world economic recovery after the Government came to office, despite all the cyclical benefits of the breaking of the drought after it came to power, all that the Hawke Government can boast of in comparison with the unemployment figures under the former coalition Government is that the current rate of unemployment in Australia is higher than the rate was for all but four of the 86 months that the coalition Government was in office before the Hawke Government was elected. For somebody who for three years has gone around this country saying that he has wrought economic miracles and that Australia has the greatest economy in the world it is a pretty sorry legacy. No person is more responsible for that than the Prime Minister. This Prime Minister has made so many promises that his day of political reckoning is fast approaching. Over the past few weeks we really seen the totality of those promises and the impact of the breaking of those promises on average Australians and their families.

I say to the Prime Minister and to the Treasurer that over the weeks ahead we have no intention of allowing them to forget all the promises that they made to the Australian public, because there is more to come. More promises will be broken. The Premiers of the six Australian States will find that out at the next Premiers Conference. How cynical can one get with that promise? The Prime Minister has broken so many promises that he deserves to be censured by this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just heard is a dog's breakfast of a speech if ever there was one. It is interesting that, having chosen the next best thing to motherhood, that is families, as the subject of today's matter of public importance, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) talked about everything else but the situation of the family within Australian society today. He failed to develop any of the points that were scattered through the speech we have just been listening to. The vaguest reference was made to inflation, unemployment, petrol prices, income support, you name it, but nothing subtle was said. There was no perception, no ability to discipline himself into making a speech that would influence this House in any way whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has nothing to apologise for to the Australian electorate either with respect to broken promises, as they affect the Australian family, or with respect to its overall performance in relation to economic and social policy. I know that the Opposition likes to run away from this but the Government began its period in office in a context in which we were experiencing some of the worst economic circumstances in the post-war period. It is all very well for the Leader of the Opposition to suggest that somehow unemployment just happened to be temporarily out of control when the former Government lost office.

The reality is that when we went out of office in 1975 we were spending something like $250m a year on unemployment benefits and when we returned to office the bill had gone well over $3 billion. What happened in the intervening period? Was there a whole set of extraneous circumstances which were responsible for the fact that the Fraser Government administered the economy in a way that was more debilitating for the Australian family than under perhaps any other government since the 1930s? When the Leader of the Opposition says that we on this side of the House have no monopoly on compassion, he forgets the fact that hundreds of thousands of young people throughout the Fraser years had their lives brutalised by a government that did not have the compassion to take a single initiative to relieve the tremendous problem of unemployment that afflicted the Australian people during those years.

Unemployment is not a nice experience; it is a very nasty experience. And undoubtedly the scale of unemployment in this country has to be attributed to the previous Government. It is all very well for the Opposition to say that it is concerned; but the evidence of concern is, after all, economic and social management. The economic and social management of the Fraser-Howard Government was disastrous in terms of its impact on so many thousands of young people and on so many thousands of people who suffered from unemployment.

In terms of our record, within a relatively short period we have reversed the trend in a quite dramatic way. We promised to create 500,000 new jobs in our first three years. In fact, we have created 608,300 new jobs. The percentage of people unemployed in Australia has come down from 10.1 per cent in January 1983 to 7.8 per cent in January of this year. We have sought not only to increase employment and to reduce unemployment but also to address the social problems which are a reflection of the insensitivity of the administration of Malcolm Fraser and John Howard.

In the area of social security we have introduced new initiatives which have cost something like $1.4 billion since we have been in office. We have increased payments for those families which everybody recognises are the worst off within the Australian community. We have increased additional pension for children by 60 per cent, the mother's guardian's allowance has been doubled, the single adult unemployment benefit has been lifted by 40 per cent, we have introduced a new carer's pension, and so on. A number of initiatives have been taken. Initiatives which will come into effect later this year in a major attack on poverty traps include the abolition of a separate test on rent assistance, increases in allowable income for all pensioners, particularly increases in allowable income for sole pensioners and pensioner families, and so on.

The Government has, in fact, taken a number of initiatives and those initiatives are very much in line with the commitments we have made. There being difficult economic circumstances, there have had to be priorities. It was made clear in the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) what we were going to place the greatest emphasis on after we came into government in 1983. We promised that pensioner fringe benefit levels would be indexed. They have been. We promised a zone allowance for social security beneficiaries living in remote areas, and that allowance is now $7.50 a week. We promised to increase progressively the single adult unemployment benefit, to close the gap between the benefit and the pension created by the previous Government. Successive rises have halved the gap and continuing rises will close it in the next year or so. We promised to increase the junior unemployment benefits, and so on. Rent assistance has been provided to the long term unemployed. We have a commitment to raise pensions, as economic circumstances permit, to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Some progress, although limited, has been made in that area.

In terms of real changes in the disposable income of pensioners, under the Fraser Government we saw an 8.8 per cent reduction in the real disposable income of a sole parent with two children. Under our Government there has been a 7.4 per cent increase. For a married pensioner couple with two children, under the Fraser-Howard Government real disposable income decreased by more than 4 per cent-particularly for married couples with children in private rental accommodation. Under this Government the increase has been more than 6 per cent for the married couple with two children and 8 per cent for a married couple renting privately. The real standard of living of people who are in the lower income groups has substantially increased since we have been in office.

Expenditure in the family allowances area is where the priority has been. We do not make any apology for that. The people in those situations were the very worst off in Australian society and that is where family payments have increased. However, we recognise the need, in terms of the taxation system, to provide assistance more broadly to Australian families. So, in September this year there will be a tax cut of more than $7 a week for more than 1.2 million taxpayers with children. That is not simply a promise that will be thrown away when it suits us. That is a commitment that is planned for and that is a commitment we will carry out in September this year. Smaller decreases in tax paid will be available to the balance of Australian families-a considerable contribution towards ensuring that the living standards of Australian families are sustained.

The Leader of the Opposition made some reference to housing policy. It is extremely unfortunate that the Leader of the Opposition chose to make any reference at all to housing policy, because if there was an area of social policy which was butchered by the Fraser-Howard Government it was the area of housing policy. Since we have been in office there has been a massive increase in housing starts and tens of thousands of young people have had an opportunity to get into their first home. Between October 1983 and October 1985, 167,000 payments were made to tens of thousands of young people, which cost the Government of the order of $519m. In the current financial year we will spend $290m assisting first home owners through that scheme. On the other hand, we recognise the fact for low income people, particularly during a period of high unemployment, public housing, is extraordinarily important. So, in 1985-86 we will be spending $654m, with 16,600 new housing units being provided to assist low income people across Australia. In 1982-83 the Liberals spent $406m and there were only 8,700 new houses in the public sector. That is only half the level that is currently being achieved by this Government. What could be more important to the Australian family than the commitment this Government has made in terms of expenditure and the development of policy in the housing area?

I finally make reference to an area that the Leader of the Opposition did not mention, although I believe that it is an area that is critically important to Australian families. I am interested that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) is in the House, because I remember being with him some years ago at a public meeting at Northcote on the subject of child care. Child care is crucially important if one analyses the situation which has occurred, particularly with the growth in supporting parents and pensioner families headed by women. The only way that women will get out of a poverty situation in the long run is if they are able to get into the work force. The most critical factor, particularly for women with young children getting into the work force, is the provision of child care. We have made a major commitment in that area. In our first term in government, we allocated $40m for new child care services initiatives-eight times the amount allocated in the last Fraser Budget. In 1984 we introduced a more generous fee relief system for lower and middle income families.

Child care for families is one of the fastest growing programs of the Government-over 25 per cent per annum. This clearly demonstrates our priorities. The number of day care places for children has increased from 37,580 in June 1982 to 63,535 in June 1985, an increase of about 70 per cent. We have entered into new cost sharing arrangements with State governments to ensure that new centres are established as quickly as possible and to overcome the backlog of need created by years of neglect. Prior to the last election, we promised to provide a further 20,000 child care places, and plans are well advanced to meet that election undertaking.

Most State governments have agreed to assist the Commonwealth by continuing the cost sharing program. It will cost an additional $107m to establish the new centres and services under this three-year program. Once established, the cost of recurrent funding is estimated to be $50m per annum. Let us consider the Government's record in child care. Expenditure on children's services increased from $65m in 1982-83 to about $150m in 1985-86. By the end of our current three-year program we will have expanded the number of child care places from 4.5 per cent of the under five-year old children to 10 per cent-a record in commitment unmatched by any previous government.

The difference between this Government and the Opposition is that we have been careful about what we have said and about our commitments. In the social security area we have spent additional money but we have also made some savings. They have not been easy but they have been important so that we can provide assistance to Australian families, particularly low income families. Before the Leader of the Opposition spoke, the shadow spokesman on trade, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), listed about 15 elements for the rural sector that would have to cost hundreds of millions of dollars. There was no reference to cost. He said that just had to be done. When it suits the Opposition electorally it will spend hundreds of millions of dollars. When it suits those opposite to say that things ought to be chopped back, they will do that. But there was no reason, no rationality, no logic, and certainly no compassion, sympathy or understanding in the policies of the Opposition when in government. The contrast is clearly there in the figures to which I have referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I offer my congratulations to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on achieving your position, although I often do not envy you the task.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak in support of the Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986 with pride and appreciation. The appreciation is on behalf of all those individuals and organisations in my electorate that have benefited from this program. The pride flows from belonging to the Government that not only developed and implemented this policy but also recognised the need to keep it going.

The Newcastle area was particularly ravaged by the economic vandalism practised by the previous Government, the failed ideology, the lack of industry policy, and the inhuman neglect of the current and future circumstances of hundreds of thousands of Australians. The generation of a large pool of unemployment as an aspect of Liberal Party economic and wages policy had the effect of generating a huge volume of long term unemployed Australians who were virtually taught how not to work.

The community employment program specifically targeted the long term unemployed and those with employment disabilities. It is a savage indictment of our predecessors that the average period of prior unemployment of CEP participants Australia-wide has been 57.9 weeks and in the Hunter region this figure is 61.3 weeks. The community employment program has been a huge success in the Newcastle area. To date almost $13m has been committed to projects in my electorate, providing employment for almost 1,200 unemployed. Whilst the program has been extremely successful, and for that I congratulate the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), the fact is that this success is due in a very large part to the efforts of our project officer, Mr Gavin Farley, and his State counterpart, Mr John Othergee-I offer them my congratulations-and also to the organisations that have worked so hard to develop submissions and then to manage the ongoing projects.

I would like to emphasise the point that the community employment program is one that offers wonderful potential for communities all around Australia, but it also poses a very great challenge. The Government alone cannot make the program successful. For those members of the House who may be critical of this program, I suggest that the answer is in their own hands. If they are so lacking in concern for the long term unemployed and so unable to mobilise their community organisations to reap the very great benefits the program offers, I would question their justification for being members of this House and claiming to represent their communities. Innovation is the key to CEP. As a program its guidelines relate primarily to the unemployed. It allows itself to be mobilised for as wide a range of activities as there are needs in the community. Whilst the prime objective of the program is to assist the long term and disadvantaged unemployed, the achievement of this objective can provide substantial and long term benefits for the community as a whole.

I can best demonstrate this by outlining just a few of the projects in my electorate. One of the most exciting is the conversion of an old hotel to a hostel for unemployed youth. This project, sponsored by the Newcastle Youth Service, has received grants in the vicinity of $280,000-the most ever provided for any single youth project in Newcastle. It will provide accommodation for 16 of our unemployed young as well as house parents, together with space for a library and training facilities to help its occupants and others to learn new skills. Another project has involved the establishment of Rainbow Recycling, which collects industrial waste and recycles it for use in school arts and crafts courses. This project has worked in closely with the New South Wales Department of Education and the eventual objective of the project is to establish a continuing and viable business, after the CEP grant concludes. The conversion of an old picture theatre into a community centre is a project that proves how the wider community can and has benefited from CEP. Organisations as diverse as surf clubs, kindergartens, a maritime museum, ethnic groups, Parents Without Partners, environment groups, and churches can and have utilised CEP to help their communities while they help the unemployed.

The vast majority of people who have been employed under the community employment program do not want handouts or payment for digging holes and filling them in again. They want to work and they want to feel a sense of pride and achievement in the work they do. The CEP can provide meaningful work the participants can look back on with pride and satisfaction in the years ahead. It is important for us to understand that the problem of long term unemployment has effects and implications that are not well understood. The CEP has been a pioneering program in this field and whilst it has been of enormous benefit in assisting communities and unemployed it has also been of great benefit in teaching us a great deal about the nature of long term unemployment.

The success of CEP in assisting previous long term unemployed into the regular work force is now well established. The results of studies show that a significant number of CEP participants are in full time employment some six months after their CEP involvement is concluded. This shows us that for very many of the long term unemployed the experience of a reasonable period of proper productive work is more effective than courses and theory. The work experience is in itself a training. The CEP has been training people, firstly, how to work and, secondly, to re-establish faith and pride in themselves.

The amendment we are debating today is a clear indication that the Government recognises this fact. By extending CEP beyond the three years of its initial legislation the Government is recognising that there is a continuing role for this program in the armoury of Government weapons used in combating unemployment. It is important that CEP be kept flexible and that we increasingly monitor and analyse its performance. I believe that as we learn more about the effect of long term unemployment on the unemployed, CEP will need to flex and adjust to that understanding.

There is another aspect of the application of the CEP that the Government is addressing that I believe is important; this relates to invalid pensioners. Currently the criteria for receiving the invalid pension is an 85 per cent incapacity. Whilst we have various rehabilitation programs wherein we attempt to help people with disabilities to return to the work force, in general these have limited success, partly because of the very nature of the work experience they offer. The CEP specifically targets the disabled as a group and attempts to place them within CEP projects. Cases have occurred where invalid pensioners have been accepted into a CEP project only to find at the end of the project that they have lost the invalid pension completely and then have to spend months being re-evaluated for pension eligibility. This experience has undone much of the benefit that they have received from their CEP involvement.

The Department of Social Security is now reviewing the work test for CEP participants with the possibility of extending the work test period for CEP participants on invalid pensions to six or 12 months. This would mean that an invalid pensioner could enter a CEP project in the hope that the experience gained would enable him to compete in the normal work force but knowing that, if it did not he still had the security of the invalid pension. In effect, the CEP experience would serve as an extensive, real life rehabilitation program for such people. I believe that there is a very real opportunity for a number of disabled within our community to minimise the impact of their disability on their employment prospects and return to a much more normal lifestyle.

In other words the CEP allows them to spend six months or a year working on a project that allows them to use and develop whatever ability they may have. There is a real possibility that many such people will be able to develop their ability to a degree adequate to allow them to compete, within that specific skill area, with people who suffer no disabilities. In this context the CEP can be regarded as a rehabilitation program offering serious work, including job satisfaction, self pride and all that flows from this.

I have listened with some interest and, I confess, some horror, to the debate on this legislation. For example, a previous speaker spent virtually all of his time listing projects from outside his electorate, from all over Australia. He seemed to suggest that somehow or other the only people who pay taxes in Australia are the people with whom he agrees, understands or feels close to. The fact is that, if one wanted to make the kinds of stupid, cynical suggestions he made, one could do the people of Brewarrina a great disservice by, for example, listing the arts skills development program costing $64,000 and employing five people which was put forward by the Brewarrina community development committee in his electorate. The fact is that Brewarrina has such a need. I, as the honourable member for Newcastle, could stand here and scoff at such a project. If I did so, I would be doing what that previous speaker, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has done.

It is very easy for members of this House to isolate projects and groups in the community. It is easy to pick out a minority group and say that it does not have any right to any form of service. There will always be arguments about specific projects in any program of any government. It behoves us not to isolate those or to judge programs on those results. The fact is that in an electorate like Newcastle, which is part of the heartland of Australia, we have received very great help. The projects have been good. Those who have come out of the unemployed groups-on average they have been there for 61.9 weeks-have been good people who have shown that they can make those projects work. That is what the program should be judged on and not by the very cynical superficial efforts of people like the honourable member for Parkes.

In concluding my remarks on this legislation I would like to indicate my very strong support for the community employment program. It is a program that offers each and every community in Australia and hence each and every parliamentarian an opportunity to design and develop their own program, their own solution to assist their own long term and disadvantaged unemployed and their own community. It is flexible, creative and decentralised and there is now overwhelming evidence of just how effective it can be. For any who see individual failures or weaknesses, I suggest they lay the blame with the application or the appliers rather than with the overall program.
I urge all members of the House not only to support the amendments in the legislation but also to support actively the community employment program in the towns and cities for the benefit of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986. I recognise that the community employment program is by no means a permanent answer to unemployment but it gives many participants a sense of self respect after a long period on the dole. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) recognised this when he reiterated research undertaken by the Bureau of Labour Market Research which showed that participants in this type of program experienced a continuous improvement in psychological well-being and are more able to cope with any subsequent period of unemployment than are non-program participants. In essence, it gets them back into the habit of working again. It gives them a sense of belonging to the local community because there is a local job for them. It gives them a sense of achievement and contribution. They can look back on the project and say: `I helped to build that'.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme also allows local authorities and community groups the opportunity to complete projects which otherwise may have taken years to initiate because of a shortage of funds. Taxpayers can see their money being spent locally to provide additional facilities and to employ local people. Unfortunately, the trouble is that patch-up schemes such as the CEP eventually run out. What we have to do is to search for permanent ways of dealing with the problem of unemployment.

During this debate I would like to address three issues. First, I will deal with some local issues related to the operation of the CEP in the division of Forde. Secondly, I want to address the issue of unemployment, particularly some of the Minister's comments on it. Thirdly, I want to comment on the evaluation of this program which was provided in the report of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on the community employment program for the second year 1984-85.

I will deal with some of the local issues: In an answer to a question on notice last year, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations revealed that the area covered by the Woodridge Commonwealth Employment Service office received only 2.5 per cent of Queensland CEP funds for 1984-85. He also revealed that 5.6 per cent of the State's unemployed people were registered with the same office. This is one of the most disadvantaged areas in Australia with unemployment running at approximately 15 per cent. I hoped that by asking this question the Government's neglect of Logan City would be drawn to the Minister's attention. It appears that this was successful. At a subsequent meeting, the Queensland CEP secretariat made a conscious decision to allocate half of its available funds to Logan City, most of which is covered by the Woodridge Commonwealth Employment Service. My understanding is that this has never happened before. At the time there were many local applications which had been deferred because of a lack of funds. These included an application to build a community hall at Woodridge High School and an application by the Woodridge and District Committee on the Ageing to purchase a bus and employ two drivers to transport the aged people to the centre. They were both very worthwhile projects.

Logan City lacks many facilities that other areas take for granted. It was intended that the hall would be used by a wide range of groups. Logan City has a high proportion of aged pensioners but public transport is one of their biggest problems. I found it appalling at the time that the Government could provide the left wing People for Nuclear Disarmament with about $80,000 to purchase the now infamous peace bus, which has been mentioned by a number of my colleagues, but could not find $43,000 to help Australians who had paid taxes throughout their lives to make their old age a little more enjoyable. I am reminded that boy scouts help old ladies across the streets, but this Government was more interested in assisting the minority group to peddle its propaganda in schools than in helping the old ladies of Logan City to get to their senior citizens centre. Government members are not good scouts. The bus was also to be used by such commendable groups as Meals on Wheels. Has anyone ever criticised Meals on Wheels? Of course not! But many people are opposed to People for Nuclear Disarmament, and a lot more people were disgusted by the Government's decision to allocate CEP funds to that group.

I am pleased to report that both the community hall and the senior citizens bus were approved after the Government had suffered considerable embarrassment. Naturally, I was delighted. However, there is only a certain amount of money available for such projects. It upsets me to think that other deserving groups have missed out because of the Government's irresponsibility in providing funds for items such as the peace bus and funds to other left wing organisations already specified in detail by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) and, of course, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb).

Under the guidelines laid down for the CEP, a number of target groups are given preference when labour is allocated for programs. In general terms 50 per cent of the participants must be women, while Aborigines, the disabled and migrants with English language difficulties are also preferred. The requirement concerning female participation has caused a great deal of resentment in the Logan City area within my electorate. Certainly there are a lot of unemployed women in Logan City but the biggest problem is the large number of men with families who cannot get jobs. They are honest toilers and believe that families have just as much right to assistance as specific individuals. Perhaps the system could be altered to provide for a ratio of male to female unemployment equal to the ratio in the relevant Commonwealth Employment Service office. I understand, for example, that about 25 per cent of the total unemployed people in Logan City are females.

Another preference I would question relates to migrants with English language difficulties. This preference discriminates against migrants who have come to Australia from non-English speaking countries and who have gone through the hard slog of learning our language. The Government is creating a disincentive for migrants to learn English. Another guideline I would like reviewed is the requirement for community group sponsors to contribute 20 per cent of the estimated cost of a project. The requirement for a contribution runs parallel to the Liberal Party's philosophy of encouraging people to do something for themselves. If there were no requirement for a contribution, every club with more than one member would be seeking government assistance. My complaint concerns the rigidity of the requirement. In the Logan City area many community groups cannot afford to raise the 20 per cent of funds necessary to qualify for CEP funding. The strict enforcement of this guideline is discriminating against the very people the program is supposed to help.

I believe I have covered the rights and wrongs of the community employment program adequately in terms of the extension of the proposed Bill and its effects on my electorate. Yes, the program does have some advantages for the community; but, no, it is not as good as it could be.

As I said earlier, CEP is simply a patch-up scheme. It is not designed to create permanent employment for the participants. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is fond of citing figures which suggest that 46 per cent of former participants were employed six months after working on a CEP project. Even on his figures-I will return to the veracity of them later-54 per cent were not employed. I believe that today we should be focusing on why they are not working. We should be looking at the causes of long term unemployment. It is the primary responsibility of governments to create an economic climate in which adequate jobs exist-real and permanent jobs, not temporary government props. During the 1950s and 1960s, Australia's unemployment averaged less than 2 per cent under Liberal governments. People had permanency in their jobs. School and college leavers could obtain the jobs of their choice. There was an incentive to acquire additional skills and a reward for those skills.

Where have all the jobs gone? Predominantly, they have gone out of manufacturing and agriculture. In the past 15 years, employment in manufacturing has fallen by 11.3 per cent, from 1,301,639 jobs in 1970-71 to 1,154,400 in 1985. This is a loss of 147,239 jobs in a period when the overall population increased by 20.7 per cent. Of these jobs lost, no fewer than 138,000 disappeared in the last two years of the Whitlam Labor Government, during the two years 1973-74 and 1975-76. If manufacturing growth had followed the population increase, there would have been 252,000 more jobs in this sector, not an 11.3 per cent decline, and unemployment would have been contained at a low level.

In the same period agricultural employment declined significantly. Unlike manufacturing, farming is not labour-intensive. The farming sector, in its battle to contain costs and to improve productivity, has shed labour and has become increasingly mechanised. The rural decline in employment is continuing. Currently combined employment in agriculture, forestry, fishing and hunting amounts to barely 400,000 jobs, or only 6.1 per cent of total employment. For many years rural exports provided more than 80 per cent of Australia's overseas earnings; today they yield about 40 per cent but remain a vital economic asset. Mining now competes with agriculture as our export earner, however mining is not labour-intensive. It employs very little labour compared with its earning capacity. It is a highly mechanised industry, and increasingly so. Its percentage share of the Australian work force has been virtually static over the past 15 years. In 1971 mining employed 76,020 people. In 1985 it employed 95,900-a marginal gain of 19,880 in a period when the Australian population grew by 2.7 million.

Manufacturing has been traditionally the main source of employment and the demand for skills. It had an upsurge in the 1950s and early 1960s when a succession of Menzies Liberal governments sought to overcome the vulnerability which Australia faced at the outbreak of World War II.

TALK.START.PARA: —Liberal-National Party govern ments.

—In deference to my colleague the honourable member for Fisher, Liberal-National Party governments. Since the mid-1960s concentration on developing significant industries has largely dissipated. Cost pressures and failure to modernise have taken their toll. There has been a growing reliance on imports and greater emphasis on assembly rather than basic manufacture. Increased technology and structural change have brought with them greater mechanisation and less labour-intensive needs, but these do not effectively explain the shrinkage of jobs. Manufacturing has failed to expand and to keep pace with world trends. Australia has become increasingly dependent on the farming and extracting industries-industries which require very little labour and universal skills. We have everything going for us-the physical resources, the climate, the land and the human potential-but only if we switch on the vital motivation and if our goals are clearly defined and understood. If we are to be able to trade competitively on world markets, we must get our costs down and our quality up. In other words, we need increased productivity. If we are to create more jobs and protect and raise the living standards, increased productivity is the answer and the Government needs to ensure it provides the appropriate taxation incentives.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I would like to examine the methods used to evaluate and monitor the community employment program. I wish to go into some technical detail because the Government wishes to make evaluating statements on the basis of research. I refer particularly to the Minister's statement on page 6 and following pages. I want to say from the outset that the experimental design is so poor that no substantive statements can be made on the basis of the design adopted. The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations did recognise in paragraph 4.3 of Chapter 4 of its 1984-85 report the absence of control groups. What it failed to say was that the absence of control groups makes any conclusions from the evaluation virtually useless. The Department argued that resource constraints stopped it from interviewing matched control group samples. The Department should have saved additional funds by not doing the review at all, as what it has done is essentially worthless. The design adopted-I hate to get too technical-could be loosely called an ex post facto one group design with a repeat. I am sure that a former colleague of mine, Professor Donald Campbell, who is recognised as the world authority on experimental design and program evaluation, would agree that such a design is so poor that it is hardly worth including it as an experimental design at all. It is not far from useless when it comes to drawing conclusions from it.

However, the Minister would like us to believe that CEP has positively affected the ability of long term unemployed to obtain a job after entering the program. Unfortunately, since there is no comparison between the unemployed who undertook CEP employment and those who did not undertake such employment, no differential rate of employment data is available. Thus, there is no way we can objectively decide whether the program has had any positive or negative differential impact. The Minister attempted to argue that the better results for the program were obtained by the July 1985 survey as against the March survey. Unfortunately for the Minister, no such conclusions can be reached because of the problems I outlined earlier.

There were other changes occurring in the economy during that period. It is well known that seasonal variations affect employment-I am sure the Minister is aware of that-and that these may have influenced the results of the survey. There was no attempt in the methodology to control for exogenous effects. However, if anything, the evidence provided by the surveys refutes the Minister's assertions on page 6 of his statement. For example, on page 81 of the 1984-85 report, the survey results show that those who withdrew from the program did not have substantially different post-employment records from those who completed the program. Of the persons surveyed in March who completed a CEP project, 35.4 per cent were in employment at the time of the survey, compared with 32.4 per cent of the persons who left early. In the July survey, there was a reversal of these outcomes with 36.6 per cent of completing participants in employment and 42.9 per cent of those who left early holding a job. Contrary to what the Minister has said, these results imply that completing the program has little effect on the probability of obtaining employment.

Finally, the survey results demonstrate that some six months after completing a CEP project, over 50 per cent of the participants were either unemployed of had left the work force. Because of the methodological problems I outlined earlier, I do not want to belabour this point. But it is worth noting because, viewed objectively, the survey results do not support the Minister's assertions which are contained in his second reading speech. While recognising that community employment program projects are not the answer to long term unemployment, I have attempted to provide some constructive comments on the implementation of the program and, I hope, in the longer run, on the evaluation of the program. I hope that, the Minister, who is at the table, considers some of them worth implementing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Employment Amendment Bill puts into effect an announcement made by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) on 10 December last year that the Government proposed to continue the very successful community employment program for a further three years. Despite the remarks that have been made by several Opposition speakers who have sought to denigrate the scheme and who have been rather unjustly critical of it, I want in the main to express my appreciation for and satisfaction with the great benefits that have come from the scheme, specifically to many locally unemployed people in my electorate. Naturally, of course, a great number of community programs have proceeded simply because of the opportunity that existed through this program-an opportunity that otherwise would not have given the community the benefits of these projects.

SPEECH.PARA: We inherited the unemployment problem from the former Liberal-National Party coalition Government. The issue of unemployment and the ways of overcoming it have been a top priority of this Government. Of course, foremost among the successful schemes that have been put into effect is the community employment program. As far as my electorate is concerned, the scheme has been very welcome and extremely successful, in particular in the Redland area of my electorate. The Redland Shire Council has taken every opportunity to capitalise on the opportunities available through the scheme and many worthwhile Council and community projects have been carried out. I take this opportunity of expressing my appreciation to the Chairman and members of the Redland Shire Council for the excellent way that they have co-operated in utilising the benefits of this community employment program to upgrade many of their facilities and to create many new facilities throughout the Redland Shire.

In excess of $2.8m of CEP funds has been committed to create more than 265 jobs for locally unemployed people in some 38 projects in my electorate. The current Budget provides some $290m for the Community employment program at a national level. Of this, $42.1m is to be used in Queensland and $10m is to be made available to the Queensland Government for projects which it will sponsor. I want to concentrate for a few minutes on that aspect of the scheme as it is one aspect which I am far from happy with. I was pleased to note that the Minister said in his second reading speech:

The Government is currently in the process of consulting with those administrators and sponsors who have participated in the CEP in order to gain constructive input into the formulation of the new program. We believe that it is necessary to undertake this process of consultation before final decisions are taken both on the program and financial guidelines which determine the structure and administrative arrangements for the new program.

I strongly urge the Minister to ensure that the officers of his Department, those associated with the secretariat in Queensland and those who sit on the advisory committee, will look very closely in the future at some of the projects that are submitted by the Queensland Government. I am aware that the guidelines for funding require 65 per cent of Commonwealth funds to go towards labour costs. I believe that the Queensland Government would certainly abide by those regulations. However, my concern is that the State Government is applying for CEP funds for projects that should ordinarily come within the normal range of departmental activities and, in that regard, should be funded from normal budgetary sources rather than through the utilisation of CEP funds. In that way the Queensland Government is using the community employment program incorrectly; it is using it to balance its Budget. I believe that such action is contemptible but it does not surprise me that the Queensland Government should take such contemptible action.

I have quite a number of examples of how the Queensland Government has carried out maintenance work on a variety of projects, under quite a range of different government departments, utilising CEP funds. I say once again that the Queensland Government should be funding those projects from its own budgetary sources and not from CEP funds. I give as examples the cleaning up of the railway yards at Bowen and the cleaning of machinery in storage sheds-work which was carried out through the Department of Primary Industries. The Department of Transport has provided a number of worthwhile park and ride facilities in some of the suburban stations of Brisbane. That has worked well with the introduction of the electric rail system in that area. But, once again, these projects could well have been funded from Queensland Budget sources rather than from CEP funds.

I give an example of how the Queensland Government uses these projects for its own political purposes at every opportunity. During a recent by-election campaign in the Redlands seat in the Queensland Parliament the Queensland Government staged the opening of the Thorneside railway station park and ride station that had been constructed from community employment program funds. Some 30 jobs had been created by the project and $182,000 of CEP funds had been expended. All the news media were there and in attendance was the National Party candidate for the by-election. State Minister Lane declared officially open the car park constructed with CEP funds. He unveiled the plaque with his name on it, saying how great was the Queensland Government for providing this facility for motorists to park their vehicles, enabling them to travel to the city by train. Neither in his speech, nor indeed on the plaque he unveiled was any mention made of the fact that the community employment program facilitated the provision of those facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What deception.

—Absolute deception, as the honourable member for Cowan interjects helpfully. I understand that Queensland is not the only State guilty of this practice, but let me assure honourable members that from my observation in Queensland it occurs with a regularity which I am sure is not matched in other States. It is an outright abuse of CEP. It is regularly nothing more than an arrogant misuse of Commonwealth Government funds to carry out work which should be undertaken by the State Government with funds from a source other than that. I strongly urge the Minister to ensure, when these guidelines are being re-examined, that if this practice is not discontinued by the Queensland Government the $10m that is to be allocated to that Government is reviewed and withdrawn from the scheme and allocated to other areas, which I can assure the Minister will be very grateful to receive the funds. The State Government should show a genuine concern for creating job opportunities and should create them from its own Budget. If it were to do that, all funds that are available through the CEP could be allocated either directly to local government or to community organisations, which often lack the funds to carry out desirable projects. The CEP funds would then be of more substantial benefit to the various local communities.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Government on its decision to continue the program. For many unemployed people it provides an important step back into the work force. Through the program many long term unemployed who have found it very difficult to get a break enabling them to regain their confidence and to secure a job have been able to learn new skills and often to gain work experience, probably providing them with a reference from recent employment. All these things are definite advantages when these people apply for jobs in the future.

I just comment in closing that the youth traineeship scheme, which is also an initiative of this Government, initially will concentrate on assisting young 16 or 17-year-old school leavers to secure job training. There is certainly a need also for a scheme that caters for the unemployed older youth, those beyond the 16 to 17 year old age group. I am sure this also should receive the attention of the Government and a scheme similar to the CEP introduced to create opportunities for those people to have the type of training that very often has been denied them because of the severe lack of job opportunities in recent years. I compliment the Minister and am very pleased to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier I was giving some examples of where I thought there was waste in the community employment program. I will conclude my speech by mentioning just two more. I see that the New South Wales National Aborigines Day Observance Committee will receive $10,904 to employ a co-ordinator for 18 weeks to promote and organise activities and assess applications for funding from groups wishing to participate. I may be wrong, but I do not think the taxpayers would view this as a very productive contribution towards the welfare of Australia. Finally, I was amazed to see the Arts Council of the Australian Council of Trade Unions will receive $31,563 to employ four people for 18 weeks to train and work with a professional clown. So there we have it-a litany of waste of taxpayers' funds amounting to over $1,100m in just three years. No doubt a number of projects that have been funded have some merit-with the thousands funded it would be remarkable if that were not the case-but those more benign ones it appears are being used as a cover for the Government to carry out its funding of left wing and ratbag groups.
—A disgrace.

—It is a disgrace. It seems they are intent on bankrolling and nurturing every anti-Australian group imaginable. The community employment program has become a joke across large areas of Australia. Wherever one travels nowadays there are stories of rorts and waste. The Government trumpets the virtues of this program for the long term unemployed; however, it overlooks what the figures show. In July 1983 the average length of time a person was unemployed was 39.9 weeks. A year later it was 47.8 weeks. It is now around 52 weeks-hardly something to skite about. The extra taxes the Government has had to collect to fund the program, some $1,100m, must surely have contributed to the malaise in the economy that is preventing unemployed people from getting a job. In my area shire councils are dissatisfied with how the scheme must work and are now making little or no use of it.
—The guidelines are mad.

—They are. Let us look at it from the point of view of the shire councils. First of all, they cannot hire who they want. There have to be so many very long term unemployed-who incidentally are often the poor workers in the community-so many women, so many Aborigines, so many migrants, so many who cannot speak English, so many this, so many that. Specific jobs require specific people, and if the Government dictates who they may or may not hire for the job half the time it is not really worth the effort. Shire councils have not only a contribution cost of 20 per cent with the projects but other costs as well. Capital equipment is but one of them. On top of that is the higher than normal supervision costs because of the nature of these people, their inexperience and so on. It is also par for the course to have 30 to 40 per cent of the participants in these programs drop out, which may even require fully paid labour to be employed to get the job finished. The deal is not quite the giveaway some think it is. Some shire councils have also had difficulties because of tight budget restraints resulting from the rural depression. These CEP projects can look very enticing mid-year when there are a number of odd job projects that could be done, but because of the outlay of shire money and staff required even permanent jobs can be at risk as the end of the year looms up and the figures are added up.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not to say that there are not elements of the scheme that have merit. Also I believe that if the Government is to pour money into the CEP program, each electorate is entitled to its fair pro rata share. What I do object to is the waste and inefficiency in the scheme. The CEP job subsidy scheme is a roundabout way of the Government admitting that wage levels are too high. It is nothing more or less than a wage subsidy pitched at a level to make unemployed people employable. The number of CEP participants who get full time work even six months after they complete their CEP jobs is relatively low, at 35 per cent. When one subtracts the percentage of those who would have found work anyhow, even without the dubious work experience benefit of the CEP scheme, the figure is much lower-probably closer to 20 per cent. One cannot help but be very sceptical of the benefit of the whole program. I suspect if one were to lower taxes to employers by the $1,100m that the scheme has cost, they would have been able to employ a similar number or even more people anyhow. As well, they would provide more permanent employment and in jobs that are far more productive to the community as a whole.

In the Government's quest to do something about the unemployed in our society, we often overlook the fact that it is government taxes and regulations on employers that cause unemployment in the first place. Further taxes to create make-work jobs will destroy at least as many jobs as they create. I suggest that if the Government is genuinely concerned about unemployment, it should look to treating the cause of the disease and not its symptoms. When the dead hand of government is lifted from those who can employ people in real jobs, the problem will solve itself. Perhaps a placard I read at the Dubbo rally summed it all up. It simply said: `Unemployment Isn't Working'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Ms H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the rather extraordinary remarks made by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), I must point out that I applaud the decision to continue the community employment program. In my electorate it has been responsible for providing employment in many useful and creative areas. Although I can go into the amount of money-over $3m-which has gone into the electorate, providing benefits in all sorts of ways, and the number of jobs created, I want to talk about the effect of the program on the community organisations which have been so generous in their sponsorship. Many services have been provided, work experience and training have been made available to people who needed them, and a great deal has been accomplished in a very economical way indeed. The barrier of long term unemployment has been broken for many people who have spent long soul-destroying hours in job seeking queues at local Commonwealth Employment Service offices.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the employment is community based, community controlled and subject to carefully scrutinised guidelines, the work made available has lasting beneficial effects for the community as well as for the employees. The training experienced through the ambit of the CEP has greatly encouraged many of the unemployed in my community and has given them the taste of a regular income. This in itself is a positive directive which helps to provide personal confidence and a commitment to the training for future full time work. The target groups have been well represented. Women workers have obtained 47.3 per cent of the jobs, under 25 year olds have obtained 51 per cent of the jobs and over 60 per cent of the work has gone to long term unemployed. I hope everybody realises that those are not cumulative percentages but illustrative.

This was the first labour force program to pursue the Government's equal opportunity policy and it worked brilliantly. Major CEP projects currently running in my electorate of Chisholm are sponsored by the cities of Box Hill and Camberwell, the Mitcham Special School, the Graig Community Centre, the Box Hill College of TAFE and the DOME Association. Other projects have been sponsored by the Royal Horticultural Society of Box Hill, the Mission of St James and St John and various similar organisations. Because we have heard so much nonsense about where the money has been going for CEP, I decided that it was worth while explaining in some detail the nature of the organisations which have sponsored projects in my electorate.

It is fanciful to describe those organisations as left wing politically, or even political at all. Those sponsor organisations, which have demonstrated real responsibility to their community, may look upon some Opposition members with distinct cynicism, deservedly so. It seems a pity that the Opposition can only approve of sponsors who have political motives to suit their taste. The CEP project which demonstrates the value of the program quite clearly, is the support of the DOME Association. The letters `DOME' stand for `Don't Overlook Mature-age Expertise'. The Association provides a service for unemployed mature age people. People of 45 years or over can suffer very great personal pain and dislocation when, after having worked for many years, they find themselves without work. DOME is a self-help association which, with the aid of CEP funds, assists its members to cope with their situation and to find employment. Such a project, with its proven worth is typical, not atypical, of CEP jobs in which the benefit of the funded jobs reaches far beyond the actual employment into a permanent benefit for the community in which the projects takes place.

I listened to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) earlier in this debate giving some attention to his fanciful notion of the nature of the community groups which have sponsored employment. We have heard this over and over again. I think it is a matter of trying to discredit anything that it is initiated by a Labor government, determined as we are in a realistic and thoughtful way to counter with dignity the problem of long term unemployment. The remarks made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition were more a mirror reflecting his own character than a sensible contribution to this debate.

I would like to say a few words about those who work behind the scenes administering CEP in regional areas across Australia. This support system is both highly qualified and industrious as it sets about its task of providing advice to members of parliament and those wishing to lodge applications under the scheme. The two project officers working in my electorate have, from the outset, provided careful scrutiny and good advice in relation to all aspects of this program. Their conscientious approach to providing this assistance as well as the thoughtful explanation of the CEP guidelines have given many an interested would-be sponsor the opportunity to produce a realistic and, eventually, successful application. The end result of all this is, of course, the placement of unemployed people in job-training positions which look to future worthwhile employment.

A most innovative and successful program, evolving from CEP funding, is that sponsored by the Mission of St James and St John, known as the CONJARA project. CONJARA means `Creation of Nursery Jobs and Related Activities'. Under the scheme, a wholesale nursery was established which has diversified to offer a service designed around a `Goodness in the Garden' concept-specifically, mulching of garden waste. Many in the community have taken advantage of this service and learnt from it. Initially, the project got off the ground with funding of $131,000 which provided training for eight long term unemployed people. I am pleased to say that half of those placed in training were young women.

Another most worthwhile project has been that sponsored by the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals to construct an animal shelter and a see-and-touch animal nursery. The RSPCA is a highly respected organisation with headquarters based in my electorate. Through this CEP project, the RSPCA has received funding to provide the local community with a much needed facility for injured animals, while at the same time educating the community to a better understanding of all animals. In terms of funding, my electorate has received $3.5m which has provided for a variety of exciting projects, some of which I have described. The myriad of interests emanating from the CEP concept adds to the colour and flavour of this genuine Government commitment to alleviating the problems associated with unemployment.

The CEP is another of the Labor Government's successful attempts to curb long term unemployment and the stigma it produces. This Labor-intensive program has as its dominant aim the promotion of greater equity in the labor market through the provision of employment and work experience to those least likely to find jobs in the course of the general economic recovery. This group was made up, to a large degree, of victims of recession and structural change who had subsequently become unemployed for a long term, as well as certain groups who were seen as experiencing special disadvantage in the labor market. In particular, women, the disabled, Aboriginals and migrants were seen as needing assistance along with the long term unemployed.

The honourable member for Parkes had a pleasant sounding solution to unemployment-namely for the Government to stop doing anything at all. Had that been a successful solution to unemployment, it certainly would have worked for the previous Government, which did nothing at all and produced an unemployment level of 10.3 per cent. That figure has now fallen to 7.8 per cent under this Government and a great deal of that fall has been in full time private employment. All in all, the CEP program in my electorate-and that is the one of which I have detailed knowledge-has provided benefits to the community. It has provided benefits to the sponsoring groups and to those who are unemployed, and has provided in a variety of ways services which have been very much needed and very useful. Many of those services continue after CEP funding has run out because their value to the community has been demonstrated and other funding has been found to keep them going. I believe that the continuation of the CEP program will be a significant factor in my electorate for the next three years. Once again, I applaud the Government's decision to continue the program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is in the chamber. I am pleased to see that. I hope that he is not just about to leave.
—I'll be back.

—I will certainly send the Minister a copy of my speech. The Community Employment Amendment Bill 1985 seeks to extend funding for the community employment program for three years. The Opposition supports in principle the extension of the program, as it did the principal Act in 1983. We recognise, however, that the CEP scheme is not the cure-all that the Government, the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) and many other honourable members opposite would like us to believe it is. The CEP was only ever to be a short term approach. This Bill entrenches it as a permanent part of the labour market. One should ask whether that is a recognition of failure.

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment relief schemes serve a purpose. No one would doubt that. There is no general disagreement on that point. However, unemployment relief schemes do not lead to a great boost in overall employment. Levels of employment and unemployment are consequent upon many factors, such as labour market regulation, centralised and rigid wage fixing, high levels of employer on-costs, international competitiveness, overall economic performance and the capacity of industry to pay-all points that have been made by other speakers during this debate. There is no doubt, however, that unemployment is one of the principal economic and social ills besetting not only this nation but also many nations throughout the world.

Australia's unemployment rate has remained constant at 7.8 per cent for a period of four months since October last year. It has even been suggested that Australia's natural rate of unemployment has stagnated around this high level which, if it were true, is a damning indictment of this Government. This high level of unemployment is higher than it was for 82 of the 86 months of the Fraser Liberal Government. Of even more concern is the fact that the average length of unemployment has increased significantly during the term of this Government. In March 1983, the average length of unemployment was 33.2 weeks. In July 1984 it was 47.8 weeks. By July 1985 it had increased to one year-52 weeks.

Unemployment among the youth of this nation is also at an unacceptably high level. Currently, the rate of unemployment among 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds is 21.4 per cent. They are the people who, all would agree, are the future of this nation. There are 583,000 Australians who cannot find employment. The incentives for employment are no longer there. Employers have been constantly battered by the deal this Government worked out with its masters in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Recently, it was interesting-I was amazed-to hear the Minister's answer when he was asked on television what he thought about youth wage rates and whether he believed that there should be a youth wage rate. He agreed that there should. However, when he was asked what he was going to do about it, he said: `At this point, nothing'. The irresponsible mandarins in the union movement have, by their collective actions, harmed irreparably the employment opportunities of a great many young Australians. More than 220,000 people are currently unemployed for a period, on average, of greater than 36 weeks-the length of unemployment which is used as a guide by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations when assessing eligibility for employment under the CEP program.

According to the Government's guidelines, those most in line for employment under the scheme are those who have been unemployed for more than nine months, migrants with English speaking difficulties, Aboriginals and the disabled. Whilst it is generally accepted that people in these categories are affected adversely by generally high rates of unemployment, the guidelines need to incorporate a greater flexibility so as to reflect in a more realistic manner the quite often great demographic differences that are in employment. I note that the Minister's second reading speech, almost on the last page, states that the Government believes that it is necessary to undertake the process of consultation before final decisions are taken on both the program and financial guidelines. I hope that, when consulting, he will take note of the remarks I have made and also of some made by honourable members opposite. Some of the remarks I want to make a little later are in agreement with what some of them have said about setting out the new guidelines. For example, in my electorate of Bass in Tasmania there are, as there would be in other electorates, towns such as Georgetown which unfortunately have very high levels of youth unemployment. The youth unemployment level in Georgetown exceeds 20 per cent and the prospects for funding long term, sustainable employment are not great at all.
