Short term unemployment relief schemes serve a purpose and, in fact, can serve a very good purpose. Unfortunately, the benefits available under CEP in Georgetown are not as freely available as perhaps would be desirable. On a number of occasions I have received expressions of concern from local councillors at Georgetown who say that they have the projects, they certainly have the labour, but they cannot get the funding they require from the CEP. I have communicated these concerns to the Minister on a number of occasions during the past 12 months. Only recently I received a response to my last letter-a little card saying that my letter had been received. Now some months have passed by. I guess that adds credence to what the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) was saying in this chamber the other evening about how long it takes Ministers to respond. I would have thought that, on an issue as vital as youth unemployment, the Minister would have ensured that his administrative staff answered promptly. In any event, I hope that he will take my remarks into account in his review.

The question is: Is the CEP scheme a simple pandering to minority groups as a vote catching exercise? The guidelines need attention. CEP is in real danger of being seen as a facade for the Government to appear to be doing something about structural unemployment. Alice in Wonderland's cheshire cat may not be an unfair analogy. The program must have substance. The guidelines, therefore, must take account of demographic variations. Whenever one discusses the CEP scheme one is always forced to return to the basic question: How effective is the community employment program? In Tasmania, just last week, another 95 people were employed on approved projects. The cost to the Commonwealth of these projects is $816,000, bringing the total allocation for CEP funding in Tasmania to $26.3m. There have been 1,003 projects approved, leading to temporary employment of some 3,481 Tasmanians. The average cost per job has, therefore, been in the order of $7,500. The average cost per project has been $26,220. The average duration of employment has been in the order of 21 weeks. The average number of people employed per project in Tasmania has been three. So, for $26,220 we get only three people employed for only five months. All of this calls into question the worth of the program.

Nationally, the Government has expended over $1 billion on the CEP in its first three years of operation. By anyone's criteria this constitutes a massive financial commitment. By and large, the Opposition is of the opinion that such a commitment has not been irresponsible. Whether or not the benefits that have accrued under the CEP are all the Government claims is an entirely different matter. For instance, some projects which have been approved for CEP funding I am doubtful about, to say the least. We have to be careful that this scheme should not be seen to be a honeypot for left wing causes. Many examples of this have been quoted in the chamber for the last two days.

I would like to mention two programs in Tasmania. Interestingly, I found mention of one program tucked away in the back of the report of the Department of Aviation. The Department of Aviation received CEP funding for a study of the role of women in Australia's aviation history. Whilst I do not doubt that that would be an interesting study, I question whether or not CEP should be funding work within the Commonwealth Department of Aviation.

In Tasmania the National Parks and Wildlife Service has received CEP funding of $13,324 to employ one person for 48 weeks to undertake a survey of Cape Barren geese and potoroos on Flinders Island and to implement field trials to test target specificity of certain poisons and baits. The Launceston City Council, another example, received $6,240 to employ one person for 16 weeks to compile a directory of recreational facilities and inspect and report upon the suitability of further sites. In each of the above cases some questions as to the desirability-indeed, the propriety-of such projects being funded by CEP grants must arise. The matter of inappropriate projects receiving funding under CEP is one which I have long held to be a major flaw in the conduct of the program. It is a matter which directly relates to abuses of the program which have been perpetuated by State governments and local councils using CEP funding in order to fund the capital works commitments of those organisations. Interestingly, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) made this very point. We are saying that when the Government looks at the guidelines it must look much more closely to make sure there are not abuses of the scheme. There needs to be greater scrutiny of programs approved for funding in order that the abuses which have been illustrated do not continue, or at least are kept to an absolute minimum.

Let us leave aside for a moment the abuses of the scheme. I would like to return to the issue I raised earlier concerning the guidelines under which employment of CEP funded programs is gained. The Liberal Government in my home State of Tasmania-a government which was recently resoundingly re-elected under the fairest electoral system anywhere in the world-has instituted a remarkably innovative scheme to assist the unemployed youth of George Town. The scheme is to be known as the Tasmanian community service program and will essentially operate as follows: The State Government will pay young unemployed under the age of 21 the equivalent of the unemployment benefit in return for two days of community service. On the other five days of the week, those unemployed will be free to engage in whatever leisure or work activities they so desire. Technically, these people will no longer be regarded as unemployed as far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned. The possible impact on CEP funding for George Town could be serious. I have asked the Minister to consider altering the criteria on which some regional organisations and local government authorities are assessed in order that their eligibility for CEP funding is maintained at current levels. The work undertaken must be additional to the work that local council employees normally perform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad to hear the honourable member for Dobell say `Hear, hear!' because I know he is to speak next. I would like to quote what the Premier, Robin Gray, said when he announced this innovative pilot program pertaining particularly to George Town. I do not believe that there is a program like it anywhere else in Australia. The Premier stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It will give them a sense of community responsibility, self pride and a feeling of identification with their local environment, in addition to providing them with valuable work experience.

The present system of allowing unemployed people to earn only $20 per week before reducing their entitlement by $1 for every $2 earned is ridiculous and does nothing to encourage the person to help himself or herself.

This initiative shows the way and puts the onus on the Federal Government to do more to help unemployed young people to become actively involved in community work while receiving unemployment benefits. I note with interest that the Minister in his second reading speech referred to the Bureau of Labour Market Research, which shows that work experience-that is what this program is aimed at trying to achieve-for young people has a positive psychological effect on them. I am sure that all of us would agree with that.

The unemployed youth of this nation have been sold down the drain by this profligate Government, which deludes itself that $1 billion and a whizz-bang advertising campaign can help the long term unemployed gain employment. The Priority One: Young Australia campaign gets 10 out of 10 for pandering to the enormous ego of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and zero marks for effectiveness. I note that even this morning the Australian Democrats, through Senator Mason, agreed with this assertion. To my knowledge not one person has been placed in employment under the Government's much-vaunted youth traineeship scheme. If we stand for anything in this place we stand for the future of Australia, and what more important future element is there in the Australian community than youth? Until this Government faces the economic realities of the factors which cause unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, no amount of expenditure by it will result in substantial gains being made in long term sustainable employment growth.

In summary, whilst the Opposition supports the extension of the program by three years, it does so with the conviction that this Government is seeking to use an essentially short term relief program in an effort to disguise the fact that it is doing nothing to effect major improvements in Australia's unemployment levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join other members on this side of the House in welcoming the extension of the community employment program for a further three years. When I was elected to this Parliament in 1983 the area I come from, the Illawarra-the great industrial hub of Australia, the area that keeps Australia's industry moving-was reeling after seven disastrous years of Liberal-National Party rule.
—Who was the local member?

—He is now a member of the other House and is still making a lot of noise but doing very little. The steel industry was devastated, as was the coal industry, with all the endemic consequences of mass unemployment and social disruption. Although shortly after coming to office the Hawke Labor Government stepped in with a steel industry plan and saved the steel industry for Australia, the Illawarra still suffers above average levels of unemployment, especially youth unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened to what members of the Opposition have said. No one on this side would argue that the CEP was a panacea for all the unemployment ills of Australia. We know that unemployment is a serious and complex issue. I have never argued that the CEP was a panacea for the unemployment problems of this country. It gives those in the community who are most difficult to place in work an opportunity not only to obtain skills but also, and often of equal importance, to obtain self-esteem and confidence and thus go on to be gainfully employed. The figures show that something like 46 per cent are in full time employment six months after they have participated in a CEP scheme.

Many young people have come to me, many women, many migrants and many Aborigines, some months after they have participated in the CEP scheme. Through that experience they have gained full time employment and they have told me that it was their participation in the CEP project that enabled them to get a job. At the outset, I pay a special tribute to those who have been in charge of the CEP in the Illawarra region. The three Commonwealth organisers are Steve Jolly, Graham Call and Robin Bird. Today it is very fashionable to knock public servants and to make a lot of unfounded criticisms. One often hears this in the House from members of the Opposition. I must say that I have never met three more dedicated people than the three I have mentioned. Over the time the CEP has been operating, I have had a lot of contact with the three officers and they each have a genuine concern for the unemployed and have worked hard for them in the Illawarra. If other members speak to the Federal Government officers who are in charge of CEP in their areas they would echo what I have said.

I have listened to many of the speeches in this debate. I did not think that anything would shock me, but after listening to many of the speeches from members on the other side I have been shocked at the attitude that had been exhibited. The speech by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) revealed nothing but his own ignorance and prejudices. He read a list of projects that he did not particularly like. I wonder whether he checked out any of these projects. I venture to say that he did not check out any of them. Has he followed through any of the CEP projects to see what has been achieved? Has he spoken to any of the people involved? I put this to the honourable member for Parkes and indeed to members of the Opposition: If they are so opposed to the CEP, why do they not have the money returned? But what do they do? They beat a path to the door of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), asking for more and more CEP funding.

If the CEP is such a dreadful scheme- according to honourable members on the other side-why are they involved in it at all? Why do they not just send all the money back if they do not want any of these dreadful socialist CEP schemes in their electorates? No, they beat a path to the Minister's door. They are hypocrites because they will come in here tonight and vote for the Community Employment Amendment Bill because they support it. It will reveal them for exactly what they are-nothing but hypocrites. What they have been saying in the chamber for the last couple of days is nothing but a sham. We on this side of the House know that it is a sham, so do honourable members opposite and so do the people of Australia.

As members of my own political Party know, I have been known occasionally to question some aspects of the CEP, especially as it applies in New South Wales. I might add that I have never questioned the scheme itself. I have always been one of the strongest supporters of the CEP scheme. It has my unqualified support; but like all schemes--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are hiccups.

—As the honourable member for Dobell has said, there are a few hiccups. We on this side of the House have done our best to iron out these hiccups and I believe that we have done so. I admit that I have been known to say in the past that there have been a few too many surveys. In my view, one of the problems with surveys is that they build up in the community expectations that cannot always be fulfilled. We might give a grant of, say $10,000, $12,000 or $15,000 to carry out a survey which rightfully reveals certain deficiencies in the community, but to remedy those deficiencies might take another $200,000 or $300,000. When, for reasons of budgetary constraints, we cannot always come up with the $200,000 or $300,000 we are often criticised for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I also sometimes question the amount of money from the CEP which goes to State government projects. I do not have any evidence to support this, but I suspect that some of our State governments use these funds for services that they should provide out of their own Budgets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Queensland and Tasmania.

—Especially Queensland and Tasmania, as I have been reminded. The problem is that they employ someone who is justifiably needed in the community and then, if that roll-over money is not there, they criticise the Federal Government for not continuing the project. My response has always been, whether in respect of the New South Wales Government or any other government, that if this service is so vital in the community the State government should be providing it. I do not believe that it is the role of the Federal Government to provide money to State governments to do work that the State governments should be funding out of their own budgetary allocations. I would like to see more money going into community projects because I think this is the real benefit of the CEP.

SPEECH.PARA: As people in my Party know, I sometimes worry about the credit claimed for many of the schemes. I must admit that it has not been unknown for even my own Party in New South Wales to claim credit for schemes that have been fully funded by the Federal Government. I think that is a slight oversight on its part, which is being rectified. If it continues to happen I will draw attention to who is providing the funds. Just before Christmas I happened to go past a scheme in Wollongong and I saw a huge sign that the project was funded jointly by the NSW Government and the Wollongong City Council. However, the project happened to be funded jointly by the Federal Government and the Wollongong City Council. I must say that I did have that sign changed within two days.

Having said that, I must say that in my electorate of Throsby there is not one project that I cannot stand up in this Parliament and fully justify. I can justify every project into which money has gone under the CEP scheme in my electorate. I have no problem at all in justifying it, be it a government project, a local government project or, most important of all, a community project. Each project has my strong support. I do take a great interest in the CEP projects. I examine the projects that are submitted through my electorate. I encourage community groups to give me a copy of their submissions and I follow each of them through. I suspect that that is what is missing on the other side. I suspect that honourable members opposite do not follow the projects through, because if they did they would not come in here today and make some of the inaccurate statements that they have made.

Another thing that has not been stressed enough by members on the Opposition benches is that it is not only the individual who benefits from the CEP, it is the community. In my electorate the community has been provided with many, many facilities. Also in the electorate of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) many, many excellent facilities have been provided. These community facilities would not have been provided without the CEP projects. In my electorate of Throsby I have had 147 projects. I hope that my colleagues on this side will not be envious when I tell them the amount of money which has gone into my electorate. They should remember that my electorate has above average unemployment. It is an area that was devastated by the previous Government and left with high unemployment. Since the Hawke Government came to power $6,710,825 has gone into the Throsby electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Almost $7m. It has been a very generous allocation and I do thank the Minister most sincerely for that. Among the projects in my electorate there has been the usual street beautification-which we needed. There was a small group called Smart which built a mud brick workshop, an excellent project, at Kiama. An old pilot's cottage that was going to be turned into a fish and chip shop has been restored.
—No!

—It was going to be turned into a fish and chip shop but the local historical society came to see me about it and it eventually got the money out of the Council. The historical society told me that it required funds for this building program. I suggested the CEP project, it put in for it, and I think it got $180,000 to restore that cottage, which is now a showpiece in Kiama. It is floodlit in the evenings. It has been restored and it is now used by the community. Without the CEP, that would not have occurred, because the local council would not have had the money to do it. The Council could not have afforded to do it. Now we have this wonderful pilot's cottage in Kiama. It is a gem in a town full of gems.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the CEP we have put a lot of money into the grounds around Bowral Hospital and into cycleways. I have heard a lot of criticism about cycleways. Indeed, in the early days I questioned them until I saw how people used them. I do not know about other members, but the people in my area actually use them. People cycle on them with their families. They cycle all through Kiama and Shellharbour, all the way from Albion Park across to Warilla--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they wear helmets?

—With helmets, but not enough of them, I am afraid. Many of them use helmets. The families use these cycleways. That is another thing. The Opposition talks a lot about the family. One of the great things we have done under the CEP is bring families together out cycling on these cycleways that we have put in. We have put money into the Illawarra light railway museum-a particular interest of mine-to preserve part of Australia's heritage. There they are preserving early engines and things like that. I am sure that the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) would be very interested in that. Only the other week it was announced that the Kiama pony club was to receive $20,000 to do some work there. The pony club does a lot of work providing riding for the disabled. All these schemes in my area and in other members' areas have a tremendous community benefit. I am very sorry about the attitude of the Opposition. Whatever schemes its members do not like they immediately label as left wing. I have never heard of so many left wing projects as I have over the last couple of days.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed the other day that the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), who has now left the chamber, claimed that the money would have been more effectively spent by the private sector. I do not know how he can make that claim. The CEP has been the biggest job-generating scheme in Australia. I urge honourable members opposite to follow through their schemes more closely. I know that the honourable member for Parkes said that the councils in his area were not in favour of the CEP. They are certainly different from the councils in my electorate which are all very much in favour of it. Perhaps the honourable member should have discussions with the councils in his electorate and see what their opposition is because if the councils in his electorate do not want the money, the councils in my electorate most certainly can do with it.

I compliment the Minister and his staff for what has been achieved with the CEP. I am proud to be a member of the Government that is trying to do something about the unemployed in this country. We have never claimed that the CEP is the panacea for all unemployment problems, but at least it is doing something about them. It is giving the unemployed the confidence, skills and self-dignity to take their place in the work force. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) throughout his speech overlooked whether the community employment program was successful in terms of its objectives. I make it very clear that the Opposition will not oppose the Community Employment Amendment Bill. We have said that we would not tackle unemployment in this way but in other ways. Since this is a government program, the Government can continue to tackle it in this way if it wishes, but we shall point out the failure of the program. That is the general thrust of the Opposition's contribution to the debate. Naturally, if a group of my constituents come to me with a project which they hope will attract CEP funds, I will support that group because that it is the way that funds are made available. If my local councils come to me for support, I will support them, the more so since the Hawke Government took away from local government the automatic 2 per cent share of income tax that it had under the Fraser Government. It is not surprising that local governments have to resort to this sort of program, given their treatment from the Hawke Government in general financing.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government came to power in 1983 on a slogan of jobs, jobs, jobs. The people have been given words, words, words. The community employment program was supposed to tackle long term unemployment. It was a make-work scheme, particularly for those who had been out of work for some time. The actual success of this scheme is revealed in the second reading speech of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) which shows that in the terms that the Government has set for itself, the scheme has been a failure. The Minister referred to the community employment program as a highly successful one. He referred to the large number of people who had been unemployed for nine months or more in November 1983. He then said:

This represented a tragic waste of human and economic resources which the Government was determined to address through special measures designed to improve the employment prospects of these disadvantaged job seekers and enable them to share in the benefits of general economic recovery. The community employment program was our major response in this area.

At an earlier stage in this debate, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) had incorporated in Hansard a table which referred to the average duration of unemployment by age in Australia. That table appears on page 775 of the House of Representatives Daily Hansard of 18 February 1986. It shows that from June 1983, three months after the Government came to power, until June 1985 when it had been in power for more than two years, long term unemployment had risen on average from 41.4 weeks to 50.3 weeks, an increase in the average duration of long term unemployment of two months. This scheme had then been in effect for two years. It shows that the position for youth had improved only marginally and that for those aged 15 to 19 years, the number of weeks unemployed on average had dropped from 31.9 to 30.3-a welcome drop, but small. It shows that in the next age group, those 20 to 24 years, the number of weeks unemployed on average had risen from 41.9 to 46. Worst of all, it shows that for those aged over 25 years the number of weeks unemployed on average had risen in those two years of the Hawke Government from 45.5 to 60.5 weeks. That was some achievement, some result, for the Government's major response to long term unemployment.

One would not even have to rely on the honourable member for Tangney to supply those figures. The Minister gave us figures in his speech and made statements which damn the success of this program and damn the Government and its major response to long term unemployment. I refer further to the Minister's speech on this Bill to continue the CEP program for another three years. He says:
The decision to continue CEP is based on both evidence of the continuing need to assist the long term unemployed and other disadvantaged groups-
a continuing need, after three years in government. He goes on:
The continuing need for assistance for the long term unemployed is reinforced by short term projections undertaken by my Department which show that even under optimistic scenarios-
and heaven knows the Government is pretty good at inventing them-
for economic and employment growth the total number of long term unemployed persons is not expected to fall significantly as a percentage of total unemployment over the next two to three years.

It has had three years in government, we have had three years of this so-called major response to the problem of long term unemployment, and according to the Minister the figure will not fall significantly for another three years. The dramatic facts are contained in this part of the Minister's speech:
The average prior duration of unemployment amongst all CEP participants to date is 58 weeks and 70 weeks for those placed during this financial year.

If this program were having any real effect, we would expect the average length of prior unemployment to drop. Instead, as the figures in the table that the honourable member for Tangney had incorporated in Hansard show, the average length of hard core unemployment in this country is rising dramatically under this Government. That is the response to the major response of the Government. The length of time unemployed people spend in the queue to get employed under CEP projects is growing despite the program. One would think that the Government would look at this program and the $1.1 billion allotted to it and think that perhaps this has not been the appropriate result. That is what the Opposition has been saying; I point that out to the honourable member for Throsby. In its own terms, the program has failed to reduce long term unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you take the money.

—Of course I take the money. I care about the unemployed in my electorate. If that is all that is offered, of course I will help people in my electorate to get it. But I would rather they were offered goods that were not so shoddy. The situation is that 47 per cent of those who have been employed under this program are still in work six months later. Some skills they have been equipped with! Some state of the economy! The honourable member for Throsby would be wise to remain silent.

SPEECH.PARA: At the beginning of his second reading speech the Minister referred to the CEP as `the highly successful program'. But the facts show otherwise. He said in his speech:
The success of the CEP has ensured that it will remain an important part of the Government's overall strategy for assisting unemployed persons.

That should make unemployed people's blood run cold, particularly if they are in the average category of having been unemployed for 60.5 weeks-the average at June 1985, more than two years after the Hawke Government came into power. More and more unemployed people, as their length of time unemployed lengthens, will remember that this occurred entirely under a Labor government.

We have heard much from other Government Ministers, notably the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), about education programs that are supposed to do something about employability. The effect, if it is there, has been marginal. If it is there, it is only for those now in education and training; it is not there for those who are older and might need to seek it.

I have to refer, if only briefly, to another part of the Minister's speech in view of the things that this Government keeps saying about its policies on women. Yesterday, an affirmative action Bill was brought into this House and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) praised himself at great length for his attitude and the Government's attitude towards women. However, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations stated in his speech introducing this Bill:

One of the most outstanding achievements of the CEP has been its success in meeting its objective of equal female representation in jobs created under the program. The CEP was the first labour force program to take up the challenge of the Government's equal opportunity policy in this way.

I interpolate that it is the first Labor Party labour force program to take up the challenge in that way. The work creation program that was under way under the Fraser Government as a result of the wage pause program had the same objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not the same results.

—As the Minister knows very well, it was not in force for very long. We will see how long it has taken this Government to make some progress. It has been in office for three years. The Minister's speech continued:

SPEECH.PARA: To date the overall participation of women in the program has been 38.6 per cent. This includes the Jobs on Local Roads component which initially did not have a target for women. If this component is excluded then the overall participation rate for women on projects approved to date is 42.7 per cent and on projects approved in 1985-86 it is 52.6 per cent. In 1985-86 the target of a 25 per cent placement rate for women on the Local Roads component is actually being exceeded by 5 per cent.

To that I say: `Hip, hip, hooray!'. Why did the Government not do it in the first place? If the Government has that attitude towards women and claims that the objective has been there from the beginning of the CEP, why did it not have an objective in the initial program? The female employment figures were so bad in the early program that it has to take out that part to lift its female employment figures up to target. The increase, the excess over target that the program is now achieving, shows that it should have been there all the time. My local authorities have talked to me about the subject of female employment in their works programs, which include roads. They have had no difficulty in meeting their quotas. I am surprised that Senator Ryan had the difficulty she obviously had to get the Government to live up to its fine words of March 1983. However, the improvement is welcome.

Let it not be said that the Opposition does not care about long term unemployed people; that it did not have policies on employment and training in the last election to meet the problems. They are detailed policies, real policies, on training programs. They are spelled out in detail. The objectives of those programs are very different from the objectives of the Hawke Government and its make-work program under CEP. Our objectives are to give young people basic competencies, if they lack them, in literacy and numeracy if that is needed, in work skills and even in such basic things as how to present oneself for a job interview. It is a long range program. It could be long term, tailored to the needs of the individual person.

I said in my maiden speech that one of the things that concerns me about CEP is that, whilst it certainly takes young people off the dole and puts them on to wages and gives them work habits, which is good, it is not necessarily giving them training that is worth anything to them after the project finishes. By its nature, projects are required to be as labour intensive as possible. I say to the honourable member for Throsby that, whilst there are projects in my electorate that are very worth while, they are being done in a way that no contractor would proceed if there were any competitiveness about it and if cost containment were an object. Those involved in the projects say that they are being forced to employ techniques and to train young people in techniques that are no longer used and have not been used for years and years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since they built the pyramids.

—It is a little more recently than when the pyramids were built, but some decades in some cases. It would be far more to the point if the Government looked at this aspect of the program and made it more effective in terms of giving young people training for employability after the project has finished-something higher than the 47 per cent who are still in employment six months after finishing the program.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the Bill. It hopes that it will do some good. It believes that it is not doing the good that it should be doing and certainly rejects totally that it is doing anything like the job claimed for it by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986 presented to the House by the most successful Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in the post-war era, Ralph Willis. The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who has just concluded her remarks, destroyed her credibility somewhat when she said early in her speech that the Government had talked of jobs, jobs, jobs but with no result. The result is that, since the Labor Government has been in office in the last three years, over 608,000 jobs have been created by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The community employment program, since its inception in the 1983-84 financial year, has been one of the most important and successful initiatives of this Government. It is one of the initiatives which have turned the atmosphere of doom and gloom in employment in the Fraser years to a situation in which the Government has managed to reduce the level of unemployment in this country from the double digit figure of 10.4 per cent in 1983 to the current rate of 7.8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were incompetent.
—As my colleague says, they were incompetent.
—They still are.

—They still are; that is why they will remain in opposition for a mighty long time to come. This figure of 7.8 per cent is still much too high. We on this side of the House recognise that; we want to reduce it and with our policies we will reduce it. But we must remember that when we came to office in March 1983 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised that we would create 500,000 jobs in the first three years of office. Members of the Opposition, bereft of both ideas and talent, scoffed at the Government at that time and ridiculed the promise. Now, as I have said, they can eat their own words because this Government has not only exceeded that 500,000 jobs in less than three years but also exceeded the target by something like 108,000 to the end of January 1986. These figures show an employment growth of 3 1/2 per cent in 1985-86. They clearly illustrate the strong economic growth in this country. The target of 500,000 jobs has been exceeded by more than 20 per cent in less than three years. There is no doubt that the community employment program has played an important role in assisting the creation of jobs, thus reducing unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: The projects themselves-this has been spoken of by a number of my colleagues on this side of the House and, in fairness, by some honourable members on the other side of the House-have been of social and economic benefit to the community. In my own electorate of Moore in Western Australia-which I repeat is the fastest growing electorate in Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —With a good member.
—And it has a good member; I accept that.
—Modestly.

—Very modestly, I add. The electorate of Moore has received community employment funds of the order of $5 1/4m. That is not as much as the amount received by the electorate of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) but obviously, with a higher rate of unemployment in this area, his electorate must take precedence over mine. These funds have benefited the shires in my electorate as well as the newest city in Australia, the city of Wanneroo-a city with a population of 128,000 people. I take this opportunity of publicly thanking those officers and councillors in the shires and that city who have co-operated with me and my electoral staff in expediting these projects. We have heard quite a lot of names from various electorates mentioned in the course of this debate. I mention Mr Norm Wallace, who is the Shire Clerk of Gingin. Gingin is a very small shire, with only 2,000 or 3,000 people, but Norm Wallace is a man of initiative. He saw the benefits to be gained from the old regional employment development scheme and he used funds from that scheme to benefit his community. Today we see a lovely park in the centre of Gingin which is a credit to his imaginative nature. He has continued to use these funds to benefit the shire and he deserves to be congratulated.

SPEECH.PARA: Importantly the number employed through these initiatives in the electorate of Moore totals 489 persons, of both sexes, some of whom were in the long term unemployed category and/or were suffering from social and other disadvantages. A number of these persons have been offered full time employment at the completion of the projects. A recent survey of participants in the program showed that 40 per cent of a sample of 600 people had a job six months after leaving the program. Of these, 82 per cent had full time jobs. These figures prove that the community employment program does more than provide temporary work for the unemployed. It is more than a band-aid; it gives the unemployed a real opportunity to obtain full time employment. The Bill before the House implicitly recognises the worth of the community employment program by the simple expedient of increasing its life by three years. It would be quite easy for the Government in a cost cutting exercise to say: Right, we have given the program a try and that is the end of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ripped $200m off in the mini-Budget last year.

—Just listen, my friend. What we have is a government that does care about the unemployed, a government that is prepared to accept that the CEP has been successful in its first three years and is extending its life for another three years. No doubt in 1989 a further decision will have to be made as to whether to continue the program or to wind it up. My preference at this point is for the program to continue because I consider that the community-I repeat, the community-has benefited from the program in so many diverse ways. Whilst I am a strong supporter of the community employment program, I support those honourable members who feel that not enough recognition has been given by State governments to the fact that this is a Federal Government funded initiative. I have heard in the past from my colleague the honourable member for Throsby how frustrating it is for members of this House to hear of initiatives in which they played a part in bringing to fruition being claimed by State governments as State government initiatives. But as the honourable member for Throsby said in his most excellent speech, this matter is being attended to. I know that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who is at the table, is looking closely at this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Another problem of a quite different order relates to the duration of projects. One of the criteria states that the projects must create positions for a minimum period of three months and a maximum period of one year. This criterion creates two problems, the first of which is a build up of expectations in the community if the project is related to social welfare and the person is employed to provide a service. At the end of the 12 months, unless the project sponsors can continue to employ that person out of their own financial resources, that person loses the position and his or her expertise is lost to the community and the service previously provided ceases unless alternative funds are provided. The other problem relates to fairly big projects which cannot be completed in 12 months. This often leads to a project being split into separate parts and the sponsoring organisation seeking funding for one part and then on completion seeking a grant for the next part. I do not see anything wrong in that approach and in fact have urged sponsoring organisations to do just that. However, because of the limited funds available, alternative worthwhile projects may miss out. I appreciate that the only answer to that problem is to increase the funds available for community employment programs. However, in view of the tight budgeting considerations for the coming financial year I am sure that that is not likely, although I am sure that the Minister would like to see it happen.

I have agreed to curtail my remarks to allow other members to participate in this debate. I wish to say once again that I strongly support the Bill and I commend the Minister for his initiative in this direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably appropriate to remind the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) that the Government slashed $200m of the community employment program expenditure last year. That very act in itself was a form of judgment on its effectiveness. It has always been my philosophy on these types of projects and programs that, while it is there, be in it. I was in this Parliament in the days of the regional employment development scheme. The Whitlam Government introduced the scheme and abandoned it after one year because of what was going on. A lot of creative things were left in the community as a result. That is happening now and I do not dispute that for one moment. I lend my entire weight to groups in my electorate who make applications for a grant because that is not inconsistent with my view that, while the scheme is there, be in it. The community should get as much out of it as it can, whether it be a new library building, halls, or beautification programs. If the scheme gives people employment, that is a good thing.

SPEECH.PARA: My own record in this field was my suggested work program, which unfortunately the Fraser Government decided to implement in mid- December 1982 and a month later abandoned. It was a scheme whereby the Commonwealth would pay an unemployment benefit direct to a local government authority and that local government authority would match the unemployment benefit. They would take the hourly wage rate applicable to the type of job that a person undertook and divide it into the total amount of money. If it provided a person with 24 hours or 25 hours work a week, it was far better for that person's morale than to be sitting at home doing nothing. I have always subscribed to the view that it is better for people to be out there doing something than doing nothing. I also accept that it can be very demoralising to be out of work for a long time, and that is why this program is being retained.

The very fact that the Hawke Government is bringing in this legislation to extend the program for another three years is an admission that it does not see itself as being able to beat long term unemployment. The fact that the Community Employment Act has been in place for three years and will go for another three years is really the Australian Labor Party Government saying: `We cannot beat it'. We sit in this chamber day after day and listen to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-and occasionally, when he is asked a question, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who is at the table-haranguing us and telling us how well the Government is doing in terms of unemployment. I will give the Government some good marks. It is able to claim that over 600,000 new jobs have been created. That is a fact, but when we examine the jobs we find that a lot of them are part time and, furthermore, a lot of them are in the public sector, whether they be doctors, nurses or just plain public servants. The well-being of this nation, the future of this nation, and the elimination of unemployment are more bound up in the recovery of the private sector, where real jobs are created, than simply in the creation of jobs in the public sector. This nation's recovery will be in the private sector, whether in the manufacturing industry, out on the farms, or in the little corner stores where additional people are taken on. That is where the recovery lies. The Government should not simply pluck out a figure and say: `We have created over 600,000 jobs'.

I am about to show that this Government is really being very loose with the truth in terms of its performance in the unemployment arena. I see that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is smiling. I give the Minister his due; he has a reasonable sense of humour. I concede that the number of unemployed people has fallen; that is indisputable. What is the history of unemployment in this country? In 1981, 400,000 people were out of work for an average of 34 weeks. In 1982 that figure had risen to 480,000 and that is why the people got so restless with the performance of the Fraser Government. But they were still out of work for 34 weeks. Come 1983, when there was a change of government, that number had rocketed to almost three-quarters of a million, or 725,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—The honourable member should not laugh; it was not funny for the people who lost their jobs. The unemployment figure had rocketed to 725,000 and, worse still, the average number of weeks for which people were unemployed had grown to 40-39.9 to be exact. This meant that in 1983, when the Fraser Government was turned out by the people of Australia and the great white hope, Mr Hawke, came marching in, 29 million weeks work had been lost by the nation and by the unemployed in this country. The smugness that we see on the faces of honourable members on the other side of the House as they push down people's throats how well they are doing is ripped apart as we examine the figures for the following year. In 1984 the unemployment figure of 725,000 had fallen to 630,000. Great! The Government had created jobs out there. The facts are that the weeks for which those people were out of work had grown from 40 to 48. Instead of a loss of 28 million weeks work we had a loss of 30 million weeks. As at 30 June last year the number of unemployed had fallen to just below 600,000 but the number of weeks that people are out of work has increased to 52 weeks per person on average. This means that the number of weeks unemployment that people are suffering has grown to in excess of 31 million in total. Let me tell those people who do not know where these figures come from that they come from the Bureau of Statistics. I must acknowledge the Bureau in view of the fact that I give it a touch-up from time to time. Some of its work is most useful. This exposure of the figures really tears apart the claims of the Government that it is doing so well. Certainly the numbers of unemployed are down, but people are out of work for longer. It is almost as if it is easy for the Government to forget them, to no longer worry about them, because the figures are looking good. Members of the Government can get up and beat their chests and say `600,000 new type jobs have been created and unemployment is down', but the truth is that the level of suffering for those who are unemployed in this country is greater than it has ever been in this nation's history.
—What about--

—The honourable member will get a go later tonight. I ask her to leave me alone so that I can continue with my effort. I will be a little more detailed on just what is happening across Australia. Incidentally, all the figures to which I have referred previously are as at 30 June each year. The following figures have come from the Bureau of Statistics in the last day or so and are for the period November to November. I shall deal with figures for each of the States for November 1983 to November 1985. In Tasmania-no wonder the Labor Party down there was annihilated-the average number of weeks of unemployment has gone from 53 weeks to 64 weeks. In South Australia, where unfortunately these types of figures were not used, the number of weeks unemployed has grown from 52 1/2 to 56 1/2 in those two years. In New South Wales, the State with a number plate that calls itself the `Premier State', the number has gone from 48 to 56 weeks a year. In Victoria, it has gone from 42 to 46 weeks a year, in Queensland from 35 to 39 weeks a year and in Western Australia it has stayed the same at 38 weeks a year. All these figures lead to an average across the nation of 52 weeks a year out of a job, compared with 39 weeks a year when the people thought the Fraser Government was doing so badly that it had to go.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government indulges in the approach: Forget about how much misery those who are unemployed are actually suffering, forget about the fact that their misery is compounding by virtue of the fact that they are unemployed longer term; just beat the drum on the number of new jobs. As I pointed out earlier, those jobs include a great number of part time jobs. The Government grabs at anything to bolster its case. That is understandable. It is no wonder that the public is cynical about politicians. Day after day they get examples of behaviour which allow them to see through the veneer. Occasionally they need a little assistance.

We can look at tonight's Sydney Sun headline: `Petrol, save $520 a year'. These are the things that will save this nation. If the Government gave people back their money and stopped this game of trying to tell them how to spend their money, the economy would recover far better than it will with some of these band-aid schemes we are forced to resort to because of the continuing misery being suffered out there in the community. This newspaper article points out that because of the way the price of oil has fallen around the world, the Hawke Government now has to give back to John Citizen, not five or six cents a litre, but 11 cents a litre. The price of oil has gone down so far that the average person should now be refunded 11 cents a litre-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I realise that in debate we do allow a bit of flexibility, but certainly the price of petrol has nothing to do with the CEP and I ask you to draw the speaker back to the substance of the Bill.
—Yes, I must say I had some doubts about the relevance of the material the honourable member was raising.

—I can well understand that, Mr Deputy Speaker; it is a fairly long bow, but I did not wish to miss the opportunity to explain that if the Government gives people back their money instead of adopting this policy of high taxation, a lot of the unemployment we are trying to alleviate with this program will correct itself.
—Very tenuous.

—It may be tenuous, but it is true. If we were to take a poll on the popularity of my views and those of the honourable member for Canning and I were to tell the people out there driving their cars home that the honourable member for Canning is against people getting back 11 cents a litre, I will bet I would win the poll hands down.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I understand that the use for display purposes of implements such as newspapers is contrary to the Standing Orders and I ask you to ask the honourable member to withdraw that newspaper from use in his speech.

—I withdraw my newspaper. On the community employment program, we all recall how the regional employment development program finished ingloriously in 1975-in about November, I think. The Minister then was Clyde Cameron, a predecessor of the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, who is at the table. Clyde Cameron was a man much respected in this place, even feared by members on both sides of the chamber. The RED scheme fell to pieces because of extravagances and too little accountability. I simply draw that to the Minister's attention. I know that there have been a lot of good CEP projects, well policed and well run, but lest the Minister think that every project was without warts, I have a letter from Queensland which I wish to read into Hansard. I do not think I will achieve a lot by naming the project concerned, so I will not even though the person who wrote the letter would be happy for me to do so. When I received his letter I wrote back to him and asked him whether he was prepared to let me use his name. He said that he would not have written to me in the first place if that were not so. This is what I hope is a rare example of the other side of the CEP. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my intention to complain frivolously or maliciously, nor is it my intention to allow inefficient finance and engineering practice to pass unremarked.

A bright young lad of 56, I have been self-employed most of my working life, and having employed others, I am acutely conscious of the sink or swim necessity of correctly costing work, seeing it efficiently performed, and a margin of profit achieved.

I acknowledged profit motive is a doubtful consideration in CEP work, and the efficiency aspect may not be considered as vital. Simply put, the Government may consider its role is to inject the community with funds allocated to CEP schemes, regardless of other considerations.

In this case the thoughts, health and feelings of the employees of such a scheme are given lip service only. Efficiency, training, inspiration and long-term job prospects are mostly, if not entirely, absent.
This is the view of a 56-year-old man. He continued:

I am in no position to give chapter and verse as to monies misdirected, having worked on one scheme only, and not being privy to the costing of same. However, the following information may be of interest and use to you:

He then gave the name of the job, which I cannot see any point in giving here, but the Minister can learn of it from me privately later. The place concerned employs seven persons, two female and five male. That is very unusual these days. The employees are aged 20 to 56 years. He goes on to say what the wages are. He says what the foreman gets. He notes that only two members have experience at the work, that none have had training on the job, that morale is low and that absenteeism is high. The letter continues:
Immediate past employment history: All except one on social security up to 18 weeks.
Planning errors as seen by those on the job: Job started too early, i.e. before other contractors had completed preparatory work.

Probably this originated in the allocation of a grant, which had to be taken up on or before a certain date. The result being that the CEP team had to fill in time while preparatory work was done. Actual instruction was ``go down in gully and hide.''
Total man days lost because of this and wet weather: 7 persons X 15 days = 105 days, give or take.
I will not read the rest but simply say to the Minister that it is not all silver lining and roses out there.

In the last couple of minutes available to me I want to become a little parochial and relate the figures I referred to earlier to the situation in my region of south-east Queensland. As I said, the Government tells us how marvellous the unemployment situation is. The reality is that the level of unemployment has gone up. I have here figures for weeks lost through unemployment as recorded at CES offices as at September 1983 and weeks lost as at September 1985. The figures for the Annerley CES office in my electorate show that in September 1983, 98,000 weeks were lost through unemployment and this has gone up to 107,000 weeks. At Coorparoo also in my electorate, it has risen from 57,000 to 67,000 weeks. At Mount Gravatt, it has gone up from 117,000 to 129,000. Woolloongabba is the only bright spot but it is an area where the population numbers are dwindling, people are moving out. There the number has gone down from 120, to 105,000 weeks. In Cleveland, in the electorate of the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Keogh), that we heard so much about before, it has gone from 64,000 to 76,000 weeks. In Woodridge it has gone from a massive 201,000 to 260,000 weeks. In Wynnum it has gone from 75,000 to 85,000 weeks. In South Brisbane it has gone from 53,000 to 59,000 weeks. Even in Warwick it has gone from 60,000 to 62,000 weeks. In Ipswich it has gone from 175,000 to almost a quarter of a million, and that is in the electorate of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). If he stayed home he might see what is happening in his home town of Ipswich. In Inala the figure went from 92,000 to 104,000 weeks lost and in Indooroopilly it went from 76,000 to 109,000 weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate a point of order was taken by the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) in relation to an exhibit that the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) was using. While I ruled against the relevance of some of the material used by the honourable member, as I understand it, exhibits can be brought into the chamber for the purpose of emphasising points in debate and, unless they are contrary to the Standing Orders or demonstrate some disloyalty, Speakers have previously allowed such exhibits to be used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity, Madam Speaker, to congratulate you on your appointment as Speaker of this Parliament. It is an excellent effort for a woman to be so appointed, and I hope that we shall reach the time when it will not be necessary to point to the fact that a woman is Speaker and that it will become common-place.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Community Employment Amendment Bill is to extend the highly successful community employment program for a further three years from 1 July-a very sensible decision. It is important from the beginning to put the community employment program into context. The CEP is just one of many programs introduced by this Government to attack the high level of unemployment caused by the restrictive economic policies of the Fraser Government, which brought this country to its deepest recession for some 50 years. The Government was elected to turn around the economy, to create employment through growth without inflation-a promise we made and, as I will point out, a promise we have kept.

It is through our expansionary macroeconomic policies that we have created employment and turned the economy round. In fact, we set out to create what seemed to be an impossible target-certainly the Opposition criticised us for having an impossible goal-and that was to create half a million jobs in three years. The results are well known: 600,000 jobs indeed, 100,000 more than our target, have now been created and we are still two weeks short of the end of our third year in government since 5 March 1983. Employment has grown 3.8 per cent, which is the best of any Western industrialised country. Unemployment is down from 10.2 per cent at the end of the disastrous years of the Fraser Government to under 8 per cent. Inflation has been reined in from more than 12 per cent to around 8 per cent. All this has been achieved without industrial unrest. In fact, disputes are at their lowest level for 17 years.

We have always said that economic growth and activity were the answer to unemployment-the generator of jobs. Yet not all these jobs have been made in the public sector. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) alleged that we had created jobs in the public sector and not in the private sector. I would point out that after the kick start with an increase in infrastructure spending in the public sector by the Government the private sector gained confidence. Now more than seven out of 10 new jobs are indeed created in the private sector. The honourable member for Moreton also said that most of the jobs created were part time. In fact, eight out of 10-80 per cent-of the jobs are full time.

It is not good enough for the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) to bleat, as he did in this House on Tuesday, that it is the private sector that creates employment. These are words, words, words. It is rhetoric without any sincerity. It is this Government that has the runs on the board. It was the Liberal-National Party Government which sacked worker after worker in the private sector, sending thousands of workers on to the dole as the private sector suffered at the hands of these economic vandals. The Opposition has never accepted that Australia is a mixed economy, that the private and public sectors are synergistic-that is, they help and reinforce each other. Neither can get our economy going on its own; each needs the other. In fact the community employment program recognises this fact. The funds that come through this program go to local government, State government and community groups, and the private and public sector. It is a tragedy that the honourable member for Tangney, when in 1983 the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) gave him an involuntary holiday, did not gain in that 18-month holiday some empathy for the unemployed and a greater understanding of the causes of unemployment.

The community employment program has a specific function: It is to zero in on the long term unemployed, to tackle the special difficulties facing long term unemployed people. Those people were almost forgotten by the Opposition when it was in government. Let us go back to when the Opposition was in government. At the end of its term, in mid-1983, a quarter of a million long term unemployed-that is, 41 per cent of the total unemployed-had been out of work for more than nine months. It is well known to anyone who has bothered to stop, talk and discuss the problems of the long term unemployed with them that the longer a person is out of a job the greater the loss of skills and confidence and the more reluctant are the employers to take them on. Their low self-esteem slumps further. Employers treat them almost as a dead loss if they should ever make a face to face interview.

The purpose of the community employment program is to break the unemployment cycle prolonging the misery and bleak future of the long term unemployed by employing these people-often women, Aboriginals, disabled and mature age people-on community based projects for a period of six months so they can acquire skills, regain their confidence and be able to approach an employer with a recent job record and references. That is what employers are looking for. That is what CEP is all about. That is why people go on and get jobs. The Opposition wants the guidelines to be changed. The National Party said that we should not be looking at the long term unemployed-the women, Aboriginals and so on. We should be looking at able-bodied people so that the projects can get off the ground. That is not the purpose of the CEP.

The results have been outstanding. Over three years, with the $1 billion committed, we have had 16,000 projects creating job opportunities for 87,000 people. Sixty-two per cent of all the program placements were long term unemployed; that is, people who had been unemployed for more than nine months. In the year past, the figure increased to 77 per cent. Almost four out of every five people have been long term unemployed. The average length of their prior unemployment was 58 to 70 weeks-that is, 13 to 18 months without work. The people we are looking after are those who have not had a job for over a year. I believe that is the reason the program is reaching the core of long term unemployment.

Despite our economic upturn, our successes in getting unemployment down, there are still 92,000 people who have been unemployed for more than two years and 210,000 people who have been unemployed for more than nine months. The program has helped to achieve a reduction of 50,000, or a quarter of this category, over the last two years. This is why the program must be extended for three more years. That is the purpose of this legislation. That will mean new job opportunities for many more; another 75,000 if the success rate is continued.

The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) tried to argue that the community employment program had failed because the average duration of unemployment had increased from 40 weeks when the Opposition left office to 52 weeks two years later. That allegation was repeated by speakers on the other side time and again, with particular ferocity by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the last speaker before the suspension of the sitting, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron).

There is a saying that there are lies, damned lies and statistics. I want to spend one moment on explaining how the statistics the Opposition has used have been misrepresented in this Parliament. In fact, I will take the Opposition's statistics and show that they are proof that the unemployment defeating policies of this Government are working. The figures demonstrate the success of the Government's overall employment promotion policies. As the economy prospers more and more people, mainly those who have just left school or have recently been unemployed, are snapped up by employers. Unfortunately, those who have been unemployed the longest are not so successful, even though the program is assisting them. As the total number of the unemployed drops, it is obvious that the average length-this is what the Opposition is concentrating on; the average length, not the individual length-of unemployment increases dramatically. It does not fall, as honourable members opposite would like it to. It increases when there is success. The sign of success is our overall attack on unemployment. We should not look at averages, we should look at the absolute inroads we have made into long term unemployment. The increasing duration of unemployment exposes the statistical legacy of the previous Government's policies, which resulted in an unemployment rate of 10 per cent in February 1983-a mammoth increase. The absolute number of long term unemployed-those unemployed for nine months or more-has fallen by around 50,000 since December 1983.

The honourable member for Menzies also used a spurious argument on statistics-lies, damned lies and statistics-when he said that in 1980 the unemployment rate for teenagers was 16.6 per cent, but that we had increased it to 18.2 per cent by 1985. That is the second time in this debate that the Opposition has used statistics in a spurious manner to mislead the Parliament. Let me explain. What the honourable member did not say was that the previous Government was still in office in 1983 and had increased the rate of teenage unemployment to 28 per cent. We have reduced it from 28 per cent to under 20 per cent, according to his figures.

`There is a need to cut wages for youth'-this is the catchcry of the Opposition. The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) said it. This morning he said that the best gift we could give our youth would be to cut their wages, that is, to employ them at slave rates, to tell them that they are not worth a proper wage. No wonder the youth of Australia are turning away from the Liberal and National parties. The answer for youth is not underpayment, but job opportunities. That is what the CEP Priority One program and the general increase in economic growth are achieving. Is it any wonder, when the Opposition's only contribution towards solving the unemployment problem is to call for a deregulation of wages, to drive them down, that the business councils of this country have turned their backs and given the thumbs down to the Opposition?

Sixty-seven projects for my electorate of Streeton have been approved, at a cost of $6.2m, and 485 jobs provided. That means that nearly 500 people whose job expectancy was virtually nil will now have a chance. It means that $6m will be injected directly into the local economy. People spend where they live and work. So we get the multiplier effect, which is that the extra employment created by these jobs when the employed spend their incomes in turn employs other people.

The Opposition tried to discredit the projects funded under the CEP, picking out a minute number of the total of 17,000 and alleging-to quote the honourable member for Menzies once again-that `the money is being used simply to promote a cause, and one side of the cause at that'. The cause that Opposition members derided, the cause that worried them the most and gave them nightmares, was, of all things, peace and disarmament. National Party members particularly were worried about a peace bus. It really sent them mad, made them angry. If they want the opposite side, the reverse, they must be arguing, therefore, for war and an escalation of the arms race. How out of step they are when this year is the United Nations International Year of Peace and Gorbachev and Reagan are seeking ways of reducing the arms build-up. Peace, I remind the Parliament, is not a left wing cause. It is everybody's cause. Honourable members opposite are so out of step that I suggest it is they who have missed the bus.

Where the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) got the delusion that all CEP money goes to radical groups, I do not know. I can suggest only that it was an invention of his fertile imagination. The facts are that, overwhelmingly, the funds have been channelled to State governments and local governments, and about 20 per cent of the funds have gone to responsible and worthy community groups.

I had intended to outline some of the projects in my electorate but I will skip that because the time is passing. One of the most successful CEP projects is the restoration of the railway line between Lilydale Coldstream and Healesville in my electorate. That railway line passes through not only my electorate but also that of the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). Yet in the debate this morning he said that he thought that the money spent on the CEP since its introduction in mid 1983 would have been much more effective in creating jobs had it been provided to the private sector. His Government never did that when it was in power. It set up the wage pause, but he wants to discredit even that. Yet after meeting with the Healesville Council he was persuaded-and I do not know whether it was arm twisting or reason that got him to do it-to support the program's fund for the restoration of the railway line. Does he now, in this Parliament, deny that support? Does he stand with his colleague, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who said that it would be better to have these long term unemployed people on the dole in order to save money and that it was cheaper to forget their plight? Does he agree with the honourable member for Tangney that job creation schemes are morally corrupt? The honourable member made that statement to the New South Wales University in July last year. Where does the honourable member for Casey stand? He stands up here and ridicules the program, yet when he comes face to face with councillors he supports it.

Indeed, it is puzzling why the Opposition is nit picking with this Bill. Opposition members say they will not oppose it. According to the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), they agree with it in principle but all they have done is attempt to discredit the scheme. Have they forgotten that the Fraser Government, in a death bed conversion, introduced the wage pause program as a job creation scheme? Perhaps that Government was guilt ridden over the number of people it had put out of jobs with its disastrous economic policies. Do Opposition members not realise that the CEP is a great improvement but nevertheless is of the same ilk as their job creation scheme? There is no doubt that the community employment program is worth while. Rather than disparaging it with erroneous references and spurious statistics, honourable members opposite would be well advised to strongly support it. I will correct a quote made at the very end of the speech of the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb). He should have said that the CEP is a program that is working and that goes on working. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that things have changed a lot since Madam Speaker took up the chair, but I think it is going a bit far to take the hand off the clock. Perhaps, Mr Deputy Speaker, we could have that reinstalled at some time.
—Perhaps the honourable member would care to glance at the clock on the other side of the chamber.

—Perhaps we could have a CEP project to reinstall the hand on the clock. That would employ a lot of people. The Community Employment Amendment Bill commits the taxpayers of Australia to a cost in excess of $1 billion over the next three years. I believe that the cost of this commitment indicates why such serious consideration has to be given to the reasons why we need a community employment program at all. This program, which is costing well over $1 billion, would not be necessary if unemployment were not as high as it is today, particularly among the youth of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government has had three years to improve our economy. It keeps returning to comparisons between today's unemployment figures and those of the Fraser era. Apart from the fact that everyone in the country is thoroughly sick and tired of hearing this Government drag out figures from the past and compare them with today's, I think it is worth pointing out that the overall economic conditions prevailing today are totally different from those which prevailed in the Fraser era. The previous Liberal-National Party Government had to suffer the worst drought in living memory and this was coupled with a world wide recession. These factors added greatly to the unemployment conditions at the time. Since the Labor Government has been in power the drought was broken, the world economy has picked up and the recession has faded away. To make claims that Labor policies have improved the economy is not entirely correct or fair. Suppose we adopted some of the techniques that the Labor Government has been using and compared figures that went back a little further than just the end of the Fraser Government. In 1979, prior to the drought and the world recession having their effect on unemployment, during the Fraser era unemployment was 5.8 per cent. In 1981 unemployment was 5.7 per cent and in 1982 it was 6.8 per cent. All these figures are better than anything this Government can produce, despite the fact that the drought has broken and despite the fact that the world wide recession has lifted. If one looks back over the years one sees that Labor's unemployment figures today, assisted by the stimulus of the breaking of the drought and assisted by the stimulus of the lifting of the world wide recession, are dismal. An unemployment rate of 7.8 per cent is 2 per cent higher than the Fraser Government's figures before the drought and the recession.

Let us look back at the reduction in unemployment since Labor has been in power. Undoubtedly there has been a reduction in unemployment; there is no doubt of that. The CEP has contributed significantly to that reduction in unemployment. However, not only has the CEP assisted the reduction in unemployment but the Labor Party's philosophy of big government-bigger government-has also helped. Since Labor has been in office we have seen the size of the public sector increase quite alarmingly. What is blatantly obvious, despite the improved economy during the term of this Government, is that the taxpayer has created many of the jobs that the Labor Government is now taking credit for. The Government should not think that it is fooling anybody by making claims that Labor policies are the sole reason why unemployment has been reduced.

Often as I travel around the electorate of Gilmore people say to me that most of the jobs that the Government is taking credit for are artificially created; most of these jobs are being paid for by the taxpayer. They are being paid for out of the taxpayers' pockets. Just the other day I was reading through the February-March 1986 issue of a publication called Budget Profile and I noticed an article by Mr Bob Ansett, who is the principal of the firm which, I believe, produced the publication. Mr Ansett is recognised throughout Australia as being one of our leading businessmen. He is also recognised as being one of the greatest job creators in this country. Jobs that he creates are real jobs, jobs created not at taxpayers' expense but out of his own initiative, ingenuity and capital. In the article he says that Australia is not doing all that well taking into account that over half of the jobs created over the last few years were in the public sector. Mr Ansett continued:

This of course adds to the tax burden of the private sector and goes part way to explain why business was hit so hard with entertainment, fringe benefits and capital gains taxes at last year's summit.

Not all people are being fooled by the claims of the Labor Government. Some people can see, some people do realise that Labor policies are not creating all of the jobs; it is taxpayer's money that is creating them. How much longer does the Labor Party expect the taxpayer to continue to fork out money to boost its employment figures? All members of parliament must remember that the preservation of the private sector is crucial in any job creation project.
