By introduc- ing a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax and such things as quarantining farm losses, introducing a 3 per cent productivity case and a superannuation scheme to handle that 3 per cent productivity case, which is managed by the union movement and operated by the union movement, the Government is damaging the private sector and will limit the nation's chances of creating real jobs at no cost to the taxpayer.

Conversely, we see jobs being created by this Government at the taxpayer's expense. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) freely admits that it costs about $20,000 a year to create a job through CEP. The taxpayer is being hit very heavily by all the jobs that we hear honourable members on the other side of the House claiming are a great boost to their electorates. When we look at the community employment program I guess, at the very least, we must congratulate the Government for maintaining one of its election promises. Since the Government has been in power we have rapidly got used to the Government not keeping its election promises. It seems that every day we hear Ministers and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saying that the Government will do something and the next day we hear them saying or doing the exact opposite. Broken promises have become the order of the day for this Government. One of the best examples of the standards of honesty which we can expect from this Government is that of a statement made by the Prime Minister in the Labor Party policy speech on 16 February 1983. I think this is one of the best examples of the lot. Mr Hawke said:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

That is what he said. Now we have a capital gains tax. That was a promise made by the Prime Minister; it is a promise broken by the Prime Minister. We have also heard the Prime Minister repeat that performance on several occasions. For example, in November last year the Prime Minister said:
Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from the successful policies of the past 20 months.

What has happened since then? Interest rates have increased. We have record interest rates. If interest rates were to go down as a result of the successful economic policies of the last 20 months the fact that they have gone up surely must indicate that the economic policies of the previous 20 months have been bad and have created the scenario for high interest rates. Petrol prices also have been the subject of a great number of broken promises. One of the best quotations to use is from a statement on 9 February in 1983 by Mr Hawke. He said:
Petrol prices will be immediately cut by about three cents a litre under a Federal Labor Government.

So much for promises! What have we seen? We saw petrol prices increase last year by between 20 to 25 per cent. We saw the fuel freight equalisation subsidy scheme scrapped causing fuel prices in rural parts of Australia to increase by up to 4 cents a litre. All of these broken promises are costing Australians-especially rural Australians-dearly. Rural Australia is in crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 81 concerning relevance.

—I must say that I think it is appropriate to argue by reference to some comparisons but they should not dominate the speech. I ask the honourable member to come back to the discussion of the Community Employment Amendment Bill.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will return. In fact what I was doing was building up the reasons why unemployment is being generated in the rural areas and why the CEP is needed. The crisis in rural Australia is creating unemployment and immeasurable hardship. The CEP will have to be directed more and more towards country areas as unemployment grows in the bush. The Government's refusal to pass on cheaper fuel prices to Australian consumers-reductions in the price of fuel are being enjoyed by people all around the world-is denying Australians the opportunity of cheaper fuel at 11 cents a litre less, I am told. This robbery from the Australian public by this Government is critically wounding the rural industries that rely so much on petrol for their survival.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there would be a saving of $204m if fuel price reductions were passed on. I ask honourable members to imagine how many jobs could be created by having an extra $204m in the rural economy. That could create a lot of jobs and a lot of prosperity. The robbery which this Government is undertaking in regard to fuel prices is critically wounding the rural industries that really rely so much on fuel prices for their costs of production. The Government must pass on these reduced fuel prices to Australians immediately. The Government's broken promises on such things as interest rates are doing just as much harm to the rural economy. If the Government were out of the interest rate market and if it were not playing around with the economy and keeping interest rates up, there would be more jobs in the bush as farmers would have more money to spend.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. It is quite clear that the honourable member for Gilmore is raising matters that are not related to this debate. They are well outside the Community Employment Amendment Bill.

—In an earlier ruling I made reference to some arguments by way of analogy, but one should, in fact, connect those to the topic that is under discussion, the title of the Bill being the Community Employment Amendment Bill. That is the matter that is to be discussed and the comments should be much more closely related to it.

—CEP is a band-aid attempt by the Government to overcome the problems of unemployment. If it is just going to continue to treat the unemployment problem with a band-aid, it is never going to get there. I am trying to point out the real reasons why we need CEP. The reasons why are that this Government is not treating the real issues of unemployment properly. The real issues are that we have a rural crisis and that interest rates are 7 per cent higher than they ought to be. That is taking money out of the productive sector of our economy, a sector which could create real jobs and give real futures to our young Australians. That is what we should be talking about when we talk about unemployment programs for Australia, not about giving band-aid treatment by way of the simple measures proposed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest rates are costing people who are farmers, small business people and people who are trying to build homes a lot of money. Someone who has borrowed $100,000 is paying $7,000 a year extra because of the Government's economic policies. That is $7,000 for every small businessman, every home owner and every farmer that could be used to create a job. Without the high interest rates the CEP budget would not be as high as it is today. We could create real jobs and real futures for young Australians so that we do not have to be here in a few years time talking about the same sort of budget, perhaps even an increased budget, for the same sort of program. The Government is just going for short term political gain at the expense of long term growth and, as I have said, long term real job creation.

If the Government wishes to wind down the cost of CEP in the future, it must reduce those interest rates, it must get fuel prices down, it must scrap such things as capital gains and fringe benefits taxes and it must do away with the quarantining of farm losses. All of these things are going to make the job of creating opportunities for employment in the bush that much harder. The Government must realise this. I know that the people of Australia realise this. If the Government does not follow this course the unemployment situation in rural areas will grow as the rural crisis heightens.

I must admit that it is pleasing to see the CEP has had some positive influence in the cities, towns and communities within the boundaries of the electorate of Gilmore. A number of very worthwhile organisations have benefited from funding under CEP. One which immediately springs to mind in the fair city of Goulburn is a small theatre company called Mustard Seed Productions which has provided a great deal of pleasure to a number of people who have been involved in it-a number of people who, I might add, have some disabilities. The Young Community Arts Centre will benefit from renovations and improvements. In Cowra, the Lachlan Steam Railway Society will continue providing a unique tourist attraction with its beautifully kept steam locomotives. In the Shoalhaven region, a number of projects have helped improve standards of living. One readily thinks of the tennis courts at Lake Conjola, which not only add to the enjoyment of locals but also add to the tourist potential of that region-a most beautiful part of the Australian coastline. Residents of the Royal Australian Navy Base at HMAS Albatross will also enjoy improved landscaping at the cost of $214,000 to the taxpayer.

In mentioning HMAS Albatross, I cannot let this moment go past without pointing out that I am extremely disappointed with the Government's refusal so far to provide adequate funds to put a protective cover over the Navy's Fleet Air Arm museum. As I mentioned in Question Time this afternoon, when I put a question without notice to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), a number of these extremely rare, unique and irreplaceable aircraft are rusting away because there is no roof over them. I am pleased to say that the Minister will look into this matter.

I was disturbed to hear that some people have been offering to buy some of those aircraft. The Sea Fury, for example, is worth in excess of $1m. I hope that the Government decides not to sell these aircraft. I hope that it decides to continue to maintain the museum at HMAS Albatross because it provides a wonderful tourist attraction. It provides millions of dollars worth of tourist income to the Shoalhaven region. As a consequence, the Fleet Air Arm museum will provide many jobs not only to the Shoalhaven region but also to the Illawarra region. When talking about HMAS Albatross I must mention that the air museum exists only thanks to the dedicated services of people such as Lieutenant-Commander Bob Gale and Lieutenant- Commander Ken Alderman and his good wife Judy. They have helped to create this museum and make it a major tourist attraction for the Illawarra and Shoalhaven regions.

The Government must realise that it has a responsibility to protect this valuable part of our history. It must also realise that if it does not do so, we will lose one of the biggest tourist attractions in the Shoalhaven region. Whilst I am sure that the people at Albatross appreciate the grant of $214,000 under the CEP scheme for landscaping, I wonder whether they would have preferred the air museum to get its hangar first and have the landscaping project follow second. The aircraft are rusting away now, whilst the landscaping project could perhaps wait another year.

I fear that we will all be back here in three years time debating the same issue but instead of an outlay of $1 billion-plus we may be debating an outlay of $2 billion-plus for a CEP scheme unless the Government realises that it has to live up to its promises. It has to cut the price of fuel. It has to cut interest rates and get them down to their proper level. It has to allow the dollar to float freely and it has to scrap such damaging legislation as that relating to capital gains taxes, fringe benefits taxes, entertainment taxes and quarantining farm losses. If it does not, we will find in three years time that not only will we have high unemployment and a rural crisis, but also our whole economy will be mortally wounded, and whether we want to or not we will not be able to afford to give any of our young people a job or a future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) had spent four of the last five minutes of his speech on the Community Employment Amendment Bill in elaborating on the theme he dealt with in the final minute, his speech might have been more sustainable and I might have been presented with a larger listening audience as well.
—Would you like a larger audience?

—I mean the radio audience. Before the honourable member for Gilmore leaves the House, I feel that I should mention that his electorate has received just over $6,649,830 in community employment program funds and 730 jobs have been approved under the community employment program. Yet he tells us that that program is not creating real jobs. If, based on the national average, half of those 730 people are now in full time work, that would mean the creation of 365 real jobs. Of course, the members of the National Party of Australia cannot go too far in criticising projects in their own electorates. We have seen evidence of that tonight. That would be the last thing to expect from agrarian socialists.

SPEECH.PARA: The community employment program is a major part of the Government's plan for employment growth. It is also a manifestation of the nation's economic recovery. A wide range of schemes that have been put into operation in south-eastern New South Wales in the electorates of Gilmore, Throsby, Eden-Monaro and the surrounding electorates manifest the nation's economic recovery. Let us consider the Garden trout hatchery in the Snowy Mountains which, not so long ago, was a part time hatchery operated by the New South Wales Government. That Government put a proposal to the Federal Government. Now the Garden trout hatchery is working full time under the community employment program. It created a tourist attraction as well as a hatchery which made trout available to farmers all over Australia. It created real jobs in tourism. One can go there any day, summer and winter, and find large crowds looking over the trout hatchery.

Let us consider the Bermagui water supply. Ten years ago, I was involved in a regional report to a south-east strategy committee set up by the Federal and State governments. The report said that water supplies along the south coast would be severely taxed if something was not done. The Bermagui water supply, as it was operating two or three years ago, was almost non-existent. Tourism was badly affected and Bermagui began to get a bad name, not only with the people who lived there, but also with tourists. Under the community employment program a water supply from Brogo was established. Now the little community, as well as the nearby communities of Quaama and Cobargo, have adequate water supplies from the Brogo scheme.

Aboriginals and women who were employed under that program were taken up full time. One woman has taken up an apprenticeship with a plumber as a result of her work. Four Aboriginals were taken on by the shire council full time. That is creating real jobs. The Wyndham local community decided that it could put in a certain amount of money for a water supply. It came up with a labour intensive program for its development and its program was adopted. It has just been announced that a water supply will be given to the little town of Wyndham.

Water supplies have been upgraded at Captains Flat and Bungendore. A power augmentation scheme was adopted in Cooma under the community employment program. Again, this created real jobs. Honourable members opposite have been telling us that the community employment program does not create real jobs. Every one of these examples has created real jobs following the community employment program. The Aboriginal people at Twofold Bay near Eden came up with a proposal for a strawberry farm. The community employment program has finished, but the strawberry farm is still going, creating real jobs-a real business.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bearing fruit.

—It is bearing fruit, as my friend from Lindsay said. The Narooma community stadium and the Milton basketball stadium were created-real jobs-under the community employment program. Other proposals are coming up. I hope to hear an announcement from the NSW Department of Agriculture about the setting up of a feral animal task force for this region of NSW and eastern Victoria. I am also trying to encourage the Federal Government to come up with a national program for feral animal control. That program creates not only real jobs, but also services. We all know that if exotic diseases get into Australia and come in contact with our fast-moving population of feral pigs-rabies in the case of wild dogs-our primary industries, particularly our meat export industry, could be devastated. If foot and mouth disease came to Australia our meat industries would be virtually stopped. I hope that the Federal Government will adopt that matter as one of its national community employment programs. The main aim of the CEP is to help the long term unemployed. I believe that it has done that. This is the most important thing about the community employment program. It has shown long term unemployed people that they can work without problems of absenteeism and unpunctuality. They can overcome defence mechanisms which they have naturally built up over the years, particularly under the Fraser Government's record of 10 per cent unemployment, defence mechanisms which have almost convinced them that they are unable to work. This has been overcome in so many people through the community employment program. Their self-esteem has been restored. It has created almost 1,000 jobs in the electorate of Eden-Monaro.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only have a substantial number of the long term unemployed been given a chance to gain essential work experience and skills; in my electorate over 60 per cent of people have gone into permanent employment. As I said, projects of a lasting benefit have resulted from the program. I believe that the success of the CEP is a tribute to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the officers in his Department, who have devoted their time and energy beyond the call of duty to ensure its success. I could mention people in my own community-the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has mentioned some of them-Graham Gall, who has been the Area Project Officer, Robyn Bird, who has taken his place, and officers in the Department in Canberra and Sydney, who have shown that they are concerned and that they are always willing to discuss any technical or policy problems.

I believe that local community employment services have made a great contribution to the prestige of the community employment program in Eden-Monaro. They have gone carefully through the people available with the sponsors of the program. That brings me to the sponsors. I know that in many cases the sponsors have found it difficult. Sometimes they have taken a little while to adjust to government policy on employing the disabled, Aborigines and women in what seemed to be manual tasks. Generally they have adapted, and in particular local government has adapted, and I praise local government engineers as well as the other sponsors for the way in which they have adapted to the Government's program and in the end have recognised its value.

Some misconceptions have been raised by Opposition members in this debate. I noticed that one honourable member mentioned that in the three years of the Hawke Labor Government the numbers of long term unemployed have increased. I point out that in regard to people who have been unemployed for nine months or more, the numbers have actually declined by 24 per cent to November 1985. They have not increased; they have declined. Admittedly, the numbers of those who have been unemployed for two years or more have increased, but this has been due to the large number of people held over from the 1982-83 legacy left by the previous Liberal Government, the 1982-83 blowout in unemployment, when the rate of unemployment was 10 per cent. In 1975 the Whitlam Government handed over an unemployment level of below 5 per cent. The Fraser Government handed the Hawke Government an unemployment level of 10 per cent. No wonder a large number of people have been unemployed for two years or more. The fact that the Hawke Government is showing improvement in this area is indicated by the numbers of those who have been unemployed for nine months or more, which have declined by 24 per cent.

I believe that the Liberal Party and the National Party have been unable to dent the armour of the Hawke Government on this issue. Their weapons are blunt because their record was bad. I commend the Community Employment Amendment Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1984, in an address to the Economic Society of Australia--
—I wish to take a point of order. I am sorry to take the time of the House but I will not be long. Before the dinner break, I took a point of order on the honourable member for Moreton--
—I interrupt, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is not on in my speaking time. The honourable member may take that at some appropriate time, but not when I have the call and the clock is running.
—Perhaps the honourable member will take his point of order at the conclusion of his speech.
—I am happy to do that.
—On 26 August 1984, in an address to the Economic Society of Australia in Perth, the then Minister for Finance, now Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins)-he was referring to the Hawke Government-said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government came into office at the bottom of a recession riding on the coat tail of the previous Government's wage pause initiative and at a time when the rural sector was about to swing into a boom year.

The Minister's frankness serves to put his Government's economic performance into a proper perspective today. The Government makes much of its so-called creation of jobs since coming into office. However, the Hawke Government neglects to mention that in the period between September 1978 and September 1981, the Fraser Government added some 466,000 jobs to the economy, and did so without massively increasing government spending or our overseas borrowings. The reality of the situation is that, while some of the credit for the improvement, after a cyclical low in employment figures, is due to the policies of the present Government, and some as the Minister for Trade acknowledged in 1984, is due to the policies of the previous Fraser Government, by far the greater part is the result of climatic, domestic and international developments beyond the control or influence of either of those two governments.

That having been said, there are a couple of aspects in this Bill that are particularly relevant for our consideration. The first aspect is the mechanics of this proposal. I note that there are still areas of concern about the adequacy of the community employment program in ensuring, first, that projects aid those to whom they are primarily directed, that is, the unemployed, rather than merely those who are responsible for the particular project proposals.

Secondly, there are the continuing difficulties in integrating effectively training projects with the CEP. There is also the difficulty involved with the creaming-off at the top as it is described of the unemployed, leaving a substantial number of hard core unemployed people without much hope of CEP assistance. I must also note my reservation about some of the projects, especially those that come under the community organisations criteria for CEP grants. Many odd groups indeed have been on the receiving end of the Hawke Government's generosity. These have apparently included the Campaign for International Co-operation and Development, People for Nuclear Disarmament and a front group for the Italian communist party. Others have been mentioned by my colleagues in the coalition parties, particularly my colleague the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) earlier today. Some concern has also been expressed about the management of some local government projects under the CEP. I note that Senator Jim Short highlighted one such case on Thursday of last week in another place.

The second aspect goes beyond the band-aid approach adopted by this Bill and into the structural problem preventing a return to full employment or something like it in Australia. Let us remember that it is the level of unemployment which is the catalyst for this Bill. Unfortunately, there are no easy answers. Even if the most optimistic predictions of economic growth are fulfilled, the labour market will not permit a rapid return to the low levels of unemployment experienced in the 1960s and early 1970s without major adjustments to current practices.

One of the important areas on the agenda for reform, and there must be reform, is certainly or surely the labour market. As an interim measure, the CEP may be all right, but it is to be continued under this legislation for another three years without tackling the causes of unacceptably high levels of unemployment in general and youth unemployment in particular. All the available economic evidence goes far beyond doubts about youth and adult wages relativities and into an issue at the very heart of Australia's economic and industrial relations system; that is, the regulation of wages by governments and government instrumentalities. The evidence for the proposition that State regulation is an inefficient instrument which has adverse effects on the economy is overwhelming. John Stuart Mill wrote:
If law or opinion succeeds in fixing wages above the rate which results from competition, some labourers are kept out of employment.

The modern treatment of minimum wage laws and their effects has crazy implications for employment and leads to this sort of legislation. The truth is that managing the wage rate through law is an inept device. Nevertheless, empirical research systematically confirms the inevitable outcome of that sort of approach. This shows through time and again when economists come to consider specific issues. For example, researchers have found that increases in the minimum wage affect workers in that they lose more from reduced employer fringe benefits and better working conditions than they gain from higher wages mandated by wages laws. That should be kept in mind in the context of new taxation laws to be framed by this Government in relation to fringe benefits, but that is not central to the point I want to make this evening.

Further research has established that minimum wage standards imposed on the United States retail trade industry in 1981-the study was in 1981, but related to 1961-raised that industry's average labour costs by as much as 5 per cent during the late 1960's resulting in a loss of between a third of a million and half a million full time jobs in that market. This narrowing of labour market opportunities affected teenagers, most severely reducing employment amongst 18 and 19-year-olds in that country by some 9 per cent. There exist irresistible indications that minimum wages do not necessarily result in an increase in the full rate of pay. Fringe benefits tend to be reduced and the training values-this is the point-of jobs is largely eliminated as employers adjust to the rising labour costs. There can be little doubt that minimum wage legislation impairs the employment and compensation opportunities of inexperienced or lower skilled workers, spreading and exacerbating conditions detrimental to the maintenance of minimum standards of living. Lower skilled workers tend to be disemployed when minimum wages are applied uniformly to all industries, as we see in Australia. When minimum wages are applied only in selective industries, higher skilled workers tend to flow into jobs in the covered industries, while lower skilled workers flow into the uncovered industries. The net result can be a mere switching of workers employed in various industries without any overall effect on employment or earnings.

The CEP legislation and the Hawke Government's policies run directly counter to the prospect of higher job opportunities. Minimum wages deprive low wage earners of an opportunity to earn on the job experience by making it illegal for them to receive the lower wage that an employer might offer them, together with training. Our rigid centralised wage fixing system is literally pushing Australians on to the dole queues and into a reliance on contrived stop-gap schemes such as the CEP. In the real world that exists outside sociology seminar rooms, employers are faced with increasing cost pressures and other diverse economic forces. They cannot afford to hire unskilled staff and train them when they are expected to pay wages far in excess of the actual worth of the employee to the business. On the job training, which is traditionally the most acceptable method-because it works-is thus subverted. Wage subsidy schemes of whatever form are a perverse recognition of this reality. After all, if the Government provides $50 or $100 a week subsidy to employers or provides a lump sum through CEP organisations or to State or local governments to hire unemployed people, all it is really doing is subsidising wages downwards to meet the capacity and the willingness of those employers to pay-an action based, I might add, on the utility of the potential employees to the potential employers.

The real answer in the majority of cases is to free up the labour market. If this Government cannot bring itself to do that there must be, at the very least, a sub-minimum wage structure for the young seeking to enter the work force. This is essentially relevant to young people applying for their first job. They lack experience and a proven record in the work place. Employers faced with cost pressures they cannot control have little choice but to minimise their costs by either substituting technology or choosing older workers whose experience has already been demonstrated, or might reasonably be expected, and whose immediate productivity is far higher. Despite the efforts of the Minister for Employment and Industrial relations (Mr Willis) to highlight in his second reading speech the positive aspects of the CEP, there is only limited support for the notion that those employed under the CEP are gaining the necessary experience or obtaining long term work. Far too often experience gained is of doubtful benefit both to the employed and to future employers in the market place. Yet I suppose it must be better than nothing, in the short term, given the Government's unwillingness to tackle key reforms in the labour market that would provide genuine opportunities to the unemployed.

The conventional measure of the minimum wage is distorted and, in my opinion, underestimates elasticity. That is the ever-increasing view of contemporary economists. Although recent studies have focused on minimum wage effects on different types of workers, recent research in the United States presents empirical evidence of the effects on industries showing that the new measure works better than the old one. With the modest minimum wage levels historically imposed the economy-wide disemployment effects are barely discernible. When broken down by industry, however, the employment losses show up more clearly for low wage categories especially in the retail trade. The retail trade is a significant employer in Australia. Within the high wage manufacturing division there are adverse employment effects in the six lowest wage industry groups all over the United States of America. The laws of economics do not respect international boundaries.

Professor David Metcalf, of the University of Kent in England, in his 1981 study found through statistical analysis that British efforts over a 70 year period to establish egalitarian pay policies have done little to improve the lot of low pay workers and have not substantially altered the distribution of earnings in the labour force. Two thirds of the men who were in low paying occupations in 1965 were found to be still there a decade later. Among teenagers, however, less than a fifth failed to improve their occupational status over the decade. One in six full time workers in Britain is lowly paid, as defined in the publication to which I have referred. Most low paid workers are young, single people or married women who typically live in United Kingdom households with more than one earner and are not living in poverty.

While these and other studies show the sort of thing I have been saying, they are independent studies and they confirm the essential point I made earlier; that State regulation is an inefficient instrument which has adverse effects on the economy as a whole and the workforce in particular. If government intervenes to enforce a wage that is higher than that which would appear in competitive markets, a small quantity of labour will be employed in industries in which this higher wage is enforced. The inevitable outcome of that is that sooner or later, for political reasons, that same government will have to subsidise some wages, or finance make-work programs such as CEP, to partially counter the growth in unemployment levels. I believe that it remains extremely unlikely that the CEP can possibly provide an answer to the problem of long term unemployment. That is despite the claims made for it by the Government and its supporters.

As the elected representative of a metropolitan Perth seat it would be easy for me to wax lyrical, as other speakers have done in this place, and quote the amount spent in my electorate. I notice that this has been a device used by speakers from the other side, so I will do it and that will save the next speaker the trouble of doing it. Within Curtin $6,350,993 has been spent and 602 jobs have been provided in 110 projects. I might add that that works out at $10,549.82 per job. That will put that to rest and will save the next speaker from getting up and engaging in the ploy that previous speakers have adopted.

That said, however, I am not confident that enough is being done to foster an economic climate which will see the underlying causes of unemployment successfully tackled. CEP legislation gives the Government a straw to grasp at while doing little to meet longer term needs. Although I have to say that the CEP is infinitely better managed than the Whitlam Government's infamous regional employment development scheme, the CEP can be compared with it in that it involves throwing copious amounts of taxpayer's money at a problem while ignoring the demands of the future. I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will recognise that this is a political ploy of some merit, but it is hardly likely to quell the fears of thinking Australians.

In this regard, as in so many other unwise measures that the Government has adopted, it has set out its priorities. I believe the Government to be wrong, but at the same time I believe that it deserves to be allowed to make its own mistakes. The way that the Government has chosen-the CEP legislation is but one of its measures-is not, in my opinion, the preferred way. The Government has not adopted the right priorities. The coalition would adopt the right priorities and it will be, and is, more concerned with long term meaningful solutions to unemployment in this great land. I recommend to the Government that it address itself to economic measures which are designed to meet that end and to meet the long term needs of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I raised a point of order regarding the honourable member for Moreton displaying a newspaper.

—Order! If I may first indicate to the honourable member that in fact a point of order must be taken at the time when the issue arises. Any point taken in relation to proceedings before the suspension of the sitting for dinner would not be appropriate to be taken now by way of a point of order. If the honourable member has some brief comment to make, he may do so with my indulgence, as long as I permit him to make that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the indulgence of the Chair to make a brief comment. At the outset might I say that my previous point of order at the commencement of the speech of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) was not a deliberate act to waste his time. I would not do that to the honourable gentleman as I have a great deal of respect for him. I point out to the House that page 150 of the House of Representatives Practice has some interesting things to say about the use of exhibits in the chamber but, more particularly, pages 453 and 454 show, by way of example, some articles which have been used to illustrate speeches-and newspapers are not part of them. In ad- dition, I also wish to point out that there has been some precedence. We had Speaker Snedden ruling out the Illawarra Mercury on a previous occasion. My mind is a little hazy but I think Speaker Jenkins may well have done a similar thing during this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I merely raise this matter because it was the subject of some discussion before the suspension of the sitting for dinner and it is probably something that needs to be clarified; otherwise honourable members will not know whether or not they are in a position to use newspapers or front page headlines as displays in the House. There appears to be no consistency in the House of Representatives precedence on this as far as I can see, but I raise it now for what it is worth to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order-
—It is not a point of order; it is a matter being dealt with by indulgence.
—May I have the indulgence of the House to make a point?
—Briefly.

—Very briefly. As I recall it, the words printed in the Illawarra Mercury contained, in very large type, words which were unparliamentary in this Parliament and, as such, they differed from those used by my colleague, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) earlier this evening. I just draw that to the attention of the Chair.

—I ruled on the matter at the time but the honourable member withdrew the item. The references in the House of Representatives Practice were matters that were drawn to my attention and the honourable member for Barton also referred to them. The 1980 reference dealing with a handwritten sign, is a reference to unparliamentary language. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on the Community Employment Amendment Bill. The community employment program is the largest labour force program ever undertaken by an Australian government. In three Budgets the community employment program has been allocated $1 billion. It is undoubtedly, in my view and I dare say in the view of my electorate, a most successful program because its objectives are to help those at the bottom of the heap-the long term unemployed and the disadvantaged unemployed-to increase their mobility within the work force. As a simultaneous product this program has an objective to build lasting community assets which, in the electorate of Barton, have been most welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: CEP is part of a broad-based labour market strategy which this Government has pursued very successfully. Indeed, as part of its economic policies, the labour market policies that this Government has adopted have been most successful. But, as is the case in attempting to correct long term problems in any field of government, specific intervention is needed in many instances, and the labour market is no different. Intervention in the labour market on behalf of those who are less able to help themselves is a necessity as viewed by this Government. It is a basic belief of this Government. It is also a basic difference that this Government has with the Opposition. The disadvantaged, the long term unemployed, migrants, women, Aborigines and the handicapped are all categories of people in our society who not only need but also deserve assistance with labour market mobility. That the Opposition does not believe this is most obvious by the contribution its members have made in the last couple of days in this place. Indeed, that is ironic in itself because it is these long term unemployed at the bottom of the labour market heap who are the very creation of the Liberal-National Party Government of 1975 to 1983. It is its mess that we are attempting to solve. It is the human tragedy that it has afflicted on this community that we are attempting to solve, and the CEP is one specific measure that this Government is adopting. Indeed, the creation of a pool of long term unemployed was a deliberate economic tool of the previous coalition Government and now in the discussion of this matter in this place we find the present Opposition objecting to our humane and moral policies.

The short term view of those opposite appears to be that these people should be left on the dole and that the remainder of the funds to be expended on CEP should be used to lower taxes in the short term. I put it to the House that, with a 52 per cent success rate of participants in CEP joining the work force, the short term view of the coalition is a tragedy in itself, because with a 52 per cent success rate-and I dare say that that will pick up as the program continues-we find long term unemployed joining the work force, becoming not dole recipients, not consumers of taxpayers' contributions, but taxpayers themselves. When the multiplier effect of CEP is fully taken into account the long term implications versus the short term single-mindedness of the Opposition on these issues contrast even greater. Indeed, the CEP philosophy is consistent with the consumer-led recovery approach that is adopted by this Government, as opposed to those opposite who seek to alter downwards the wage structures and so provide greater suppression of consumer demand.

The social value of CEP also cannot be overlooked. In my electorate we have three outstanding projects amongst many. The Oatley-Como cycleway is an outstanding success-indeed, probably one of the most popular in Australia. We have the Rockdale Park and bikeway and, of course, extensions to the St George Hospital. I wonder whether those opposite would like to come to my electorate and say to my constituents that the CEP is a waste of money. I hope that they will because the people of my electorate would see even more clearly the shortcomings of those opposite. It has been alleged that the CEP is a political instrument and is being used to fund all sorts of subversive causes. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), on 18 February, speaking in this debate, had cause to mention some `extreme left wing outfit' promoting `one side of its axe grinding cause'. He mentioned the Victorian Trades Hall Council, the Tasmanian Wilderness Society, the Friends of the Earth, the Total Environment Centre, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Native Forest Action Council. He said:
The money is being used to promote the cause and to promote one side of particularly contentious issues.

He also, in agreeing with the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), labelled it a rort. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition went on to mention `not only these ratbag left wing causes but also capital works programs'. The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) said:
There has been an allocation of $36,766 to the FILEF, which is the Australian operation of the Italian Communist Party, for the construction of new offices and staffing in its information bureau.

This is a fairly grave charge, I would have thought, from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, or a succession of them, which I find astounding to say the least. It may interest the House to know that under the previous Government the wage pause program was, supposedly, a high flying strategy in the pursuit of employment programs. I draw the attention of the House to some `left wing' projects that were funded under the wage pause program by the Fraser Government. The interesting thing about this is that the second last I think, of a fairly quick succession of Ministers for Employment and Industrial Relations or Employment and Youth Affairs was the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition. It is also interesting to see all the people who get a mention. There is Friends of the Earth in Victoria and Western Australia, there is FILEF in New South Wales and South Australia-I am sure the Italian community will like being labelled Communist! I for one take exception to any large ethnic community's main cultural committees being labelled Communist. I think that is quite outlandish. In Western Australia we had the Homosexual Counselling and Information Service being funded under the wage pause program by the Fraser Government. We had the Australian Capital Territory Trades and Labour Council, and the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council. I hope I do not cause the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who is at the table, any discomfort, but in New South Wales the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union was funded quite significantly for two organisers' positions under the wage pause program. The Liberal Party is running up and down the country saying that this Government is funding a whole variety of left wing projects and organisations under the community employment program. I suggest that those opposite, particularly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, buy a large mirror.

With the community employment program we have an integral part of a long term labour market strategy that is well in place. The target for creating jobs is now running, I think, at 20 per cent ahead of expectation from the Prime Minister's speech at the election rally in 1983. The economic policy is in place but, most particularly, it has a wages policy in place which is supplemented by such things as the CEP. It is with great hide that members of the Opposition criticise the community employment program in the debate on this Bill when they themselves have no wages policy. The labour market strategy of the Opposition is in tatters. We have read recently of business leaders criticising it severely. I would have thought that those opposite-most of whom have had, at first hand, benefits of the CEP in their own electorates-would have made a positive contribution. As is the case with the Opposition's wages policy and other labour market strategies, no positive contribution come forth, only criticism. I believe that that, more than anything else, is symbolic of the problems that currently besiege the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I speak on the Community Employment Amendment Bill tonight. As we have heard from previous speakers, this is a vast program the Labor Government has implemented in an attempt to create jobs in the work force. Obviously that is happening, but it is not doing much for the figures that they keep bandying about. In fact, we are seeing billions of dollars of taxpayers' money being spent in creating fictitious jobs-they are real jobs but the figures are fictitious because, in fact, the unemployment rate is rising rather than falling. The community employment program is a direct public sector job creation scheme and involves labour intensive projects of social and economic benefits, so-called, to the community, especially targeted towards the long term unemployed. These people must have registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service for at least nine months. It is not a direct source of permanent work. The minimum time for projects is only 13 weeks, the maximum 52 weeks. Federal, State and local government authorities and non-profit community organisations are eligible to apply for projects. I shall later have a little to say about some of the government authorities that receive these funds. The CEP spending accounts for about 50 per cent of Commonwealth expenditure on all labour market programs. As we have heard previously, this Government in the next three years intends spending $1,000m-a lot of money in anybody's terms.

SPEECH.PARA: To date 16,000 projects and 87,000 short-term employment opportunities have been offered. In Queensland, where my electorate of Maranoa is situated, there have been 1,856 projects to a value of $191m. The CEP funds $138m and 14,400 jobs have been created. The program is divided into several activity areas such as clerical, community service, construction, forestry and so on, and 75 per cent of costs of funding goes to labour costs.

The main problem with the program is that there are no details of improvement of skills of people placed in CEP projects. There is inflexibility of target group quotas, and sponsor groups do not benefit all that much. A limit of a year could cause disruption to organisations. The training often drains the capabilities of a community organisation. The effects are only short term and do not aid on-going requirements of community organisations. Construction and improvement programs take precedence because of the visible results.

Governments, any government, including my own National Party Government in Queensland, love to put up big signs showing exactly what they are at. The Labor Government is not short on spending money on signs advising the community at large what jobs they are doing, CEP included. There is not an adequate response to the problem of the long term unemployed. This is our basic problem. The CEP focuses on needs of projects sponsors rather than prospective individual participants, with project design and approval occuring before recruitment of the eligible unemployed.

I turn to the role of the State governments. In Queensland we Federal members get across our tables a run-down of all the jobs that are put up to government authorities to employ people under the community employment program. I do not think I have yet supported one that my National Party Government has sponsored. I do not believe that State governments should be getting involved in this program. It would be preferable if the private sector received the jobs and not State government employees, but one finds all over the country-Queensland is not peculiar to this problem-many different sorts of jobs involved. They relate to the Department of Primary Industries, the Department of Forestry, the Railway Department, and other departments, with a whole range of government sector employees being put up for such programs. I think that this is a scandal. Queensland is copping a bit. The program is pumping money into the public works programs in the Labor States throughout Australia in the disguise of CEP projects. That is what it is about. Under the Constitution the Federal Government cannot discriminate against Queensland in this regard, but all the other Labor States in Australia are getting the same sort of funding and it is helping to prop up the State Labor Governments in Western Australia, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia.

I am totally opposed to these projects and I have never supported one State Government project-not even in my own State. I put a line through the request. I do not think it makes a damn of difference because the public servants still dole out the jobs to State government employees, but at least this debate gives me the opportunity in this place to voice my opposition to what is going on. The Government should take a close look at this program. I imagine it will not be changed because most State governments are Labor controlled. Quite a bit has been said by me and by others on the affirmative action program, which the great white leader Bob Hawke introduced. It's a bit like Russia revisited.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as the Prime Minister.

—The Prime Minister introduced this iniquitous Bill in the House yesterday afternoon. As I say, it is shades of Russia revisited, because that is what it amounts to. It is interesting to note that 38.6 per cent of the people included in these works programs are women. Many women are working on the roads these days. They do not seem to mind that. I support it. I think it is great to see them out and about and getting a bit of sunshine. So far in 1985-86, 52.6 per cent of the participants of the CEP are women. The way we are going, affirmative action is needed for men rather than women. That is about the position that we have got into. I guess fair is fair. It just so happens that the unemployed have been waiting longer for jobs. In 1981 they waited 34 weeks and in 1985 they waited 51 weeks for a job. Those characters on the other side of the House have the audacity to tell us that they are creating jobs and are helping the unemployed. What nonsense. I have never heard such rot.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister once again thinks that he has a great program running. He thinks that he is the biggest disc jockey in Australia. He puts on earphones and says: `Ring me back, fellas; reverse the charges'. It is only another bill that the taxpayers have to foot. Reverse charge subscriber trunk dialling calls were made throughout Australia. Every phone call would have cost $5. The Prime Minister promised to create 10,000 jobs by June. He has not created one job yet. I put to him that his top priority ought to be to free up, deregulate, youth wages. If he did that he would find that the youth, the really disadvantaged sector of our community, who are desperately looking for work would find jobs and be paid. They would be satisfied to have a job at a lower wage, instead of having the jackboots unions forcing employers to have to pay these very high youth wages. That is one reason that we have so many people unemployed.

The total number of unemployed in the labour force in 1947 was 3.4 per cent; in 1954 it was 1.5 per cent; and so it goes. In 1971 the figure was 1.7 per cent; in 1981 it was 5.6 per cent; and in 1985 it was 7.9 per cent. In actual fact, under this Labor Government the total percentage of unemployed people in the labour force has risen from 5.6 per cent to 7.9 per cent, which is an actual raise of 2.3 per cent. We now have 598,000 people unemployed. It is important that we understand that 33 per cent of those unemployed are in the 15 to 24 years age group. That is the sector of the unemployed that we on this side are very concerned about. We are already paying out $1 billion over three years. In 1983-84 we paid out $2.91-that is nearly $3 billion-for the unemployment benefit. In 1984-85 we paid out $2.98 billion and in 1985-86, $2.99 billion which represents an increase of $5.4m. Yet the Prime Minister has the audacity to come into this place and try to convince us and the Australian community that the Government is taking the unemployed off the streets. What rot. The Government is paying out more money now to the unemployed than it ever did. Those are the figures. Now that I have explained these figures-I indicate that I have had a bit to say on the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill which the Prime Minister introduced in this place yesterday-I wish to spend a bit of time explaining to the House how I feel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that before the honourable member does so, he recall that under the Standing Orders he is unable to make reference to another piece of legislation.

—That is correct. The way the figures are going, affirmative action is needed for men rather than for women. According to Census figures, in 1947, 19 per cent of the work force were women. In 1986, 46 per cent of the work force are women. So we need only 4 per cent to balance the numbers for men and women in the work force. The way things are going, that will not take long. One will soon find more women in the work force than men.

SPEECH.PARA: I question why there is any need at all for the Prime Minister to introduce a new Bill. It is just a propaganda election gimmick. More than half of the women who are working are married. Two-thirds of them have dependent children. I think that is important. The argument I am using in regard to the unemployment problem and the community employment program is that this Government is encouraging the disruption of the family unit and married women to go out and work. Not only is the Government doing that, but also it is forcing employers to build kindergartens and creches at the place of employment. I think that is disgraceful. It is shades of Russia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have been very tolerant tonight. The honourable member for Maranoa has strayed greatly from the Bill. I think that at the moment he is trying to make up to his wife.
—I will come to my wife in a minute.
-I remind the honourable member for Maranoa that he should remain relevant to the proposition before us, which is the Community Employment Amendment Bill.

—Forty-six per cent of the work force are women, two-thirds of whom have dependent children. There are 880,000 married women in the work force who have dependent children. I guess that once they get a job their main concern is that they do not lose it. If they do, I guess that they can fall back on a CEP project. This Government is spending money like it is going out of fashion. Expenditure on the CEP has been $3.4m. I suggest that it is a great pity that governments do not encourage working women with dependent children to stay at home. Surely there must be some pride in their doing that. There has been a bit of talk about affirmative action. It is a great pity that it is not used against some of the journalists. I thank the members of this House who have come to me today and said what a good job my wife did on the AM program this morning.
—The honourable member for Maranoa should be a little more relevant to the legislation.

—What I was talking about has to do with the unemployed, with the CEP and with the biggest problem we have in our community today-youth unemployment. I believe that not only the Labor Party Government but also the National Party and the Liberal Party should be considering this problem and encouraging women with children to stay at home. The Government should be making it easier for the 32 per cent of the unemployed-those in the age group from 18 to 24 years-to get work.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank honourable members for coming to me today and saying what a good job my wife did on the AM program. I must say that I am rather disgusted with the form of reporting that is going on in this country today. As I said, if there is any affirmative action needed, it is against some of the journalists. I am not branding all journalists, but some journalists really stoop and dive below the belt. I explain that it was Senator Vanstone who mentioned the other room. I have never ever used that word which has been bandied around the countryside today. I would like to thank honourable members for their support-and those members have been on both sides of the House. Probably more Government members than Opposition members have come to me today and told me what an excellent job my wife has done. I would like to thank her very much for the words she said and I assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that-

TALK.START.PARA: —Explain the position.

—I do not have a position to explain, I just feel that some of the things that have happened today show that some members in this House are not very happy about the sort of reporting that has gone on. I have much pleasure in supporting the Community Employment Amendment Bill and I guess other speakers will wish to do so as well. I do not know about affirmative action-I expect I will have a lot more to say about it when that Bill comes into the House-
—Do you support it?
—No I do not. Obviously that Bill will come here soon, but I am not meant to be speaking on it now. When it does come here we will have the opportunity to put our views forward at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me preface my remarks on the Community Employment Amendment Bill by suggesting to the wife of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) that she should give him curry when he gets home. The funding of the community employment program for another three years is a further step in the Hawke Labor Government's long term plan to make certain that those people throughout our nation who have not been able to find work are given the opportunity to learn skills and return to the work force. The global economic conditions and unfair trading of farm produce through massive subsidy for inefficient farmers in Europe have had a dramatic effect on our products and this flows through to affect Australian manufacturing and service industry as well as jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: In the years of the Fraser Government there was a feeling of insecurity and a lowering of morale among working women and men. There was also a distrust of employers. This was brought about by the harsh economic policies of the Liberal and National parties. They put thousands out of work and created bankruptcies by the thousand, all in an endeavour to impose a set of conditions in which their friends got richer and those who were unable to get work were forgotten and left to scramble for the meagre welfare that was distributed grudgingly. The contempt that some members of the Liberal and National parties have for those who are not born with silver spoons in their mouths is legendary. Let me remind the House what the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) said only this week about some unemployed people in his electorate:
In my electorate there is a small town called Boolarra bordering on the Latrobe Valley and I understand that a motley--
Yes, that is correct, he used the word `motley'-
collection of travelling clowns and performing artists have been awarded a large sum of money by both the State and Federal Governments.

I just wonder how those people who have been unemployed for months, whose self-esteem has been shattered and who have now been given an opportunity to learn skills and get back into the work force will feel. The honourable member for Gippsland certainly knows how to make people feel good. What he said is especially provocative when it is said by someone whose family owns thousands of acres in Gippsland, and who owns hotels, shopping centres and other investments, who drives a luxury European car-

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, what has the personal position of a colleague got to do with this Bill? Will you ask the honourable member to stick to the Bill?
—There is no point of order, the honourable member for Groom will resume his seat.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, if the honourable member for Dunkley is going to go on like this, perhaps he should tell the House how many people the honourable member for Gippsland employs.
—There is no point of order, but I draw the attention of the honourable member for Dunkley to the Bill.
—Certainly, Mr Deputy Speaker. The preselection of the honourable member for Gippsland--

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I refer you to the Standing Orders. You will know that pursuant to Standing Orders, any reflection, or any suggestion of impropriety or bad character against another member of this Parliament must be made by substantive motion.
—Order! I was listening carefully to what the honourable member for Dunkley was saying. I do not think it is a reflection on a member to suggest that his family has assets.

—The honourable member's preselection for this House bought the day before nominations closed for the Federal election. His attitude to the disadvantage is typical of some people, but I am glad to say not all people, in the coalition of which he is a member. One wonders whether he walks his property pining for the old days when one could buy and sell people to work on one's holding and pay them nothing. I am afraid that the Opposition has been taken over by the hard Right. It is moving rapidly to try to make certain that its policies overwhelm the more decent members of the Opposition. I urge the moderates of the Opposition parties to work hard to make certain that they are not buried by the right wing radicals.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last State and Federal elections Liberal politicians on the Mornington Peninsular spoke aggressively against the community employment program, its contents and its aims. It is interesting to see these hypocrites now announcing local CEP projects, embracing them for the local Press, sending out Press releases on how much money is involved and how good they are for the local community. Is it not amazing the depths to which some people will sink to get their name in the local Press? People have long memories. They remember the contempt the Opposition has for our unemployed. The Opposition is supporting the Bill at the moment but if it ever had the opportunity it would abolish it and again return the nation to the insecurity and despairing days of Liberal and National Government.

Some of us have experienced the distress of men and women in tears in their offices after having been sacked from a job that they had held for many years. They were too ashamed to tell their families or to ask for government unemployment benefits. During my first year as a member of Parliament I must have seen at least one dozen people in this pitiful state. One very sad case was that of a young woman who was out of work. She lived in a caravan and did not have 20c to put in a time shower at the caravan park. This is Australia, a rich country, and we should not have one person in this position.

Some years ago teenagers in Frankston rioted and part of the trigger for this was a feeling of lack of purpose which was brought about by the continuing degrading effect that unemployment has on people. There is still a large unemployment problem in Frankston but there is now a feeling of optimism, a feeling that better times are here.

When we took over managing the legacy of despair from the Opposition one of the first things that the Labor Government did was to start an employment program to make certain that those who had been unemployed for some time would have the opportunity of obtaining skills and self-esteem. The community employment program has been an outstanding success. Some benefits are that in two years 3,800 projects have been approved and 75,500 jobs have been created at a cost of approximately $1 billion. Over 60 per cent of participants have gained some employment after leaving the problem. Small business has gained through the increased purchasing power of the participants.

I feel I should take this opportunity publicly to thank some of those people who have worked within the Dunkley electorate and have helped make CEP the great success that it is. Firstly, I thank the project officers from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations-Mr Ralph Kenyon, Mr John Negus and Mrs Jenny Gillam. The area project officers had the responsibility of establishing the programs in many electorates and they have done it in an exemplary manner. Their diligence, efficiency and efforts have paid off. I thank the Mornington and Frankston officers who have participated actively in the program.

Mornington Council's record to date is that in 1983-84 over $566,000 was spent on CEP projects. In the early part of 1983 49 people were employed on EIP projects. In 1985, 59 people were employed on CEP projects and over $739,000 was spent. In 1986, with new CEP projects about to commence, nearly $900,000 is being spent and 70 people are being employed.

My particular thanks go to Ken McArthur and Ian Evison and the Mornington councillors, who are very well aware of the benefits which CEP has for the Mornington community. Frankston Council has established its own employment initiatives committee. The members of that committee are Albert Knowles, the mayor, Geoff Holland, Ken Woodger, Jan Williamson, Bill Langford, Jenny Gillam, Don McClean, Ian Boag, Noel Burrows, and myself or one of my staff. This committee has initiated many projects. These people have given their own time to assist in the development of worthwhile projects for the city of Frankston and surrounding areas. I make special mention of Mr Noel Burrows, who is the co-ordinator and permanent project officer of the group. He also looks after training.

I thank those organisations outside the councils which have been prepared to participate in the scheme. The Frankston and Mornington Community Employment Service offices have been involved in the selection of people to be included in the program. I mention the local papers, the Standard, the Independent News, the News and the Town Crier, which have generously helped to promote the program and make certain that the unemployed in Dunkley are more aware of the opportunities which the CEP offers. Of course, I thank the members of my staff who were actively involved in the work to make certain that all projects submitted to the secretariat were acceptable.

The benefits to CEP participants include current work experience, lifting of self-esteem by participating in the work force, greater employability through skills gained, getting into the routine of working and having social skills reassured, and, finally, a steady and worthwhile wage. Benefits to the community organisations include getting achieved and completed jobs which are of value to the community and which local government and project sponsors may not have had the money to do until a future date, achieving goals and completing projects that local organisations may wish to do but which are beyond their financial capabilities, being actively involved in community planning, and participating in organising programs of benefit to the community. Benefits to local government include the opportunity to participate in job creation schemes, to be actively concerned with problems concerning unemployment and taking up the challenge of meaningful job creation, and the attraction of funds for public works that would not normally be undertaken. These are some of the benefits of the CEP. Another benefit is just the simple reassurance that I am certain people gain through working for a period and of getting some money in their pockets, the self-confidence that comes with knowing that one is able to do a job. I commend this Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—I do.

—The honourable member in his remarks ascribed to my speech on the CEP in this Parliament on Tuesday meanings that are not accurate. The honourable member for Dunkley accused me of turning my back on unemployed persons in my electorate. May I remind the House-

The stupidity and ludicrousness of that speaks for itself, but may I, during this personal explanation, assure the House that living in a rural community-

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I shall endeavour to do so. I do not walk the paddocks wishing for a return of the slave trade. Instead, I wish for lower fuel prices, interest rates, and a return of conservative government.
