SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we all know, the community employment program was introduced three years ago to help the long term unemployed and disadvantaged to get work experience, training and confidence in short term jobs so that they would be better placed to get permanent jobs as they become available. The program has cost over a billion dollars in these three years and has put some 75,000 people into short term jobs. The basic question is: Has the program been a success? The 1984-85 CEP report says on page 8 that it has been. It says that studies show that many of the people helped have gained in both experience and confidence and that some 46 per cent of those, in one survey, had jobs some six months after leaving the CEP. I can believe that. Take, for example, a foreign migrant with little English who steps off the plane into a community with high unemployment. A job for a few weeks or a few months to help him settle down and find his feet would be a tremendous boost, and the same sort of thing applies to other categories of employees.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not doubt that the CEP has had its successes, but to really assess the scheme we need to find out easily precisely what the program is doing. The problem is that this seems to be getting harder with each passing year. For example, in the 1983-84 report there are tables setting out the jobs created and the percentage of the whole that each category fills. We see from the tables in that 1983-84 report that in broad percentage terms about 50 per cent of the jobs created are in construction, maintenance, kerbing, road building, and so on, and that they take about 50 per cent, in round figures, of CEP funds. In the Commonwealth element about 26 per cent of the jobs are in community service or cultural projects and a corresponding percentage of the funds is involved. We can see what percentage of the jobs are clerical, recreational and so on, and so we know generally speaking what we are talking about. However, these tables do not appear in the 1984-85 report. There are many more tables but they do not give us that sort of basic information. It is wrong that we should have to go sleuthing to find out the facts.

From other evidence we find that the balance of construction, et cetera, jobs on the one hand and cultural jobs on the other has been significantly changed. There is no table in the 1984-85 report like tables 2.3 or 2.4 of the 1983-84 report, but we are suddenly informed on page 7 of the report that the biggest sum of money now being spent is on a `wide range of cultural and recreation-oriented projects'. That is the biggest category. Some $263m is being spent on `cultural and creation-oriented projects' compared with $176m on roads, $173m on welfare, $124m on health and education projects, and $86m on environmental schemes. The cultural and recreational projects now dominate the CEP, which was obviously not the case at the beginning of the scheme.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has not explained why this change from an emphasis on manual work to an emphasis on cultural projects has taken place or just what these cultural projects are. Incidentally, the mystery is deepened by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen). In his famous speech on 17 October last he said that it is not generally known that as at 23 September of this year the community employment program has provided $27-plus million for arts and heritage employment projects. The report of the CEP puts the figures at $263m. The Minister went on:
These hundreds of approved projects have had considerable financial impact, particularly in Community Arts.

The position is that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment says that $28m of CEP funds has been spent on arts and heritage, but the report of the CEP itself says that between nine and 10 times as much-$263m-has been spent on cultural and recreational projects. So there is a vast and unexplained difference in these two figures. If they can be reconciled, I would like to know how. The only way to find out whether this is possible is to be given details of the projects, which we have not been given. I am going to ask for these details in a question on notice. Why the mystery or the lack of publicised detail? It is important not just for the arts, which is not an issue here since the CEP clearly provides more funds for the community arts than does the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council, but more to the point now in this debate we must be able to assess the CEP. Is it any wonder that many people suspect that the cultural projects being funded at this enormous sum are neither cultural nor likely to help a beneficiary to get the permanent unsubsidised work at which the scheme is supposed to aim.

The belief has spread that the CEP is being transformed from being predominantly a stepping stone to real work to being a funder of left wing political causes. In other words, an increasing number of CEP projects have been undertaken by organisations such as Community Radio Federation, Friends of the Earth, Gay Publications Co-operative, the Victorian Association of Peace Studies, Pax Christi, or the Union of Australian Women. In 1984 we even had the comedy of the Government supporting mining on Roxby Downs because of the jobs it would create and at the same time spending hundreds of thousands of dollars through the CEP on funding various Roxby blockade groups whose aim was to stop the jobs being created. This was being done in the name of a job creation scheme.

I stress that the difficulty in making the sort of assessment I would like to see made is that the spending of this vast sum of money-$263m-on a wide range of cultural and recreation-oriented projects is not spelt out in detail so that we know what those projects are. We get the occasional announcement from the Minister. We get scraps of information from various sources. There is absolutely no good reason why all of the projects should not be listed. The amounts of money spent on them and the number of jobs created should also be listed in their entirety so that we could assess the scheme and assess the new turn that it has taken. Cultural and recreational projects now predominate and road works, construction, maintenance or manual work projects have fallen lower in the total picture. I draw the attention of the House to one project which is a CEP project. The Minister has not announced it, but the Transnational Cooperative announced it in the beginning of its publication, a large study called `Anti-Union Employment Practices'. The project was supported by 21 unions such as the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the New South Wales Teachers Federation, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Staff Association, the Building Workers Industrial Union and so on. The project concludes with a number of recommendations including urging the trade union movement to `insist' that the Government stop funding `conservative' organisations. The TNC report recommends:

That the union movement insist that both the Federal and State Labor governments scrutinise more closely their criteria for the funding of research organisations which specialise in a conservative school of economic thinking and produce material which promotes a strong anti-union philosophy. For instance, the Centre of Policy Studies (directed by Michael Porter and with John Stone as an adviser)-

TALK.START.PARA: —My God, what a double!
—That is right. I continue:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . at Monash University, Melbourne, was in 1982 guaranteed $500,000 per annum until 1987 by the Fraser Government. In addition to that it receives very generous donations from large corporations. A similar situation exists with the right wing Centre for Independent Studies group in Sydney, and the Melbourne-based Institute of Public Affairs, both of which Hugh Morgan (Western Mining Corporation) is a patron and financier to. The continued use of scarce resources in this manner will ultimately be to the detriment of the trade union movement.

Professor Wheelwright writes an introduction to this study. He says that it is necessary to help redress the balance and that Labor governments and publicly-owned institutions, instead of helping to finance research centres and academic institutions which are `heavily oriented towards market forces and the owners of capital', should finance studies such as this which are oriented towards `collective solutions' to society's problems and the owners of labour, irrespective of whether the legal system by sleight of hand categorises them as employees or contractors. So taxpayers' money is being used to finance leftist attacks on conservative organisations.

We are told that the community employment program is not a political program but a job creation program whereas the facts are increasingly showing that it has become a political program rather than a job creation program. The sort of example that I have just given, multiplied many times over, can only discredit the community employment program. That seems to be what is happening. If it is not the case, the Minister can give us the facts. He has not done that. That only strengthens the view that whatever good the community employment program does-as it still does-it is being undermined by being progressively perverted into a weapon for the leftist abuse of the taxpayer.

The next step in this debate is for the facts to be made public, instead of our having to be satisfied with the statement that $263m is being allocated for cultural and recreation projects, by far the biggest of all categories, and a much smaller number of millions for road improvement, welfare services, health and education projects down to a comparatively miserly $86m for various environmental improvement projects. We are simply being told but it is necessary for the Minister to reveal exactly what is happening in the spending of this money. It is simply not enough to say that $263m will go to cultural projects and to imply that the earlier emphasis on manual work is being played down and there is a new emphasis on cultural projects.

It is simply not enough for the Minister to say that or for that to be stated in the CEP report. We need to know more than the scraps we can now get about what is involved. From time to time, the Minister issues a statement when he finds a CEP project with which he is pleased or which he thinks will meet with public approval. But the evidence is there that hundreds of these schemes will not meet with public approval and are an abuse of the taxpayers' money, a waste of CEP funds and are politically inspired. The CEP is becoming the principal funder for these politically inspired projects for this sort of cultural revolution that the Government is promoting and it is a perversion of the CEP and a movement away from the worthwhile objectives on which the CEP was originally established.

Whether the CEP could ever achieve those worthwhile objectives, there is no point in denying that they were worthwhile and that the CEP has had its share of successes. I would certainly be the first to say so because of personal experience in helping place people in CEP projects and seeing them at work at close hand in my electorate. But the real concern is the change that has been taking place and the movement away from the original objectives into $263m worth of cultural projects about which we know nothing but which we have every reason to suspect. That suspicion will be allayed only if the Minister comes clean and reveals the facts which at the moment are thoroughly concealed under big figures without any detail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your election as Chairman of Committees. Having been a member of the Standing Committee on Expenditure which you chaired so ably, I know well your capacity to guide a meeting with intelligence, toughness and humour. I am sure you will chair the House with equal effectiveness using those qualities. The honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) has just delivered another of his distorted tirades. A wide range of community projects is funded under the community employment program. Like many on the far right, he calls political anything with which he does not agree. Many projects have been set up by community groups with particular interests. But those groups are spread right across the political spectrum and there has certainly been no evidence of the prejudice which he alleges has existed.

SPEECH.PARA: My comments will be brief because most issues have already been thoroughly discussed in this extensive debate on the Community Employment Amendment Bill. The community employment program is part of the Government's national economic strategy. That strategy is aimed at sustaining a steady rate of economic growth and employment growth and reducing the rate of inflation thereby increasing living standards and the justice with which the economy operates. These goals are in sharp contrast to those of the Opposition. When in Government it emphasised inflation first. Although it claimed to want employment growth, unemployment grew to over 10 per cent when it was in office. Its politics were clearly inadequate, for they failed dismally. In contrast, the Hawke Labor Government has aimed simultaneously to reduce unemployment, inflation and inequity, it has made progress in achieving all of those aims. There are over 600,000 more people in employment now than there were when the Government won office in March 1983.

The national economic strategy began with a substantial fiscal stimulus, and the expansionary macroeconomic policies got the economy moving again. Continuation of that rapid growth has depended on increased private investment and consumer spending. The strength of that resurgence of the private sector has ensured that Australia has been among the fastest growing economies in the Western world during the last couple of years. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development predicts that in 1986 employment in Australia will grow faster than in any other Western country. These expansionary policies have been made possible by the effectiveness of the prices and incomes policy which has comprehensively restrained growth of income, so allowing the rate of inflation to fall, while at the same time economic activity has been increasing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish! The rate of inflation in Australia is going up.

—The rate of inflation is much lower now than when the Government came to office. The success of the accord has been an historic achievement in Australia, the result of effective, close co-operation among government, business and unions. A supportive element of the national economic strategy has been the community employment program. The CEP has been an emergency response to a crisis situation. The 10 per cent level of unemployment which faced the Government when it won office demanded swift action. Unemployment, more than anything else, of course, causes poverty, destroys self-respect and prevents people from making a contribution to the community in which they live; it causes social disruption of many kinds. The CEP is the largest and most ambitious short term job creation initiatives ever undertaken by an Australian government.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal goal of the program is to create additional employment opportunities which would provide work experience for unemployed people. By providing employment opportunities for the long term unemployed, there has been some redistribution of the burden of unemployment. The second goal of the program has been to provide financial support for projects of real community benefit. So the program has aimed to increase the employability of those people who have experienced long periods of unemployment and therefore have found it hard to get back into the employed work force. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventh report from the Publications Committee, sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. I understand that copies of the report have been circulated to honourable members throughout the chamber.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Natural Disaster Funding-Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-Medicare-Taxation-Cyprus-Adam Collins-Fuel Pricing-Entertainment-Rural Industry-Transport Industry

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I now propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest), in an adjournment address on Monday of this week, drew attention to the need for relief to the beleaguered sugar industry of Australia. I rise to support the honourable member and to add that an already serious problem has now been exacerbated by the effects of Cyclone Winifred which struck the northern coast of Queensland on 1 February. Cyclone Winifred created massive damage to the cane crop, to the sugar industry and the banana industry in the super wet belt, as well as to the grain crop of the tablelands, as well as social and physical damage right throughout the area. The cyclone reported a low of 954 millibars, created damage to those industry crops and property and public work damage of $100m.

SPEECH.PARA: In the aftermath of the cyclone I had extensive discussions with local government elected representatives, sugar mills staff, cane growers, banana growers, the State Emergency Service personnel and electricity authorities. There is immediate concern for the unemployment of some 600 people affected by the destruction of the banana crop alone. Also, particularly in the township of Babinda, should further unemployment become inevitable because of the new difficulties presented to the mills, public works programs and other Commonwealth and State work related programs such as the community employment program that can be adapted to the work needs of these people will be required. Needless to say, it will require an active presence of Commonwealth agencies, the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security at the trouble centres in order to assist not only in the job and entitlement areas but also with the consequent social and community problems that will arise.

Sugar farmers, banana farmers and those other rural industries affected on the coast and on the tablelands will not be able to service their rate assessments to councils that will become payable. In this circumstance, councils will require grants to offset this loss of rates and special consideration should be given to some form of direct grant or perhaps to special allocations through the State Grants Commission. It is essential that councils in the affected areas are allowed to continue to supply services and to be instrumental in mopping up potentially unemployed people. The banana growers have suffered a loss of nine months in supply until crops regenerate. The estimated loss in this 60 per cent of Australia's banana industry is about $30m.

There can be no suggestion by the Government to relax quarantine and disease control regulations to allow the import of bananas for this period of short supply. Banana growers require financial assistance through natural disaster funds in order to re-establish farms. While all the land cannot be brought back immediately, I was given to understand that costs of re-establishment would be approximately $2,400 per acre, 50 per cent of which would be incurred in labour.

The growers' request was that the current ceiling on disaster relief loans be lifted beyond the current $60,000 to a reasonable figure to allow re-establishment. Cane farmers and millers in the cyclone area are already starved for cash and required special consideration. The price support scheme should be immediately settled without the delay which fighting over deregulation will involve. An advance to growers and millers to provide the value of the price support should be immediately committed. I urge the Government to set aside inter-government rivalries, accept the degree of deregulation offered by the growers and fund the support price. Other deregulation can be examined in the longer term but should not delay the cash support now desperately needed. The Commonwealth should scotch the rumour that any cyclone relief to cane farmers will be taken from the offered $150m package. The two are separate and distinct. The Queensland Government should address itself to the problems of mill finance and the precedent of this separation of financial assistance between the governments follows from the relief package of 1967-68.

The value of damage to the cane crop will not be fully assessed until the end of the current crushing season. Farmers are requesting grants under national disaster relief measures similar to those made available to other residents but denied the farmers themselves at the moment. Low interest loans preferably, with a moratorium on the first two years interest, will be required if the farmers are to survive. Again the natural disaster funding guidelines have to be changed in order to make these funds available to all farmers and not only to those whom banks reject. It will be necessary if disaster funds are to be administered through the Agricultural Bank that sufficient and experienced staff should be available to ensure speedy resolution of those applicants.

I commend the SES units and, particularly, electricity linesmen, who gave great help during and after the cyclone. It should be placed on record that the concern that many people had was alleviated by the work of these units.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to express, in the short time available, my very serious concerns over the current joustings by Bell Resources Pty Ltd and others for control of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I am aware of the recent assurances given by Mr Holmes a Court regarding his commitment to the steel industry. However, I am also aware of his modus operandi regarding other take-overs. I am not persuaded that if he is successful he will not either strip BHP assets and/or fragment its operations. BHP shareholders are being asked to sell half of their shares to Bell Resources at what superficially may seem an attractive price. I believe that the price seriously undervalues BHP. However, the implication in the offer is that the half of the shares that it does not sell will earn more under Mr Holmes a Court than otherwise. I firmly believe this proposition to be wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate of Newcastle, the birthplace of BHP steel, is an excellent barometer of the health and prosperity of the company. The future prosperity of BHP depends very much on the future of the steel industry which, in turn, is very much affected by the effectiveness of the steel plan. The steel plan is basically a contract between the government, the company and the employees. This contract necessitates a high level of mutual trust between these three parties. That the plan is currently working so well is proof of the existence of this trust. The continuing efforts by Mr Holmes a Court to take control of BHP linked with the perception of his likely intentions if he is successful are corroding and undermining this trust. The current deliberate destabilisation of BHP can and will have far reaching implications for the future of the steel industry unless they are stopped.

I do not believe that there will be continuing confidence in the future of the BHP steel division by the BHP employees, both staff and shop floor, unless Mr Holmes a Court is categorically rejected by BHP shareholders. I further believe that BHP will not even retain its current level of performance, let alone improve under Mr Holmes a Court's stewardship. Whilst he and his bankers and advisers manipulate share options and borrowings while they play out their corporate chess strategies the employees of BHP, the ones who need confidence and trust in their management, are becoming increasingly nervous and apprehensive about their futures. This cannot, and will not, lead to higher productivity.

Over many years I and others have been critical of BHP management. However with the introduction of the steel plan BHP has lifted its game. The effort that has been put into the steel industry by the Board and management in the past 30 months is very commendable. The current instability being induced by Mr Homes a Court is totally counterproductive.

There is another aspect of this and other take-over bids that disturbs me. The take-over is being mounted essentially with borrowed funds. The interest on such funds is tax deductible. We have seen and are seeing the taxpayers eventually footing a large share of the cost of such take-overs. Whatever the end result of the take-over bid there is no doubt that the Australian community will pay a very high price, either in reduced taxation contribution, increased prices or both. Take-overs such as this create nothing new. Not one new job will be produced. In fact, a large number may well be lost. No new products will be generated and no new export markets will be created. On the contrary, the funds being mobilised would almost certainly appear to be from overseas.

In conclusion, I urge the shareholders of BHP to think very carefully about the concerns I have expressed. They should not assume that they will be able to retain the current earnings they should on their remaining shareholdings. They should not assume that the employees of BHP are not unaffected by what is taking place. They should take into account, particularly, projected imputations on taxation scales in the forthcoming tax changes. The current management of BHP has shown that it is capable of bringing the company into the modern manufacturing world. It deserves the confidence of its shareholders. I call on all shareholders to reject the bid and let the management and the employees of BHP get on with the job of its reconstruction and rejuvenation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In September 1983, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) heralded the introduction of Medicare by distinguishing it from its predecessor, Medibank. The Health Minister gloated:

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare will be substantially self-funding through the 1 per cent levy and a rearrangement of existing health insurance subsidies, whereas Medibank placed a considerable strain on Consolidated Revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a joke!

—As the honourable member for Warringah says, what a joke. I base my argument on two premises contained in the Minister's remarkable statement: Firstly, that the cost of Medicare would largely be covered by the nature of Medicare itself-through the 1 per cent levy; and secondly, that Medicare would be different from Medibank in that it would not strain Consolidated Revenue as Medibank had done. It is time the Australian people were told that the simple system Medicare was intended to be has not eventuated. Medicare is no longer self-funding. It is time the Australian people were told that Medicare is no different from its ancestor, Medibank. Medicare, as Medibank was once condemned for, is placing a considerable strain on Consolidated Revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded of a very clever cartoon in a recent edition of the Australian. It depicted Prime Minister Hawke being chauffered by Treasurer Keating in a very small car along a dangerous mountain road. The road was shaped like a J-a J-curve, if you like. What the occupants of the car did not see was that they were heading for a collision with an enormous truck coming from the opposite direction. The truck was driven by members of the Transport Workers Union. May I warn Health Minister Blewett that there is more than one truck on that road. The other is the Medicare truck. It is another loaded semi-trailer hurtling down a remote mountain road, out of control. I can see the driver, and it is the Health Minister. I would not have his job, the unenviable task behind the wheel, for quids.

TALK.START.PARA: —I woudn't ride with him.

—The uncontrollable Medicare truck is causing an accident of colossal proportions. The honourable member for Groom says he would not ride with him. I agree with him on that score. However, this accident is happening very quietly. The media, the cameras, will arrive at the scene very soon. The accident is happening very quietly because the Australian public cannot see it or hear it. Without the help of the media, they cannot directly feel its impact. Why not? Because only a small percentage of the cost of Medicare is felt in the famous hip-pocket nerve of the Australian. But let me assure the House that with the reckless Minister for Health at the wheel, it is only a matter of time before the crash will awaken the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I call on the Health Minister to explain his definition of `substantial self-funding'. As a learned gentleman, he will surely have no problem telling the people of Australia that it is something in the order of 80 to 100 per cent-that is, he would if he had not opted for the coward's way out. The Minister has gagged himself by stating, on Monday, 17 February:
It has not been my habit in the past and it will not be in the future, nor is it now, to make comments on issues which may be before Budget Cabinets.

Surely substantial self-funding must mean nothing lower than 80 per cent. It is more likely to be somewhere around 90 per cent or even up to 100 per cent. The Health Minister's words, however much he gags on them, have come back to haunt him. They will continue to haunt him as long as this so-called free health scheme continues. Medicare is a financial millstone around the thick neck of the Hawke Government.

Medicare has turned into the biggest bludger this country has ever known. The very simple proof that the Health Minister's prophecy has failed is this: The Government estimates that in 1985-86 the Medicare levy will raise $1.28 billion dollars. It estimates that in 1985-86 the cost of Medicare will be $4.33 billion dollars. Somewhere along the line the Government has lost $3.05 billion dollars. That is the difference between the amount the one per cent levy will raise and the amount Medicare is estimated, by the Hawke Government, to cost. Put another way, the Medicare levy accounts for only about 30 per cent of the cost of public medical and hospital services in this country. The Minister heralded the introduction of Medicare as a simple, fair, and affordable health insurance system that would provide basic health cover to all Australians. Medicare is not fair, and I claim it is not affordable.

The Australian public has been hoodwinked into believing, by the mighty Hawke media machine, that Medicare is working. If the Health Minister were truthful and held to his original commitment that Medicare would be substantially self-funded, the much touted one per cent levy should be raised to 3.4 per cent. The Hawke Government stands condemned for what it has not revealed to the Australian public; the Hawke Government is guilty of hiding the facts; and the Hawke Government should honour its original undertaking to substantially fund Medicare from the levy. The Hawke Government has broken yet another promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Canberra Times today carried the story of the six-year-old boy, Adam Collins who, while having a serious physical condition, is unable to obtain an operation as an elective admission until 11 April. The article quotes criticisms of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority and the Government from the child's grandmother, but a few facts of the case have been overlooked and I would like to put those before the House tonight. The child is a Medicare patient of a Dr David McNicol, a Canberra orthopaedic surgeon, who has recently issued a number of statements as spokesman for the Australian Association of Surgeons, which has been critical of Medicare in general and waiting times for elective surgery in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a normal practice for surgeons seeking to admit patients to Authority hospitals to classify the patient as urgent, semi-urgent or elective. It is the doctor who makes that decision, and he makes it, presumably, on medical grounds. The hospital then allocates the patient an operating date according to the vacancies available on the doctor's operating times. In Dr McNicol's case the hospital normally agrees to his requests to allocate particular patients to specific operating dates.

On 28 November last year Dr McNicol nominated this young boy, six-year-old Adam Collins, as an elective admission and asked that the patient be allocated operating time on 28 February, along with one other child and one adult. So Dr McNicol obviously did not see this as an urgent case, in that on 28 November he registered the date for the operation as 28 February. Then the hospital advised Dr McNicol that on the recommendation of what is called the workload monitoring committee, elective admissions for 28 February had to be reduced. It may be of interest to the House to know that a surgeon is represented on this committee. In Dr McNicol's case he was told that he had to cut down his operations by one paediatric patient. Dr McNicol then chose to remove Adam Collins from his operating list on 28 February. Presumably he did that on medical grounds. Subsequently the hospital has made an operating time for Adam on 7 March. Although, as I understand from the newspaper, it did not seem possible yesterday to treat the patient until 11 April, I have had a conversation with Dr McNicol tonight, who told me that he is prepared to operate on Adam at any time. Therefore, I hope that he will be able to take up the hospital's offer of the date of 7 March.

Mrs Collins is one of the bravest and most determined battlers I have ever met. I have known this family for many years in my capacity as the member for Canberra. It is a great pity that the sick boy has been used as a political football and that the newspaper did not present all the facts of the case but rather concentrated on its emotionalism. I am only pleased that I can inform the House that there is a new date, much sooner than the date of 11 April, available to the young boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent times the taxation debate has been to the forefront. People and governments have grappled with it. It is a matter still open to debate and question. I am disappointed, however, that overwhelming emphasis has been given to the method of tax collection without corresponding emphasis being given in the debate, and subject to scrutiny, to the purposes for which citizens' taxes are used.

SPEECH.PARA: The recent case of a Victorian man, Mr Murray Vilkelis-Curac, has brought into very clear focus indeed that it is appropriate for this nation to give a lead by seriously debating alternative provisions for citizens who cannot in conscience give tax money to support programs which they sincerely believe are morally offensive. Mr Vilkelis-Curac believes that it is morally offensive and unacceptable to him to have any portion of his taxation used for the funding of abortions and he has refused to pay tax. Many court cases have been held on his position. He still holds firmly to his conscientious beliefs.

It is noted that a number of American citizens have refused to pay their taxes, or even a percentage of their taxes, in protest at how these taxes are being used for what they regard as immoral purposes. Several attempts have been made by concerned Americans to have their members and senators introduce into the United States of America legislation procedures which would permit conscientious tax refusal. No such legislation has been passed but at least they are debating and considering the point. It has been proposed in the United States that a peace fund be set up to which conscientious tax refusers could contribute in the knowledge that their money would be used for specific peaceful purposes.

Many of my constituents have exactly the same conscientious objection to their taxes being used for the funding of abortion procedures. I believe that as time moves on they will follow Mr Vilkelis-Curac's example and be witnesses of their stand as conscientious objectors by refusing to pay their taxes or a proportion of their taxes. This raises a very important point as to civil disobedience on a matter of conscience and the right of a government to collect taxes by such means as declaring people bankrupt or taking money out of their bank accounts. On behalf of these people I ask the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to examine the position to ascertain whether the taxation laws are able to be altered to make allowances for people who are sincerely and genuinely conscientious objectors. In this way we are being truly honest in an approach to taxation reform in our country. Taxation is not only about collecting money it also is and must be about its distribution and it seems to me to be a reasonable proposition to advance, to analyse and, I believe, to support. As a matter of distributive justice the person who provides the funding has at least a prior right to indicate his personal conscientious objection as to how his money shall or shall not be spent.

We live in an era where civil liberties are always under debate. I suggest that it is about time equal emphasis was given to personal conscientious liberties. Let debate proceed about protection for taxpayers who, as a matter of conscience, do not want their taxes spent on what they believe are immoral purposes such as abortions. On behalf of my constituents and many people all over Australia I look forward to a reply from the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this early opportunity this year to congratulate President Kyprianou of Cyprus for the very significant improvement which occurred in the degree of support which he is able to enjoy within the House of Representatives in Cyprus. The elections in December last year, which enlarged the House of Representatives from 35 members to 56 members, resulted in the Rally Party having 19 seats with 34 per cent of the vote, Mr Kyprianou's Democratic Party winning 16 seats with 28 per cent of the vote, Communist Party-the Akel-having 15 seats with 27 per cent of the vote and the Socialist Edek Party winning six seats and 11 per cent of the vote. I feel that, to a very large extent, those results vindicate the position which President Kyprianou has adopted and the support which he quite clearly enjoys, particularly from the Greek Cypriot people today, in relation to the very unfortunate partition of that island which occurred following the invasion by Turkey 12 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the opportunity in 1984, during the year of the tenth anniversary of the Turkish invasion of Cyprus, not only to visit Cyprus but also to have the privilege of meeting and speaking with President Kyprianou. It is extremely unfortunate that that island, which has been part of the core of European civilisation for thousands of years, should have for the first time been partitioned in the way it has. I realise the efforts that have been made by President Kyprianou, the leader of the Greek Cypriots in the south, and by Mr Denktash, the leader of the Turkish Cypriots in the north. I believe that, with the continued goodwill on the part of both of those gentlemen which I consider can be further developed, the partition of Cyprus will be overcome and Cyprus as one nation, one people and one island will be restored.

When the discussions between President Kyprianou and Mr Denktash collapsed early last year, President Kyprianou then addressed the Cypriot people. I would like to quote from the address he gave to the media in Cyprus early in January 1985. In part, President Kyprianou said:

I want to believe that you are all aware that I have dedicated my life to the service of our national cause and therefore to the solution of the Cyprus problem. What I am seeking, however, is a just and viable solution and not a temporary and short-lived one. I am seeking a solution which would ensure the termination of the occupation, the physical and national survival of the Greek Cypriot people and the territorial integrity of an independent Cyprus. And I am seeking not just any compromise, but an honourable compromise which would safeguard in the best possible way the rights and interests of our people and our country. In this quest and in this effort of mine I have been and shall continue to be consistent, firm and unwavering. And I sincerely believe that in this effort I have the support of the majority of the people.
He went on:
Therefore, I consider it my duty to remain in office-
that was at a time when calls were being made for his resignation and for new elections-
and to continue from the bastion where I have been placed by the people, to work for the vindication of their struggles and sacrifices.
He concluded his address with words which, to me, were very impressive. He said:
Our responsibilities to history are enormous.

In terms of the great contribution which Cyprus and the Cypriot people have made to the development of civilisation and to that part of the world, I am able enthusiastically to endorse those remarks of the President: `Our responsibilities to history are enormous'.

I said that I had the opportunity to visit Cyprus on the tenth anniversary of the invasion of that island by a country with a population of 50 million people. I say that without wishing to denigrate or to prejudice the opportunity that may exist now for significant and successful discussions and negotiations to take place between President Kyprianou and Mr Denktash. I hope that they continue; I hope they are successful. To put this matter in perspective, Cyprus is a small island in the Mediterranean-a word which means middle of the earth-of about one seventh of the size of Tasmania. As I have said, Cyprus is a major significant contributor to the development of Western civilisation. I think we all aspire to the time when Cyprus will be reunited.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—The great debate is on about petrol pricing. In Tasmania the price of petrol at the moment is 60c a litre. I would like to make the point very clearly to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, that most people on low incomes-
—Pensioners.

—Pensioners and other people cannot afford expensive cars. The streets in Tasmania are not lined with gold like they are in Canberra. There is not a big bus service where people are picked up at every door and taken where they want to go. Most people in Tasmania and in the housing development areas live away from the city of Hobart. When we start to analyse it 60 cents a litre is nearly $3 a gallon. These people mostly have thirsty motor vehicles which do about 15 miles to the gallon, because they cannot afford the expensive, new Japanese cars that do about 35 miles to the gallon. So, by driving to work and coming home again is costing them about $3 a day. If we multiply that by five, we know what that adds to.
—The working class.

—It is not just the working class; it is the ordinary people of Australia. It is not just the farmers who are being penalised by the high cost of fuel, it is everybody in Australia. I ask the Minister for Social Security to take heed. Low income people love their motor vehicles because it is a means of getting out of the house; it is a means of entertainment. They sometimes love their cars more than their wife and their house; I know, because I have been in the motor vehicle industry all my life. If you are married to some women, I could understand that too. But the fact is that these people love their motor vehicles and consequently it is having an impact on the economy. It is costing them far too much. We have a real problem, because we are starting to talk about giving to this and giving to that, but in fact we are taking away from the price of petrol. I will go off petrol for a while as I have been making a lot of speeches about petrol. I am pleased to see that my side has jumped on the bandwagon because it is a dash good issue and it affects everybody in Australia.
—The bowser bandit.
—Highway robbery.
—Order! Honourable members will cease interjecting and encouraging other members to interject. Everyone will cease interjecting.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your protection. In Tasmania on 8 February we had a unique election. There was a swing to the Liberal Party of Australia of about 5 per cent. That was a very good weekend for the people of Hobart. We had three lots of entertainment: Torvill and Dean, Dire Straits and the Sole Bros Circus. Of course, the best entertainer in Tasmania opened the circus-me. When I opened it, I started to realise-and this will interest you, Mr Deputy Speaker-that the Government gives to the opera and it props up everything but the poor little family circus; a concern that entertains children and the elderly, gets nothing. Circus people work like demons. They said to me: `Bruce, we appreciate what you have done for us'. I worked for freight equalisation for them, I opened the circus and put on a good show for them-no crowing, but I did.
—Did you charge them?

—I did not charge. They said to me: `Bruce, what would you like us to do for you'? I said: `Give me 200 tickets so I can give them to the most worthy charities in Hobart'. I do not think Torvill and Dean did; I do not think Dire Straits did. The point I am making must be remembered: Jean Perry from that circus has had a terrible year. She has lost her husband, lost those elephants and the best clown; but the circus fights on. It does not ask governments to prop it up. It is not like the opera and the ballet and others that get the money because they are trendy. The poor old circus does not put its hand out, but it gives a lot of entertainment to the people of Australia. I applaud what it does for family entertainment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting very tired of the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) making extreme speeches that undermine the very fabric of our Anglo-Celtic culture. I would not be surprised if that man comes into this chamber one day and denounces the Queen or, heaven forbid, tries to change our flag. Just to show that I am impartial I would like to correct an error in the very good speech by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). He made a geographical error that needs to be corrected. He said that Cyprus was the centre of the world. It is well known to all educated people that the centre is Kalgoorlie.
—How would you know? You are never there.

—Kalgoorlie comprises a third of Australia, I would remind the honourable member. I am dealing with the myths perpetrated by the Opposition about farm problems. Opposition members talk in this House about the quarantining of off-farm income. I represent a lot of farmers and very few farmers ever complain to me about the off-farm income quarantining provisions. When it is explained to those who do complain, they appreciate that the position is very equitable. For every partner they can earn $20,000 without incurring any penalty, or a five-year aggregate of the income of the farm. Genuine farmers are not concerned about off-farm income, and it does no service to the farming community that the Opposition and some of the farm organisations try to tout this as a cause of falling land values. That argument is absolute nonsense. Other myths are perpetrated by Opposition members. They talk about the problems of capital gains tax. The capital gains tax introduced by this Government is the most equitable form of capital gains tax and most genuine farmers recognise this.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to talk about the real problems of the farm sector. The immediate problem of course is interest rates. I have put forward a proposal which would have some bearing on this, but the long-term problems are the problems of trade. We must address this issue by examining three main areas: The first and most important is markets. We have to get out into the community and sell our products in a much better way than is being done at present. I have a friend who is well-versed in the dairy industry and he tells me that last year he had to refuse sales to South East Asia, to Guam and to Japan because he could not get supplies.

I have recently returned from China. When I was in the city of Lanchow, one of the fabled cities of the old silk road, I visited the centre of China's oil and gas industry. There I saw row upon row of pump jacks for pumping oil, lined up all consigned to the United States. In Australia when we buy pump jacks, we buy them from the United States at four times the price of the Chinese ones. We must realise that for every dollar one buys out of China, one can sell a dollar into China. That is not the case with the United States, and we must look at these aspects.

Another area we must look at is development of the United Kingdom market. Europe's common agricultural policy is an anathema, a rort, and should never have been allowed. The Liberal Party, who were in power at the time in this country, did nothing about it, but it can be attacked. The policy will not be brought down by a frontal attack because Europe can sustain itself on about two per cent of gross domestic product. The weak link is the United Kingdom. In the United Kingdom the left-wing of the Labour Party opposes the whole of the common market, particularly the common agricultural policy. At the same time, the right wing of the Conservative Party holds exactly the same views. The middle ground of the Labour Party there is vacillating and could be convinced. We need to get into the United Kingdom where people remember where they can get good quality cheap Australian lamb and beef. We need to get into the United Kingdom and market. That is the weak link in the Common Market. I am about to run out of time, so I shall quickly address myself to the other two problems in the rural sector. I refer to marketing and marketing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a letter carrying 1,100 signatures from the people of Shepparton, which was handed to me last weekend. Those signatures were collected in two hours on Thursday afternoon from the people of Shepparton demanding the opportunity to have fuel prices reduced as per the present parity pricing arrangements.
—Whose electorate is that in?

—It is in the electorate of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I visited that area and spoke to people in the trucking industry, on which I would also like to comment. The spontaneousness of that collection of signatures is clear evidence of what the people of Australia demand. Those 1,100 signatures were collected in just two hours by the ladies of the Goulburn Valley Wives Trucking Support Group. I want to comment on the lady who is the group publicity officer, Mrs Marlene Kuhn. She drew my attention to this issue and asked me to take the letter to the Prime Minister, which I was very pleased to do. These ladies are, I imagine, unique in Australia. The trucking industry, as I well know, puts huge work loads on the drivers and they are seldom in a position to get together because they are seldom in any one place at any one time. Consequently they suffer considerably from the problems of not being able to be their own lobby group. These ladies have got together to be the lobby group on behalf of their husbands. I do not know of any other area where this has occurred, but I am now recommending it to other trucking areas.

SPEECH.PARA: These women are to be congratulated because they did a magnificent job. They know that in this day and age 30 per cent of truckies' operating costs are in fuel and they know that the simplest and easiest way to improve their present parlous condition and very low profits-much better than all the legislation this Government is bringing into the Parliament in the guise of protection for them-is to have a cut in fuel prices. When these women took up the petition the rebate should have been 7c a litre. As we heard in the Parliament today, with the fall of oil prices to $US15 a barrel, that figure should be 11c a litre. As Mrs Kuhn pointed out to me, the people of Shepparton were literally running down the street to sign this letter. Shepparton is not an extremely large town and 1,100 signatures in two hours is quite amazing.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are 48,000 people there.

—Irrespective of that, 1,100 signatures in two hours as a result of the efforts of four or five ladies is quite remarkable. They are to be congratulated on it and I hope that when the Prime Minister receives that petition from me, as I guess he will tomorrow, he will take due notice of this very genuine attempt that these ladies have made to pass that problem on.

SPEECH.PARA: I went to Shepparton to tell the people about the Interstate Road Transport Act so that they could pass that sort of information on to their husbands. Let me tell the House that they are deeply concerned about some of its implications. However, they are not as concerned as members of the Transport Workers Union of Australia will be when they discover that that legislation proposes to put a black box in their trucks which will oblige them to give information that may convict them. It is interesting that the legislation provides for some exclusions from the use of that information that will be in that electronic monitoring equipment, but these are only really exclusions based on certain criminal trials where the penalty is less than three years imprisonment. A member of a shire council in my electorate told me when we were discussing this matter that he had an experience in Germany when he was on a tourist bus equipped with one of these black boxes. The bus was pulled in to a checkpoint and the police were able to extract the information on the spot. They gave him a $400 infringement notice on the spot for speeding. Although he had never been caught, he was obliged to convict himself. Some honourable members-I heard some such speeches today-might support that approach. Nevertheless, I wonder whether members of the Transport Workers Union, as the licensed drivers of these trucks, will accept the imposition which is clearly involved. I congratulate the ladies of the Goulburn Valley Wives Trucking Support Group for their efforts on behalf of their husbands and their industry, which is a family industry. I hope that the Prime Minister realises how concerned Australians are to see that our fuel price be the world price-no more, no less. That means a cut of 11c a litre at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to express some concern about the approach being adopted by the Opposition in tackling the depression occurring in many parts of rural Australia today. My concern is that we have no Opposition. My concern is that the farmers of Australia are not being represented in the Parliament by the Opposition, which cannot put up any decent alternative policy or be constructive in its approach to the restructuring of the rural industries of Australia. I am not alone in that view. Many people in Australia share my viewpoint. Tonight in the Melbourne Herald the Deputy Director of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Rick Farley, is quoted as saying that the Federal Opposition has been ineffective during the current rural crisis. He also said that it is unclear what the Opposition's rural policies are. We know that honourable members opposite are uncertain on rural policies. Presenting a policy is very different from engaging in debate in this place, but even in debate opposite sides should put constructive viewpoints to achieve effective change.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear many words in this place, but we do not have debate about the real crisis, which makes it very difficult for the people of Australia to find out exactly what the Opposition is really on about. This is particularly so in regard to the terrible situation which is occurring in rural Australia today. I find it tragic. I am a fairly new chum here. I have been a member of this Parliament for 13 months. I thought that, coming to the national Parliament, I would be instructed in various alternatives we could consider. I thought that constructive viewpoints would be put and that we as a Government could learn from the Opposition and perhaps get some benefit from the values it represents. What do I find in 13 months? I find nothing. Not a thing has been contributed by the Opposition which is constructive. Instead, we get banter across the table. The people who listen to the Parliament out in the electorates do not believe that the Parliament can possibly operate in the disgraceful atmosphere which exists.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Link between Fluoride and Repetitive Strain Injury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to newspaper reports of tests held in Melbourne which point to a tentative link between fluoride and repetitive strain injury.
(2) Will he take action to have the matter investigated; if not, why not; if so, what action will be taken.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to tests conducted at the Nippon Dental University in Tokyo and studies at the Department of Chemistry at the University of California which have indicated that fluoride interferes with the basic genetic material DNA and with a number of enzymes in the human body.
(4) Has his Department investigated the validity of these experiments; if so, what was the result; if not, why not.
(5) What is the incidence of tooth decay in Brisbane per head of population and how does it compare with fluoridated cities in Australia.
(6) Is he able to say whether any States, cities, or municipalities in the US have withdrawn fluoride from their water supplies, if so, which ones and why was it withdrawn.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) A specialist Working Party was established by the National Health and Medical Research Council in 1984 to review current knowledge and developments in the use of fluorides in the control of dental caries. With regard to repetition strain injury the Working Party found no scientific basis for the alleged association with fluoridated water.
At its meeting on 6-7 November 1985 the National Health and Medical Research Council adopted the following recommendations:

`The Council noted that while fluoridation of drinking water is widely practised in Australia and other countries, and has been the subject of extensive investigation, there is a significant number of people in Australia who are still being denied the benefits of this well-proven public health measure.
The Council reaffirmed its previous recommendations concerning the fluoridation of water as being a safe and effective measure for the control of dental caries.'
(3) Yes.

(4) The Commonwealth Department of Health was represented on the Working Party referred to in paragraph 2 above. The Working Party investigated the studies at the Nippon Dental University in Tokyo and the Department of Chemistry at the University of California together with other published material. It was concluded that fluoride intake at levels recommended for fluoridation of water had no adverse effect on cell or enzyme function. In the laboratory studies in Japan and California extremely high levels of fluoride were used so that the results have little or no relevance in the context of fluoridated water.
A copy of the NH and MRC report `Fluorides in the control of dental caries' has been placed in the Parliamentary library.

(5) The mean DMF indices (decayed, missing or filled permanent teeth) for children aged 7 to 12 years in capital cities in 1984 are: Adelaide 1.3, Brisbane 1.4, Canberra 1.0, Darwin 0.9, Hobart 0.7, Melbourne 1.7, Perth 1.5 and Sydney, 0.9. Comparative data for adults are not available.

(6) I am unable to say whether any States, cities or municipalities in the United States of America have discontinued fluoridation of their water supplies. However, in 1983 the water supplies of 123 million people in USA were fluoridated or contained similar levels of fluoride from natural sources. This compared with 105 million people in 1977.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Australia Post written to the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations stating that Australia Post has no direct control over the duration of a strike by any union covering staff employed by the enterprise and that it cannot dictate when such employees should return to work.

(b) Does Australia Post have (a) the power and (b) the responsibility to dismiss employees who repeatedly refuse to work in accordance with the provisions of their awards and who thereby prevent Australia Post from fulfilling its responsibilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, from the information provided by Australia Post, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. This information was contained in a letter Mr R. Sly, Australia Post's Divisional Manager for its Canberra Monaro Division, sent on 5 November 1985 in response to a letter he had received from Mr F. E. Peters, Project Officer, Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations.

(b) (a) Under Division 6 of Part V of the Postal Services Act, the Australian Postal Commission has the power to dismiss an officer who has been found guilty, after an inquiry, of having failed to fulfil his duty as an officer. This failure of duty is defined under seven headings in Section 61 (1) of the Postal Services Act.

A decision by the Commission to dismiss an officer cannot take effect until the person charged has been given the opportunity to appeal to a Disciplinary Appeal Board. The procedures in Division 6 are designed to deal with individual miscreants in a fair and judicious manner with protection of the individual's right being the paramount consideration. The procedures do not lend themselves to use in cases of unified mass industrial action.

(b) (b) The refusal of an officer to work in accordance with the provisions of his or her award is not one of the seven specific circumstances which are outlined in Section 61 (1) although it could form the basis of a number of the specified circumstances in 61 (1). Australia Post has the statutory responsibility to operate the postal service in such a manner as will best meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian people. It can only dismiss employees, however, within the terms set out in Division 6 of the Postal Services Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is there a comprehensive continuing collection of Australia-wide statistics on Aboriginal health; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Currently there is no comprehensive continuing collection of Australia-wide statistics on Aboriginal health. For some years my Department has attempted to coordinate the statistics in a number of areas and these figures are published in the Department's Annual Report. The statistics, collected by some of the individual States and Territories, include the details of live births, stillbirths, deaths, including a breakdown of infant deaths, and notification of new cases of tuberculosis and leprosy.

While the tuberculosis and leprosy figures are available for all States and Territories, the coverage for the other statistics is variable. In 1984, the details of live births, stillbirths and infant deaths were only published for Western Australia and the Northern Territory, and of total deaths only for the Northern Territory. Prior to 1983 Queensland also provided figures for 14 Queensland Aboriginal reserve communities on live births, stillbirths and deaths, including infant deaths. For 1981, 1982 and 1983 South Australia provided details of live births, stillbirths and infant deaths, and it is anticipated that it will provide further figures in the future. Some figures have also been provided to my Department by New South Wales and Tasmania, but they have not been included in the Annual Report.

To overcome some of the deficiencies in statistics on Aboriginal health, this Government created in 1984 a Task Force to work towards the establishment of a national system of Aboriginal health statistics. This Task Force, consisting of senior officers of the Commonwealth Departments of Health and Aboriginal Affairs and the Australian Bureau of Statistics, held a series of discussions with State and Territory officials in September and October 1984. The basic components of a proposed national system were determined to be statistics of all births to Aboriginal mothers, deaths of Aborigines, perinatal mortality in pregnancies of Aboriginal women, and morbidity in Aborigines. The results of the discussions are included in the report of the Task Force, `Towards a National System of Aboriginal Health Statistics', published by my Department in April 1985.

The Task Force reported that all States and Territories, except Queensland, extended their full cooperation, and there was general agreement with its aims. The implementation of the recommendations involved, in some cases, further consideration by State and Territory Governments. Once implemented, the national system will produce official statistics covering the entire Aboriginal population of each State and both Territories, except Queensland, on the following topics:
births (through notification/registration systems and/or maternal/perinatal collections);
death (through notification/registration systems and/or medical certification of cause of death);
perinatal deaths (through medical certification of cause of perinatal death);
hospital morbidity (although existing systems in some States have incomplete coverage, and Tasmania does not have a hospital morbidity collection).

Implementation of changes to administrative systems will involve, or has already involved, a variety of courses of action in the different States and Territories. Some changes are purely administrative, others require legislation, and all require a great deal of development work. While the original implementation date of 1 July 1985 was found to be impossible, there is sufficient commitment on the part of all the participating Governments to be confident that the national system will be completed as soon as possible.

At Commonwealth level, the Australian Institute of Health has assumed responsibility for the continuing coordination and development of this national system of Aboriginal health statistics. Such development will of course involve further negotiations and cooperation with the States and Territories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

The time of day information is available to the computer from an extremely accurate electronic clock.
(2) The rates are changed automatically.

(3) In the last twelve months no instances have been brought to attention where there has been an error in STD trunk call charging due to a failure of the charging rate to changeover at the appropriate time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Special Minister of State: Upgrade of Air Travel of a Union Official

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 17 January 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was he involved in arranging an upgrading of air travel on Qantas for the president of a trade union in South Australia to travel to the U.K.; if so, (a) what was the name of the trade union official, (b) what was the name of the union of which is president, (c) was his wife's travel also upgraded and (d) what was the value of the additional class of travel involved in the upgrading.
(2) Did he consult another Minister to achieve the upgrading; if so, (a) who was the Minister and (b) what action did that Minister undertake.
(3) Was the trade union president undertaking an assignment for a Minister or the Government.
(4) Was any commitment given by the trade union official to him in relation to obtaining the upgrading.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable members question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have nothing to add to my response to his questions in the House during the debate on Members Interests on 13 February 1986. (Hansard, p. 446).
